Title: Chinese Government donates 3,000 rifles, 3 million rounds of ammunition, and 30 sniper cones worth P169 million for fight against terrorists in Marawi City (Linked to Project ID#65948)
Description: On October 5, 2017, the Chinese Government donated P169 million worth of military equipment to the Philippines in order to better fight terrorism in Marawi Cityi. The donation consisted of 3,000 units of rifles, 3 million rounds of assorted ammunition, and 30 sniper cones. Most of the rifles were to be turned over to the Special Action Force (SAF) of the Philippine National Police (PNP), while the scopes would remain with the AFP. The handover ceremony was held in Camp Aguinaldo.This project is linked to #65948, a $500 million loan intended for supporting the Philippine Military.

Title: China's Ministry of Defense provides RMB 100 million grant to Kyrgyzstan's Armed Forces
Description: On March 22, 2017, the Chief of Staff for Kyrgyzstan's Armed Forces met with the Defense Minister of China, Chang Wanquan. At the end of the meeting, the parties signed an RMB 100 million military grant agreement. It is unclear if any disbursements have taken place through this agreement.

Title: Chinese Government funds army training amp in Wakhan Corridor (Linked to Project ID#54116)
Description: In 2017, the Chinese Government began to build and fund a training camp in the Wakhan Corridor, a narrow strip of inhospitable land extending about 350km from the northern Afghan province of Badakhshan to China's restive Muslim region of Xinjiang. A grant agreement was reportedly signed when China's Central Military Commission Vice Chairman Xu Qiliang met with Afghan Minister of Defense Tariq Shah Bahrami on December 27, 2017. However, the monetary value of this grant agreement is unknown. In addition to financing the construction of the training camp, the Chinese Government reportedly agreed to dispatch a battalion of People's Liberation Army (PLA) soldiers (approximately 500 in total) and provide weaponry and training to the Afghan troops stationed there. Afghan General Dawlat Waziri, a spokesman for the Afghan Ministry of Defense, said that the Chinese Government would cover “all material and technical expenses for this base — weaponry, uniforms for soldiers, military equipment, and everything else necessary for its functioning.”  However, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs officially denied the construction of this training camp in 2018 (most likely because of sensitivities around the idea of China establishing an overseas military ‘base’). The Chinese Government later clarified that the facility was only developed for training and logistics purposes.
Staff Comments: This project may have been financed partially or entirely through a $70 million grant commitment that is captured via Project ID#54116.

Title: Chinese Government 2 4x4 light armored vehicles, 10,038 smoke and tear-gas grenades, and 60 night-vision goggles worth $1.2 million
Description: On September 20, 2017, the Chinese Government donated $1.2 million worth of military equipment — including two Shaanxi Baoji Special Vehicles Co Tiger 4x4 light armored vehicles, 10,038 smoke and tear-gas grenades and 60 night-vision goggles — to the Royal Bahamas Defense Force (RBDF).  The equipment was officially handed over in a ceremony at the RBDF’s Coral Harbour base in Nassau.
Source Titles: CHINA DONATES MILITARY EQUIPMENT TO THE BAHAMAS|China donates military equipment to the Bahamas|China Gives $1.2m To Buy Military Equipment
Source Publishers: Jane's Defence Weekly|China Military |The Tribune

Title: China donates military supplies to Guyana
Description: On April 4, 2017, China donates military supplies to Guyana. According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Guyana, the military supplies include 31 pieces of equipment including patrol boats, bulldozers, one excavator, water tankers, fuel tankers, tipper trucks, off-road ambulances, and several other vehicles. According to the President of Guyana, these supplies are being used for national development, protecting territory, and preventing transnational crime.

Description: On November 17, 2017, the Chinese Government donated military equipment worth 2 billion CFA to the Central African republic’s Ministry of National Defense. The equipment donation consisted of telephones, tents, sleeping bags, modular rooms, and cameras.

Title: China hosts 21 Lesotho Defense Force officers for military training (Linked to Umbrella Project #55573)
Description: On 1 August 2017, the Chinese Embassy in Lesotho celebrated the 90th anniversary of the Chinese People's Liberation Army and held an official send-off ceremony for the 21 Basotho officers headed to China for military training (see: Lesotho News Agency; Embassy). The course was scheduled to last the duration of the 2017/18 training calendar starting in September (see: Lesotho Times). Topics include: infantry-based training, engineering, communication, air force, logistics and ordinance, information technology, and military physical education. According to the Lesotho Times, this project is a part of a bilateral security cooperation framework from 2003 (umbrella project #55573).
Implementing Agencies: Lesotho Defense Force|People's Liberation Army of China

Title: Chinese Government provides $3 million grant to Liberian Ministry of National Defense
Description: In early 2017, the Ministry of National Defense of the Peoples' Republic of China (PRC) donated a batch of equipment worth RMB 20 million ($3 million) to Liberia's Ministry of National Defense. The donation consisted of medical equipment, supplies and engineering equipment. The purpose of the donation was to assist with the military medical outreach and other civil-military initiatives.
Source Titles: China Provides U.S.$3 Million Military Aid|China to Strengthen Military Friendship With Liberia
Source Publishers: AllAfrica|Front Page Africa

Title: China sends peacekeeping helicopter detachment to Sudan
Description: On October 19, 2017, the United Nations African Union Hybrid Mission in Darfur notified China's peacekeeping helicopter detachment that the 4 helicopters it had brought passed equipment verification. The detachment consisted of 140 peacekeepers and 4 Mi-171 medium multi-purpose helicopters. While in Sudan, this detachment was tasked with performing air lifts of peacekeeping troops, personnel search and evacuation, and logistics supply transportation among other support tasks. It is uncertain exactly when this detachment arrived in Sudan and when they returned to China.
Implementing Agencies: United Nations African Union Hybrid Mission in Darfur
Source Titles: China’s peacekeeping helicopter detachment to Sudan passes UN equipment verification
Source Publishers: Foreign Affairs

Title: HAMC provides 2 Harbin Y-12 aircraft to Malian Air Force
Description: On or around September 18, 2017, China provided two Harbin Y-12 twin-engine military transport aircraft on Mali's Air Force. The Y-12 is a twin engine light multi role aircraft designed and developed by Harbin Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation (HAMC) of China.
Staff Comments: 1. There is some disagreement among different sources about whether these aircraft were donated by China or purchased by Mali. The monetary value of the aircraft is also unknown. These issues warrant further investigation. 2. On August 31, 2017, the aircraft departed Guilin Liangjiang IAP for Kunming Wujiaba IAP in China, with subsequent stops in Myanmar, Pakistan (two stops), India (three stops), Oman, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Cairo and Heraklion before touching down in Malta. The aircraft departed Luqa for Houari Boumediene Airport in Algiers, before arriving in Mali. The two aircraft are TZ-WAB (c/n 095), which becomes TZ-22T with the Mali Air Force, and TZ-WAA (c/n 093), updating its registration to TZ-21T. The transports arrived at Luqa on September 18, 2017 using the callsigns ‘SXA402’ and ‘SXA403’ respectively.”

Title: Chinese and Nigerien Peacekeeping Forces conduct Joint Defense Drills
Description: In December 2017, the 5th Chinese peacekeeping detachment stationed in Mali carried out a joint defense drill with the Nigerien peacekeeping infantry battalion in Ménaka. Ménaka, Mali, was under 'orange alert', a high-risk level, since late August, 2017 due to 36 terror attacks killing more than 130 people and injuring over 130 personnel. Sixty percent of these attacks happened in Ménaka.
Source Titles: Chinese peacekeepers to Mali carry out joint drill with Niger peers
Source Publishers: People's Republic of China Ministry of Defense

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 148 million government concessional loan for Multi-Purpose Patrol Vessel Acquisition Project
Description: On October 27, 2017, China Eximbank and the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement worth RMB 148,428,000 for the Multi-Purpose Patrol Vessel Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the GCL are as follows: 2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and 5.40 year grace period. The final loan maturity date is March 21, 2038. This project sought to facilitate the acquisition of 1 multipurpose patrol vessel (with a length of 80m, a breadth of 11m, a maximum speed of 20 knots, and an endurance of 5,000 nautical miles) on behalf of the Trinidad and Tobago Defence Force (Coast Guard), provide lo­gis­tic sup­port for the ac­qui­si­tion of naval as­sets, and provide main­te­nance and train­ing for the ac­qui­si­tion of 12 naval as­sets. China Shipbuilding Trading was the contractor (CSTC) responsible for implementation. The project was successfully completed on September 9, 2015 upon delivery of the multi-purpose patrol vessel. The loan agreement to pay for the vessel was signed after its delivery, and the Chinese government went under contract to deliver the vessel on July 3, 2015. The vessel was dubbed the TTS Nelson (II), replacing an older TTS Nelson that had originally sailed as the HMS Orkney for the British Royal Navy. The original facility was recorded as a member of a group of loans that additionally contained financing from ANSA (valued at $30 million), and ING (valued at $183 million), although these loans were not used for the acquisition of the TTS Nelson (II) but for other Coast Guard purchases. As of March 2018, the Trinidad and Tobago Minister of Finance reported that the outstanding balance of the China Eximbank loan was TT$138,609,487.
Staff Comments: 1. AidData obtained the commitment date, face value, and borrowing terms of the China Eximbank loan from internal records [extracted from the Commonwealth Secretariat Debt Recording and Management System (CS-DRMS) and date stamped on March 23, 2020] that the Government of Trinidad and Tobago shared with AidData in March 2020. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the China-Latin America Finance Database, co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center. 3. The loan was originally reported to be valued at $24.2 million. However, a 2018 Public Sector Investment Report published by Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago identifies the face value of the loan as $34.2 million. AidData relies on the face value of the loan (RMB 148,428,000) that Trinidad and Tobago’s Ministry of Finance directly reported to AidData in March 2020 [based on an extract from the Commonwealth Secretariat Debt Recording and Management System (CS-DRMS)]. 4. The Chinese project title is ???????.
Receiving Agencies: Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago

Description: In August of 2017, Chinese experts completed military training to the Congolese army. The participants of the training were recruited two years previously.

Title: Chinese Government donates 4 patrol boats to Ghana Armed Forces
Description: On October 31, 2017, the Chinese Government donated four speedboats to Ghana's navy. Each boat was fitted with two propulsion engines and a generator, and capable of a maximum speed of 38 knots and have an endurance of 135 nautical miles at 30 knots. Each boat was also fitted with modern navigational and communication equipment as well as a 12.7-millimeter gun. The four boats were inaugurated at Sekondi Naval Base on November 27, 2017 by Ghana's Minister for Defense, Dominic Ntiwul. According to Ntiwul, the boat acquisition project was financed with a grant from the Chinese Government to reequip the Ghana Armed Forces after a 2017 visit to China by Ghanaian Vice President Alhaji Mahamudu Bawumia.  Multiple sources indicated that the boats were a major part of a $7.5 million dollar military aid program financed by the Chinese Government.
Source Titles: Navy Gets 4 Speed Boats|Chinese government presents speed boats to Ghana Navy|Navy receives four patrol boats|China donating boats, guns to Ghana
Source Publishers: Daily Guide (Ghana)|Graphic Online|GhanaWeb|defenceWeb
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report

Title: China sends fourth peacekeeping infantry battalion to South Sudan in 2017
Description: On November 15, 2017, the first group of soldiers from the fourth batch of China's Peacekeeping Infantry Battalion in South Sudan arrived in Juba. The rest of the peacekeepers would arrive in South Sudan by the end of November 2017. The 700-strong battalion, consists of infantry and artillery personnel, scouts, and engineers, and is drawn from the 83rd Combined Corps of the PLA. Under the United Nations Mission in South Sudan, they are assigned to protect local civilians and UN personnel and humanitarian assistance staff members, patrol defense areas, secure the UN compound, enforce a weapon-free zone and escort humanitarian assistance to areas under their jurisdiction. On November 13, 2018, the first group of soldiers from the fourth battalion returned to China while the first group from the fifth battalion arrived in South Sudan, marking the completion of the project. China has sent several groups of peacekeeping soldiers and officers to assist in South Sudan.
Implementing Agencies: People's Liberation Army of China|United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 30 million grant for provision of hydrographic and surveillance vessel to Fiji's Navy
Description: On December 21, 2018, the Chinese Government officially handed over a donated hydrographic survey vessel (a Fijian seabird) — commissioned under the name “Kacau (a Fijian seabird) — to the Fijian Navy. Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama was the chief guest at the handing over and commissioning of the state-of-art navy vessel, which took place at the Stanley Brown Naval Base, Walu Bay, Suva. The donated vessel is equipped with high-tech equipment for hydro detection. It is capable of carrying out hydrographic and maritime surveys, and providing detection data and real-time information. The vessel is a result of cooperation between the Fijian and Chinese governments as well as the Fijian Navy and People's Liberation Army Navy. The Government of Fiji has disclosed that at least RMB 30 million of previously committed grant assistance from the Chinese Government was utilized to support this vessel acquisition project. Chinese experts spent 4 months training the Fijian naval personnel to operate the  hydrographic survey vessel. A farewell ceremony for this expert group was held on March 20, 2019.
Staff Comments: The Government of Fiji has disclosed that at least RMB 30 million of previously committed grant assistance from the Chinese Government was utilized to support this vessel acquisition project. However, this is likely a lower-bound estimate of the true cost of the donation. This issue warrants further investigation.
Receiving Agencies: The Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF)

Title: Chinese Government donates 3,000 rifles and 6 million pieces of ammunition worth RMB 50 million to support fight against terrorism in Marawi City (Linked to Project ID#65948)
Description: On June 28, 2017, the Chinese Government donated a batch of weapons — including 3,000 rifles (TY-85 7.62 mm sniper rifles, CS/LR4A high precision rifles, and CQ-A5 5.56 automatic rifles) and 6 million pieces of ammunition — worth RMB 50 million (PHP 550 million) to the Government of the Philippines to support its counterterrorism efforts in Marawi City. At the handover ceremony at the Clark Air Base in Pampanga, Chinese Ambassador Zhao Jianhua announced that the Chinese Government would donate another batch of weapons in 'several months.'This project is linked to project #65948, a $500M loan to support the Philippine Military.
Staff Comments: It is unclear if this donation represents a partial fulfillment of the RMB 100 million pledge made in December 2016 (as captured via Project ID#49300). This issue merits further investigation.

Title: Chinese Government donates 60 generators to the Lebanese Armed Forces
Description: On December 20, 2017 the Chinese Government handed over 60 Generators to the Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF) at the headquarters of the Logistic Brigade in Kfarshima.Army Brig. Gen. Milad Ishaq of Lebanon was at the ceremony and thanked Chinese authorities for their “continued support for the Lebanese Army.”Chinese Ambassador Wang Kejian said that Chinese authorities were determined to bolster the Army's combat and logistic capabilities. He expressed appreciation for the Army’s efforts in maintaining local stability and fighting terrorism.

Title: Thai Defense Technology Institute (DTI) agrees to set up the country’s first commercial joint defense facility with China
Description: According to new release from Shanghai Daily released November 17, 2017, the Thai government’s Defense Technology Institute (DTI) will set up the country’s first commercial joint defense facility with China in northeast Khon Kaen province. It will be responsible for assembly, production and maintenance of Chinese land weapon systems for the Thai army. All production will be for Thai domestic official usage. The Chinese would provide training and technology transfer, but more specific details of any Chinese personnel in Khon Kaen were subject to further discussions between the ministry and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) - which makes tanks and weapons among other heavy equipment.According to a press release from The Diplomat, news surfaced in December 2016 that China and Thailand were exploring the possibility of setting up a new military facility in Thailand. In mid-December, Thai defense spokesman Khongcheep Tantrawanich said that Defense Minister Prawit Wongsuwan had raised the proposal of a facility to manufacture and repair armaments in Thailand during a meeting with his Chinese counterpart Chang Wanquan as part of his two-day visit to Beijing. Prawit had proposed that the facility be both a source of weapons parts and technology transfers to Thailand and a place to manufacture and repair armaments China supplies to Thailand and other countries in the region. Few additional details on the facility were publicly provided, and the official statement from the Chinese defense ministry on the meeting did not explicitly mention the facility.DTI will set up Thailand’s first commercial joint defense facility with China in northern Khon Kaen in July 2018, a defense ministry spokesman said.
Staff Comments: The exact date of agreement is uncertain. Additionally, it is unclear whether this joint facility has been completed.
Source Titles: WORLD NEWSNOVEMBER 16, 2017 / 3:01 AM / 2 YEARS AGO|Thais plan to set up joint arms facility with China|China, Thailand Mull Joint Military Production Facility|What’s With the New China-Thailand Military Facility?|Thailand plans joint arms factory with China

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant to BiH military for acquisition of specialized engineering and construction machines
Description: On December 6, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Ministry of Defense of Bosnia-Herzegovina (BiH) signed an RMB 10 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire specialized engineering and construction machines. The agreement was signed by the Minister of Defence of BiH, Marina Pendes, and the Ambassador of PR China in BiH, Chen Bo. No further implementation details are available.
Receiving Agencies: Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant to facilitate acquisition of non-lethal weapons (Linked to Project ID#66427)
Description: On December 26, 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to donate RMB 5 million of military grant assistance to the Government Armenia each year. Then, on September 4, 2017, the Armenian Defense Minister, Vigen Sargsyan, and the Chinese Minister of Defense and State Councilor, Chang Wanquan met to review the prior agreement and the current state of the Armenian Armed Forces. At this meeting, the parties signed a new agreement to increase the annual grant commitment amount to RMB 10 million.  In 2017, the Chinese Government donated RMB 10 million in accordance with the new agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire non-lethal action weapons in accordance with the rules of international military assistance. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: For other years' transactions and details, see umbrella project ID#66427.

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for acquisition of light armored vehicles for Belarusian Armed Forces
Description: On June 21, 2017, an initial batch of CS/VN3 light armored vehicles arrived in Belarus. This was the result of a previously signed military-technical assistance agreement with the Chinese Government wherein Beijing agreed to provide a grant for the acquisition of the vehicles. The CS/VN3, which is produced in Chongqing, has a maximum speed of 100 km/h thanks to its 245 hp turbo diesel engine. It features an operational range of 800 km. The CS/VN3 can carry up to 10 soldiers, including crew. It can be armed with a roof-mounted turret and smoke grenade launchers. The Chinese Government, in addition to providing the grant, trained Belarussian soldiers on how to operate the vehicles. The Belarusian Armed Forces were ultimately scheduled receive about 3 dozen CS/VN3 vehicles.  The second batch of vehicles arrived on January 18, 2018.

Title: PLA donates locomotives, passenger cars, and freight cars to Myanmar Military
Description: On May 26, 2017, the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) donated a batch of train equipment — including 2 locomotives, 10 passenger cars (that can carry 68 passenger cars), and 10 freight cars (that can carry 32 tons of goods) — to the Burmese (Myanmar) Defence Force.
Source Publishers: Eastday.com|CRI.com

Title: China donates 70 million RMB in vehicles, a radar, and other materials for the Armed Forces (linked to #73601, #69471, and #69606)
Description: On November 23, 2017, Minister of Defense Jorge Nieto Montesinos and the ambassador of the People's Republic of China, Jia Guide, signed a protocol agreement, which outlined equipment to be granted to the Armed Forces of Peru, worth 70 million RMB. The funds used to provide this equipment were drawn from three Free Military Assistance agreements made between 2013-2015 (see “Ministerios de Defensa de Perú y China refuerzan cooperación militar y en atención de desastres”). These three agreements are captured in projects #73601, #69471, and #69606, and were worth 30 million, 20 million, and 20 million RMB respectively. On January 8, 2019, 16 buses, 17 minivans, 11 ambulances, 4 fast patrol boats, a radar system, and other materials for the Armed Forces were delivered to the General Headquarters of the Army of Peru in San Borja, Lima, Peru. The materials were earmarked for the following branches of the Armed Forces: - 16 45-passenger buses, 16 Maxus MPV G10 minivans, and 10 CJH002 field ambulances for the Army - 4 Type 957Y fast patrol boats, 1 CJH002 ambulances, and 1 minivan for the Navy - A cooperative radar system (model DWL-001) for the Air Force  At the delivery ceremony, Ambassador Guide indicated that the donated materials would be used for both military purposes and humanitarian emergencies such as natural disasters. The delivery ceremony was also attended by the Joint Command of the Armed Forces and the President of Peru, Martín Vizcarra Cornejo (El Peruano). The materials of Project #69434 (a 50 million RMB donation of humanitarian de-mining and natural disaster response equipment) were delivered in the same ceremony.
Staff Comments: Projects #73601, #69471, and #69606 already capture the transaction amount so that is why this transaction field is empty.While there are no sources explicitly linking the Free Military Assistance agreements to this project, they are the only such agreements for which there is evidence in the time period outlined (2013-2015) and total 70 million RMB exactly. However, given the absence of such an explicit source, the funding Free Military Assistance agreements are treated similarly to Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCA): coded separately as umbrella projects.Grant involves dual-use military equipment with plausible development use; it is therefore coded as having development intent and ODA-like flow class per 1.4 coding guidelines

Title: China trains Cote d'Ivoire Navy (Linked to #66000)
Description: In 2017, 13 Chinese naval officers trained Ivorian sailors on how to operate a newly donated Chinese patrol boat (#66000) and install other related equipment. The duration and details of training are unknown.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant for provision of communications and logistics equipment to Bolivian Air Force
Description: On December 20, 2017, the Chinese Ambassador to Bolivia Liang Yu and the Bolivian Minister of Defense Reymi Ferreira signed an RMB 50 million grant agreement (‘protocol’) for the acquisition of military equipment. The grant was earmarked for the acquisition of communications and logistics equipment, including 195 radios (models XD-D23, PRC-2188, and XD-D21), 20 buses, and 20 trucks.The ultimate beneficiary of the equipment was the Bolivian Air Force (FAB). The military aid package was scheduled for delivery during the first quarter of 2018; however, its precise delivery date is unknown.
Staff Comments: Project #36118 is a potential funding mechanism, though there is not concrete evidence linking the two. It is not entirely clear if the protocol signed on December 20, 2017 provided the funding itself or if the funding came from an umbrella project.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 70 million grant for acquisition of military equipment
Description: On August 30, 2017, the Bolivian Ministry of Defense and the Chinese Government signed an RMB 70 million grant agreement (‘protocol’) for the acquisition of military equipment. Then, on or around August 3, 2018, the Chinese Government delivered 10 transport vehicles, four water purification vehicles, and 10 water tanker trucks to the Bolivian Ministry of Defense.

Title: PLA provides RMB 18 million grant for Phase 2 of the Sri Lanka Military Academy (SLMA) Auditorium Complex Project (Linked to Project ID#33487)
Description: In March 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a protocol agreement related to the provision of an RMB 18 million grant for Phase 2 of the Sri Lanka Military Academy (SLMA) Auditorium Complex Project in Diyatalawa. Phase 2 of the project involved the installation of a sound and lighting system and some building decorations. Yunnan Construction and Investment Holding Group Co. Ltd. and the Academy of Military Science of the Chinese People's Liberation Army were responsible for the design and implementation of the project.  Phase 2 of the project began on April 22, 2018 and ended on August 28, 2018. A formal project handover ceremony took place on December 15, 2018.  The state-of-the-art building was constructed in the shape of a lotus, which is the national flower of Sri Lanka and it will serve as an office, teaching and assembly space for the staff and cadets of the Sri Lanka Military Academy. The auditorium has a seating capacity of 785 seats with sound and optoelectronic facilities, central air conditioning and intelligent power supply and distribution control system. The PLA also provided RMB 100 million for Phase 1 of the SLMA Auditorium Complex Project (as captured via Project ID#33487).

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant to Armed Forces of BiH for provision of construction and engineering equipment
Description: On December 6, 2017, the Ministry of Defense of the People’s Republic of China, the Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina signed an RMB 10 million grant agreement. The proceeds from the grant agreement were used to facilitate the acquisition of construction and engineering machinery. The Ministry of Defense and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina planned to use the equipment to respond to natural disasters and repair local infrastructure.
Receiving Agencies: Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Ministry of Defense and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Title: China sends fifth batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali (Linked to Project ID# 87024)
Description: In 2017, China sent the fifth batch of soldiers for a one-year peacekeeping mission as a part of MINUSMA. This batch consisted of 395 people.They arrived for their entrance rotation ceremonies on May 17 and 25, 2017. They left after rotation ceremonies were held on May 17 and 24, 2018, and they were replaced by the sixth batch of peacekeepers. Ambassador Lu Huiying led the ceremony.
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA)
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant to Ghana Armed Forces
Description: On July 13, 2017, the Chinese Government fulfilled an earlier pledged to donate RMB 150 million of military assistance to the Armed Forces of Ghana and the Ghana Police Service. A third of the grant proceeds (RMB 50 million) was earmarked to support the Armed Forces of Ghana with financial aid and logistics in order to facilitate its peacekeeping activities (captured in this project, ID#88156). The remaining RMB 100 million was earmarked for use by the Ghana Police Service (captured in project ID#60138). The donation was formally signed over during Ghana's Vice-President Mahamudu Bawumia's visit to China on July 13, 2017. Some of the funding through this grant was reportedly used to train and educate Ghanaian service members in China. Six armed forces personnel were to be sent to China to receive training on how to use a recently donated set of boats. 28 men and women from the Ghanaian Navy, Army, and Air Force also received full scholarships to study security and defense in China
Source Titles: Aid will bolster Ghana's security forces|China donating boats, guns to Ghana
Source Publishers: China Daily-Africa Weekly|defenceWeb

Title: Chinese Government offers batch of weapons and military equipment worth RMB 100 million for anti-drug and counter-terrorism operations (Linked to Project ID##66016, #70887, and #66179)
Description: On December 19, 2016, the Chinese Government pledged to provide a batch of weapons and military equipment worth RMB 100 million ($14.4 million) to the Government of the Philippines to support its anti-drug and counter-terrorism operations. This followed the signing of a framework agreement between the two parties on October 20, 2016. At the time of the pledge, Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana said the Government of the Philippines might use the $14.4 million grant to acquire small arms, fast boats or night-vision goggles. He said ‘[w]e will finalize the deal before the end of the year and a technical working team will soon go [to China] to look at the equipment.” He also indicated that the Government of the Philippines hoped to get the Chinese armaments by the second quarter of 2017. Then, in January 2017, Lorenzana announced that his top priority was to secure speed boats (‘fast boats’) with the $14 million aid package. He also expressed interest in using the funding to acquire drones, bomb disposal equipment, sniper guns, bendable rifles, and rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs). He indicated that the speed boats would be used for patrolling in Sulu Sea in order to combat piracy and kidnapping. He also said that “We need … RPGs because our enemies are equipped with [them]. In Marawi, the Maute-ISIS have [them], but we don’t.” By text message, Lorenzana told the Manila Times that the Government of the Philippine would receive the RPGs in September 2017 and the speed boats by the end of 2017. Then, on July 29, 2018, the Chinese Government delivered four patrol boats and 30 RPGs (rocket launchers) to the Philippine Navy (PN) as a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge (as captured via Project ID#66016). The military subsequently assigned PN personnel for one week of training on the new equipment's operation and maintenance. Then, on October 29, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Philippines signed a formal handover agreement for another batch of 'law enforcement-related materials and equipment' for the Philippine National Police, the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency, and the Presidential Security Group worth RMB 50 million (as captured via Project ID#66179). This donation was also a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge.
Staff Comments: On June 28, 2017, the Chinese Government donated a batch of weapons — including 3,000 rifles (TY-85 7.62 mm sniper rifles, CS/LR4A high precision rifles, and CQ-A5 5.56 automatic rifles) and 6 million pieces of ammunition — worth RMB 50 million (PHP 550 million) to the Government of the Philippines to support its counterterrorism efforts in Marawi City (as captured via Project ID#64162). It is unclear if this donation represents a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge. This issue merits further investigation.

Title: Chinese Government donates tents, helmets, bulletproof vests, and office equipment worth RMB 20 million
Description: On March 16, 2016, the Chinese Government delivered a batch of donated materials and military equipment worth RMB 20 million (approximately $3 million) to the Government of Guinea in response to an emergency aid request following a terrorist attack against Guinea’s peacekeeping troops in Mali. The donation consisted of tents, helmets, bulletproof vests, and office equipment including computers and photocopiers machines to improve the operating conditions of the Guinean military on the frontlines of combat. The Ambassador of the People’s Republic of China to Guinea, Bian Jianqiang, attended the handover ceremony.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 80 million grant to the Mozambican Armed Forces (FADM)
Description: On December 18, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mozambique signed a military cooperation agreement. Under the agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the Mozambican Armed Forces (FADM) with technical military assistance, including training and the supply of equipment and spare parts, valued at 80 million yuan. The agreement was signed by Mozambique’s Defence Minister Salvador M’tumuke and China’s Ambassador to Mozambique Su Jian. This grant will reportedly be used build and equip the Protection Regiment, strengthen the military capacity of the FADM, and support peacekeeping missions.
Source Titles: MILITARY COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH CHINA|Mozambique and China sign military cooperation agreement|Mozambique and China sign military cooperation agreement

Title: Chinese Government donates military equipment worth $3 million
Description: In February 2016, the Chinese Government donated military equipment worth $3 million to the Government of Liberia. The military equipment donation consisted of 20 heavy-duty trucks, two graders, 10,000 sets of uniforms, and 40 military tents.
Source Titles: Liberia Praises China for Military Equipment Donations|China Donates US$3 Million Worth of Military Equipment to the Armed Forces of Liberia; President Sirleaf Lauds China?s Support to Liberia
Source Publishers: All Africa|Executive Mansion

Title: Joint Tajik-Chinese anti-terror exercises
Description: Joint Tajik-Chinese anti-terror exercises will be held in southeastern Tajikistan on the Afghan border from October 20th to 24th, 2016, privately-owned Tajik Avesta website reported on October 19th. The main purpose of the exercises is to strengthen the border with Afghanistan in connection with the difficult situation in the neighboring country and to prevent external threats to Tajikistan. The joint anti-terror drills were held from October 20th to October 24th with over 400 troops participating.Dushanbe has lately been receiving active military assistance from China, mostly free of charge within a 'humanitarian assistance' framework. China has provided its neighbor with armored vehicles, trained its military personnel and helped it build some military facilities, including the Officers' Club of the Defence Ministry in Dushanbe and a training range in the Romit Gorge.
Source Titles: Sino-Tajik anti-terror drills to be held on Afghan border| China holds first anti-terrorism drills with Saudi Arabian special forces
Source Publishers: BBC|South China Morning Post
Source Type: Media Report|Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for border facilities and military training and logistics center along the Tajikistan-Afghanistan border (Linked to Project IDs #53589 and #53977)
Description: In a decree published in September 2016, the Government of Tajikistan instructed its State National Security Committee to sign an agreement with the Chinese Government which provides for the construction of eleven border outposts of different sizes and a military training center along the Tajikistan-Afghanistan border. Then, on October 1, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed a grant agreement for the construction of three command centers, five border service outposts, five border service checkpoints and one military training and logistics center along the Tajikistan-Afghanistan border. The monetary value of this grant agreement is unknown. The military training and logistics center in Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast consists of two dozen two-story buildings and lookout towers. It was opened in 2016 under the name Sitod, which is Tajik for “headquarters.” The purpose of the center is to forestall the prospect of ethnic Uyghur militants trickling across from Afghanistan into western China. Satellite imagery suggests that the center, which is located 14 kilometers from the Afghan border, is equipped with heliports and enough barracks to house a battalion with the support of armored vehicles. It offers a springboard into Afghanistan’s Wakhan Corridor. According to on-the-ground reporting by the Washington Post in 2019, Chinese soldiers in the area wear the collar insignia of a military unit from Xinjiang, the Chinese territory where the authorities have detained an estimated 1 million Uighurs, a mostly Muslim ethnic minority.

Title: Chinese Government pledges $2.2 million of military aid to Afghanistan (linked to project #54116)
Description: In August 2016, the Chinese Government pledged a military aid package of $2.2 million to the Government of Afghanistan. The aid package was announced by the Chinese Ambassador to Afghanistan during a meeting with the Afghan Deputy Foreign Minister for administrative affairs Nasir Ahmad Andisha. It is not clear if or when the Chinese Government fulfilled this pledge.
Source Titles: China pledges $2.2 million in fresh aid to Afghanistan|China Delivers First Batch of Military Aid to Afghanistan
Source Publishers: the Khama Press|Voice of America

Title: Chinese Government provides USD $70 million of military aid to Afghanistan between 2016 and 2018 (Linked to Project ID#54115, #54398, #87491, and #87490)
Description: According to several media reports, the Chinese Government agreed to provide over $70 million worth of military aid to the Afghan Army in 2016, 2017, and 2018. This aid package supported multiple projects and activities to train and equip the Afghan military. An initial batch of military aid (consisting of parts of military vehicles, ammunition and weapons) was delivered on a Russian cargo plane to Afghanistan National Defense and Security Forces (ANDSF) in July 2016. At an official handover ceremony for this donation (captured via this project ID#54116) on July 3, 2016 attended by Chinese Ambassador Yao Jing and Afghan National Security Advisor Hanif Atmar, it was announced another shipment of military equipment was scheduled to arrive later in the year and it would include scanners for the Afghan police to detect bombs such as vehicle-born improvised explosives devices (at four different entry points to Kabul). On July 10, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Afghanistan officially handed over these four explosives-detecting scanners to the Afghan Government. This donation is captured via Project ID#87490. Then, in October 2016, Afghan Ministry of Defense Spokesperson Dawlat Waziri announced that the Afghan Air Force would soon receive two transport planes from the Chinese Government. He said that the ‘the Afghan Air Force need[ed] the planes for the transportation of the army officials on official trips inside and outside the country.’ However, it is unclear if and when this pledge (captured via Project ID#87491) was fulfilled. Another project that was likely financed through the $70 million aid package involved the establishment of a mountain brigade and the construction of a mountain outpost (training camp) in the Wakhan corridor (as captured via Project ID#54398).
Staff Comments: The monetary values of individual donations and subsidiary projects that were supported by the larger $70 million aid package are unknown. Therefore, the full monetary value of the $70 million military aid package is captured via Project ID#54116.

Title: Chinese Government donates patrol craft and other military supplies worth RMB 20 million to Barbados Defense Force
Description: On March 15, 2016, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the Barbados Defence Force (BDF) signed an RMB 20 million (BDS 6 million) military grant agreement. Then, on December 20, 2016, a protocol agreement was signed with the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the BDF, outlining the specific equipment to be donated. On February 26, 2017, a formal handover ceremony took place at St. Ann’s Fort for the supplies, which included 4×4 vehicles, a mobile kitchen, a refrigerator van, a tractor, and a 958-series naval patrol craft named Endurance. The patrol boat's christening ceremony took place on July 20, 2018, at which the Barbados Defense Force Chief of Staff, Colonel Glyne Grannum, indicated that the vessel would be essential in building the BDF's capacity to monitor and secure over 183,000 square kilometers of Barbadian ocean. It was also to be used in anti-smuggling efforts. The other equipment will primarily be used in disaster preparation and relief efforts, particularly for hurricanes.
Staff Comments: This is the only project associated with the March 15 Free Military Assistance Agreement found: therefore, a separate umbrella project has not been created for it. One government source from Barbados gives the protocol agreement date as December 19, 2017 (see 'Featured Stories...'). However, the majority of other sources, including another official source from Barbados, places the agreement in 2016, which is why AidData codes the agreement date as being from 2016.

Title: China sends third peacekeeping infantry battalion to South Sudan
Description: In December 2016, China's third peacekeeping infantry in South Sudan was deployed. On October 2, 2017, the UN Mission in South Sudan presented UN medals to the members of this battalion. The exact date that they left from South Sudan is unknown. The battalion was sent to help maintain peace in South Sudan, focusing in particular on protecting civilians.
Staff Comments: The flow class has been coded as military as the exact purpose for the peacekeeping troops is unspecified.
Source Titles: Medal Presentation Parade Held at UNMISS to Award UN Medals to CHNBATT|China dispatches third peacekeeping infantry battalion to South Sudan
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in South Sudan|ChinaDaily

Title: Chinese Government provide RMB 50 million grant for provision of 27 armored tanks and 4 riot control trucks to the Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: On March 10, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Bolivia signed an RMB 50 million (equivalent to 7.6 million USD) grant agreement. The proceeds of the grant were to be used to acquire 27 armored tanks and 4 riot control trucks for the Bolivian Armed Forces. 19 vehicles were earmarked for the Army (including two anti-riot trucks), 6 vehicles were earmarked for the Air Force (including one anti-riot truck), and 6 vehicles were earmarked for the Bolivian Navy (including one anti-riot truck). The donation also included training to handle and maintain the equipment. The vehicles arrived in Bolivia in the summer of 2016, with records of their import taxes being waived on August 2, 2016.
Staff Comments: The Spanish project title is 31 vehículos blindados.

Title: Chinese People's Liberation Army assistance in construction of Lao People's Army ASEAN light weapons shooting arena
Description: On April 10th, 2018,  the transfer ceremony of the Lao People's Army ASEAN Light Weapons Shooting Field project (or ?????????????????????) was held in Vientiane, Laos. The Lao People’s Army ASEAN light weapons shooting arena project is a project implemented by the China Construction Engineering Corporation Company (CCECC) with assistance from the Ministry of National Defense of the People’s Republic of China based on the grant agreement signed by China and Laos. The project started in December 2016, was completed at the end of February 2018, and passed the inspection and acceptance of the expert group at one time.
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic|

Title: Chinese Government provides $833 million loan for acquisition of tanks, arms, ammunition, and anti-aircraft defense systems
Description: On July 13, 2016, representative of China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group) and Poly Technologies met with the Iraqi Defense Ministry to discuss a $2.5 billion contract for the acquisition of military equipment including arms, ammunition, HQ-9 long-range surface-to-air (SAM) missiles, and VT-4 battle tanks. Iraq’s Council of Ministers subsequently authorized the Iraqi Minister of Finance to buy $2.5 billion of military equipment from NORINCO Group and Poly Technologies on behalf of Iraq’s Ministry of Defense, Iraq’s Ministry of Interior, Iraq’s PMU Commission and the Iraqi Counter Terrorism Service and to contract an $833 million loan in 2017 to finance the first installment of the contract. Multiple sources indicate that an unspecified Chinese state-owned institution agreed to provide the loan to the Iraqi Federal Ministry of Finance. The $833 million face value of the loan has been corroborated by the IMF.  However, the borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.  As of March 25, 2019, the IMF Mission Chief for Iraq reported to AidData’s Executive Director that no disbursements had taken place through the loan.
Implementing Agencies: China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group) |Poly Technologies

Title: Chinese Government pledges $500 million loan to procure military equipment (Linked to Project ID#64162 and #49300)
Description: On December 19, 2016, the Chinese Government offered the Government of the Philippines a long-term soft loan worth $500 million that could be used to procure defense equipment (including airplanes, drones, and fast boats) and to fight illegal drugs and terrorism. Then, on May 15, 2017, the Philippine Defense Secretary Delfin N. Lorenzana signed a non-binding letter of intent regarding $500 million loan with Poly Technologies, an arms manufacturer and a subsidiary of China Poly Group. During a press briefing, Secretary Delfin N. Lorenzana stressed that, “This is an intent and we are going to send … a technical working group to look at the equipment and see what we need. We are not saying that we will buy from them or we will not buy from them but if we need anything from the Chinese defense industry then we’re going to procure using the loan that they are going to offer to us.'
Staff Comments: This project is linked to a weapons donation to the Philippine military (captured via Project ID#64162) and a $14 million grant for equipment to fight drugs and terrorism (captured via Project ID#49300).

Title: Chinese Government donates 4 naval patrol boats and 30 RPGs (Linked to Project ID#49300, #66179 and #70887)
Description: On December 19, 2016, the Chinese Government pledged to provide a batch of weapons and military equipment worth RMB 100 million ($14.4 million) to the Government of the Philippines to support its anti-drug and counter-terrorism operations. This followed the signing of a framework agreement between the two parties on October 20, 2016. At the time of the pledge, Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana said the Government of the Philippines might use the $14.4 million grant to acquire small arms, fast boats or night-vision goggles. He said ‘[w]e will finalize the deal before the end of the year and a technical working team will soon go [to China] to look at the equipment.” He also indicated that the Government of the Philippines hoped to get the Chinese armaments by the second quarter of 2017. Then, in January 2017, Lorenzana announced that his top priority was to secure speed boats (‘fast boats’) with the $14 million aid package. He also expressed interest in using the funding to acquire drones, bomb disposal equipment, sniper guns, bendable rifles, and rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs). He indicated that the speed boats would be used for patrolling in Sulu Sea in order to combat piracy and kidnapping. He also said that “We need … RPGs because our enemies are equipped with [them]. In Marawi, the Maute-ISIS have [them], but we don’t.” By text message, Lorenzana told the Manila Times that the Government of the Philippine would receive the RPGs in September 2017 and the speed boats by the end of 2017. Then, on July 29, 2018, the Chinese Government delivered four patrol boats and 30 RPGs (rocket launchers) to the Philippine Navy (PN) as a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge (as captured via Project ID#66016). The military subsequently assigned PN personnel for one week of training on the new equipment's operation and maintenance. Then, on October 29, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Philippines signed a formal handover agreement for another batch of 'law enforcement-related materials and equipment' for the Philippine National Police, the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency, and the Presidential Security Group worth RMB 50 million (as captured via Project ID#66179). This donation was also a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge.
Staff Comments: On June 28, 2017, the Chinese Government donated a batch of weapons — including 3,000 rifles (TY-85 7.62 mm sniper rifles, CS/LR4A high precision rifles, and CQ-A5 5.56 automatic rifles) and 6 million pieces of ammunition — worth RMB 50 million (PHP 550 million) to the Government of the Philippines to support its counterterrorism efforts in Marawi City (as captured via Project ID#64162). It is unclear if this donation represents a partial fulfillment of the December 2016 pledge. This issue merits further investigation.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million military grant for unspecified purposes in 2016 (Linked to Project ID#66427)
Description: On December 26, 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to donate RMB 5 million of military grant assistance to the Government of Armenia each year. Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government donated RMB 5 million to the Government of Armenia in concurrence with the 2013 agreement. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: For other years' transactions and details, see umbrella project ID#66427.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 30 million grant to Serbia's Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes
Description: On June 21, 2016, a donation protocol was signed between the Serbian Ministry of Defense and the Chinese Ministry of Defense in Beijing. The donation protocol provided for a grant of up to 30 million RMB for unspecified purposes.
Source Publishers: |Institute for Political Studies in Belgrade

Title: Governments of China and Bolivia pledge to sign cooperation agreement providing 30 million USD in free military aid
Description: Reports from late July and early August 2016 indicate plans for the Chinese and Bolivian governments to sign a cooperation agreement for $30 million in free military assistance in September of the same year. The intent of the planned donation was to strengthen the logistical and operational capacity of the Bolivian Armed Forces and would involve the donation of war and logistical equipment. Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira announced the intention to sign such an agreement at an event for the arrival of armored vehicles (see project #64949) in July 2016.

Title: Chinese Government donated 36 military vehicles to Kenyan Defence Forces
Description: The Kenya Defence Forces announced the donation of 36 military vehicles from the People’s Republic of China on November 29, 2016. The Kenya Defence Forces' Twitter page published photos showing refrigerated trucks, bulldozers, recovery vehicles, and fuel tankers painted in military green. The 36 vehicles were handed over by Dr. Liu Xianfa, Chinese Ambassador to Kenya. According to defenceWeb, the vehicles are worth $4.5 million. China also donated three containers of spare parts, which were handed over to Defence Cabinet Secretary Raychelle Omamo at the department’s headquarters in Nairobi.

Title: China granted 40 million RMB to Guyana for military aid
Description: In February 2016, the Government of China granted the Guyana military 40 million RMB for military aid. The aid package included two patrol boats and road infrastructure equipment. The Guyana Defense Force (GDF) Fourth Engineering Battalion will use the materials for development work in the hinterland, and the Coast Guard will use the equipment to increase patrols in the Coastland and Riverain areas. GDF Chief of Staff Brigadier General Mark Phillips and Chinese ambassador, Zhang Limin signed on the relevant protocol at the Defense Headquarters in Base Camp Ayanganna. At the event, both leaders expressed an interest in future military infrastructure projects in the hinterland of Guyana. .
Source Titles: President Granger receives courtesy call from Chinese Military Delegation|China provides military aid package to Guyana
Source Publishers: Ministry of the Presidency |Kaieteur News

Title: China provides Bolivian Navy 50 million RMB in supplies through December 2016 Free Military Assistance Agreement
Description: On December 28, 2016, the Bolivian and Chinese Defense Ministers signed a Free Military Assistance agreement that granted Bolivia 50 million RMB in military equipment with a five year use period. On February 27, 2018, an agreement to use the grant to acquire 928C type boats, King Long KLQ6115H buses, and communications equipment was signed by the Chinese Ambassador to Bolivia and the new Bolivian Defense Minister. The equipment is expected to be delivered to the Bolivian Navy, though there is currently no confirmation of the equipment delivery.
Staff Comments: Because it is assumed only this acquisition was financed through the 2016 Free Military Assistance agreement, a separate umbrella project has not been created for it.

Title: China commits to grant Bolivia 50 million RMB in March 2016 Free Military Assistance Agreement
Description: On March 10, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Bolivia and Bolivia’s Minister of Defense signed a Free Military Assistance agreement which will provide 50 million RMB in grants to the Bolivian Armed Forces over a five year period. The funds will most likely be put towards technological, communications, and transportation equipment identified as important for the Bolivian Armed Forces by the Ministry of Defense, according to Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira. El Diario reports the grants will fund patrol boats, machine guns, computers, radio equipment, parachutes, camouflage uniforms, and other equipment.
Receiving Agencies: Bolivia Armed Forces|Bolivia Ministry of Defense

Title: Chinese Government provides $28 million grant for provision of refurbished ‘P-62’ naval patrol (frigate) to Sri Lankan Navy
Description: On October 13, 2016, the Ministry of Defense of China and the Ministry of Defense of Sri Lanka signed a military aid agreement for the provision of a refurbished ‘P-62’ warship (frigate). The Chinese Government initially committed RMB 120 million of grant funding in 2016, but through subsequent military aid agreements, it eventually increased its total grant commitment to $28 million. The purpose of the project was to refurbish an Offshore Patrol Vessel (OPV) — commissioned under the name 'SLNS Parakramabahu' — for use by the Sri Lankan Navy. The ship with the Pennant No 625 is 112 meters in length and 12.4 meters in width. It can travel at a maximum speed of 25 knots and it has an endurance of 3500 nm at 18 knots. The ship is a Type 053H2G Jiangwei-I (NATO Codename) class Frigate and it was originally built between 1988 and 1991 in Hudong Zhonghua Shipyard in Shanghai. The vessel was commissioned in 1994 as Tongling under Pennant No 542 and was deployed for duties very effectively by the People's Liberation Army Navy (PLAN). The refurbished ship was officially handed over to the Sri Lankan Navy on June 5, 2019 at a naval shipyard in Shanghai. The vessel arrived in Colombo Port on July 8, 2019. The ship’s commission ceremony was on August 22, 2019.
Staff Comments: 1. This project is also known as the Offshore Patrol Vessel (OPV) Acquisition Project. 2. In March 2017, the Ministry of Defense of China and the Ministry of Defense of Sri Lanka signed an RMB 100 million military aid agreement for an unspecified purpose. The proceeds from this grant agreement were likely used as supplementary funding (to the RMB 120 million grant commitment in 2016) to support the acquisition of the SLNS Parakramabahu. Therefore, to avoid double-counting, AidData has not documented the RMB 100 million grant commitment in a separate record.

Title: Chinese Government provides $3 million grant for provision of military equipment
Description: In November 2016, the Chinese Government provided a $3 million grant to the Ghana Armed Forces for the provision of four naval patrol vessels, machine guns, rifles, and ammunition
Source Titles: Ghana to receive Chinese patrol boats this month
Source Publishers: Defence Web

Title: China sends fourth batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali (Linked to Project ID# 87024)
Description: In 2016, China sent a fourth batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali for MINUSMA for the period of a year. The peacekeeping troops were sent home in a rotation ceremony led by Ambassador Lu Huiying on May 17 and 25 of 2017. They were replaced by the fifth batch of peacekeeping troops. A terrorist attack occurred on May 31, 2016, and a peacekeeper by the name of Shen Liangliang died in service. A memorial was held on June 7, 2016, and Ambassador Lu delivered a eulogy.
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA)
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source
Geographic Location: Bamako, Mali

Title: Chinese Government donates 4 explosives-detecting scanners to Afghan Army (Linked to Project ID#54116)
Description: According to several media reports, the Chinese Government agreed to provide over $70 million worth of military aid to the Afghan Army in 2016, 2017, and 2018. This aid package supported multiple projects and activities to train and equip the Afghan military. An initial batch of military aid (consisting of parts of military vehicles, ammunition and weapons) was delivered on a Russian cargo plane to Afghanistan National Defense and Security Forces (ANDSF) in July 2016. At an official handover ceremony for this donation (captured via Project ID#54116) on July 3, 2016 attended by Chinese Ambassador Yao Jing and Afghan National Security Advisor Hanif Atmar, it was announced another shipment of military equipment was scheduled to arrive later in the year and it would include scanners for the Afghan police to detect bombs such as vehicle-born improvised explosives devices (at four different entry points to Kabul). On July 10, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Afghanistan officially handed over these four explosives-detecting scanners to the Afghan Government. This donation is captured via this project ID#87490. Then, in October 2016, Afghan Ministry of Defense Spokesperson Dawlat Waziri announced that the Afghan Air Force would soon receive two transport planes from the Chinese Government. He said that the ‘the Afghan Air Force need[ed] the planes for the transportation of the army officials on official trips inside and outside the country.’ However, it is unclear if and when this pledge (captured via Project ID#87491) was fulfilled. Another project that was likely financed through the $70 million aid package involved the establishment of a mountain brigade and the construction of a mountain outpost (training camp) in the Wakhan corridor (as captured via Project ID#54398).
Staff Comments: The monetary values of individual donations and subsidiary projects that were supported by the larger $70 million aid package are unknown. Therefore, the full monetary value of the $70 million military aid package is captured via Project ID#54116.
Source Titles: Afghan Air Force To Receive 2 Transport Planes From China|China may ‘push forward’ Afghanistan peace process to protect Belt and Road interests |China’s Strategic Assessment of Afghanistan|Quarterly Monitoring Brief -- Afghanistan - Third+Monitoring+Brief+Afghanistan+FINAL+May+-+July+2016.pdf|China Delivers First Batch of Military Aid to Afghanistan
Source Publishers: Defense World|South China Morning Post|Texas Natinal Security Review|Barcelona Centre for International Affairs|Voice of America
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)|Media Report

Title: Chinese Government pledges to donate 2 transport planes to Afghan Army (Linked to Project ID#54116)
Description: According to several media reports, the Chinese Government agreed to provide over $70 million worth of military aid to the Afghan Army in 2016, 2017, and 2018. This aid package supported multiple projects and activities to train and equip the Afghan military. An initial batch of military aid (consisting of parts of military vehicles, ammunition and weapons) was delivered on a Russian cargo plane to Afghanistan National Defense and Security Forces (ANDSF) in July 2016. At an official handover ceremony for this donation (captured via Project ID#54116) on July 3, 2016 attended by Chinese Ambassador Yao Jing and Afghan National Security Advisor Hanif Atmar, it was announced another shipment of military equipment was scheduled to arrive later in the year and it would include scanners for the Afghan police to detect bombs such as vehicle-born improvised explosives devices (at four different entry points to Kabul). On July 10, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Afghanistan officially handed over these four explosives-detecting scanners to the Afghan Government. This donation is captured via Project ID#87490. Then, in October 2016, Afghan Ministry of Defense Spokesperson Dawlat Waziri announced that the Afghan Air Force would soon receive two transport planes from the Chinese Government. He said that the ‘the Afghan Air Force need[ed] the planes for the transportation of the army officials on official trips inside and outside the country.’ However, it is unclear if and when this pledge (captured via this project ID#87491) was fulfilled. Another project that was likely financed through the $70 million aid package involved the establishment of a mountain brigade and the construction of a mountain outpost (training camp) in the Wakhan corridor (as captured via Project ID#54398).
Staff Comments: The monetary values of individual donations and subsidiary projects that were supported by the larger $70 million aid package are unknown. Therefore, the full monetary value of the $70 million military aid package is captured via Project ID#54116.

Title: Chinese Government donates 44 vehicles to PNG Defense Force
Description: In January 2016, the Chinese Government delivered 44 vehicles — including .trucks, buses and smaller one-tonne vehicles — to the Papua New Guinea Defence Force. However, the donation was impounded at the Port Moresby wharf due the fact that the Papua New Guinea Defence Force did not pay the required import duties. The military asked customs officials to waive the import tax because it was receiving a gift to the government, but the request was rejected.

Description: On March 24, 2016, the Chinese Government donated a batch of equipment to ECOWAS Commission. The donation consisted of Personnel Protective Equipment, High-Capacity Generators, Tents and Tentages, Ablution Facilities, Portable Kitchens, Movable Cabins,  IT and Communications Equipment, and 8 motor transport vehicles (including 3 Command Vehicles, 2 32-Seater Buses, an Ambulance, a 10,000 Liters Capacity Fuel Tanker, and a 10,000 Liters Capacity Water Tanker. Title: Chinese Government provides grant for Tajik Drug Control Agency Office Building Construction Project
Description: In 2016, the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China provided a grant to the Government of Tajikistan for the Tajik Drug Control Agency Office Building Construction Project. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. The purpose of this project was to construct a three-story brick-concrete office building — with offices, equipment rooms, interrogation rooms, and lounges — for the Tajik Drug Control Agency in the city of Kulob (approximately 40 kilometers from the Afghan border). China Jing’an Import and Export Corporation (also known as China Jing An Import and Export Corporation or ????????), which is a major state-owned arms and materials supplier to China’s security services, was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on March 18, 2016. Tajikistan’s border force unveiled new Norinco VP-11 mine-resistant ambush-protected vehicles (of which there are two visible in online photos) and Shaanxi Baoji Tiger vehicles (of which there are eight visible in online photos). These were unveiled alongside dozens of armored Chrysler jeeps.

Title: Chinese Government provides $1.2 million grant for the African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia (Linked to Project ID#41113, #52298, #60859)
Description: In September 2015, China's mission to the African Union (AU) committed $1.2 million USD to support the AU's peacekeeping mission in Somalia. AU commissioner for peace and security Smail Chergui and Kuang Weilin, the head of China's permanent mission to the AU, signed the grant agreement at the AU headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Title: Chinese Government funds construction of PLA military base in Djibouti (Linked to Project ID#59375)
Description: In June 2015, the Government of Djibouti and the Chinese Government signed an agreement on the establishment of military base in Djibouti. Construction of the heavily fortified naval base began in March 2016. On July 11, 2017, the People's Liberation Army Navy dispatched ships from the South Sea Fleet in Zhanjiang to open the base. Then, on August 1, 2017, the Chinese Government officially inaugurated the PLA Military Support Base in Djibouti. It is is 0.5 square kilometers (0.2 sq mi) in size and staffed by approximately 1,000-2,000 personnel, and has an underground space of 23,000 square meters. The base has a 400 meter runway with an air traffic control tower, as well as a large helicopter apron. The base also houses the PLA Support Base Hospital in Djibouti. The first live fire exercises were conducted on September 22, 2017. Then, around May 2018, the Chinese Government began constructing a large-scale pier (over 330 meters in length or 1,120 feet) at the base, and it appeared to be fully completed after 18 months from a satellite photo taken in December 2019. Satellite analysis also suggests that the Chinese Government may be building a second pier or quay as to increase the naval capacity of the base.The Chinese Government funded the construction of the facility; however, neither the monetary value nor the financial modality used to support this project are known. According to IMF, the agreement signed in June 2015 between the Government of Djibouti and the Chinese Government on the establishment of military base was expected to generate $20 million a year of revenue for the Government of Djibouti (via rental payments).The base is physically co-located with the Port of Doraleh (which was constructed with a $344 million China Eximbank loan, as captured via Project ID#59375) to the west of Djibouti City. To the south of the city are several other foreign military bases, including Camp Lemonnier (United States Navy), Base aerienne 188 (French Air Force), and the Japan Self-Defense Force Base Djibouti. The base is strategically situated by the Bab-el-Mandeb Strait, which separates the Gulf of Aden from the Red Sea and guards the approaches to the Suez Canal. The base is reportedly being used for intelligence collection, non-combat evacuation operations, peacekeeping operations support, anti-piracy and counterterrorism activities. Independent observers have also noted that the base will increase China's power projection in the Horn of Africa and the Indian Ocean, as well as the blue water capabilities of Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy (PLAN). The 1,120 foot pier is reported to be long enough to be able to fit the PLAN's two new aircraft carriers and other warships or at least four nuclear powered submarines.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ????????????????????.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for Okahandja Defense Academy Project (Linked to projects #1282 and #68444)
Description: On March 16, 2008, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 60 million interest-free loan to the Government of Namibia for the Okahandja Defense Academy Project. These funds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed by the two governments (see Project ID#68444). The Chinese Government also provided a supplemental RMB 10 million grant to support this project in 2015. Project ID#1282 captures the loan and this project captures the grant. The Okahandja Defense Academy Project involved the construction of a National Defense Academy in Okahandja. The new military academy was designed to accommodate between 30 and 50 trainees per course and provide training for officers. Jiangsu Zhengtai Construction Group, a state-run Chinese company, was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in September 2011. During the construction of the company, workers reportedly faced harsh working conditions and ultimately went on strike, which led to major delays. The project was officially completed and handed over to the Namibian authorities on October 17, 2019. The Chinese project title is ?????????? or ???????????? or ???????????.
Implementing Agencies: Jiangsu Zhengtai Construction Group Co., Ltd.

Title: Indian and Chinese Army Host Anti-Terrorism Military Exercise Together
Description: October 12, 2015, Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) and Indian Army (IA) began a joint counter-terrorism exercise, codenamed Hand-in-Hand 2015, at Kunming Military Academy in Yunnan province located in southwestern China. The Hand-in-Hand counter-terrorism drill is the fifth held since 2007. It involves 175 soldiers from the Indian Army’s Naga Regiment of the Eastern Command and 144 military personnel from China’s Chengdu Military Area Command and will continue until October 22, 2015. The goal of the exercise is to develop joint operating capability, share useful experience in counter-terrorism operations and to promote friendly exchanges between the armies of India and China. The exercise involved warships visit from both countries to the other, maritime search and rescue exercise, and passing exercise (the Chinese term:'??'). The project has been completed.
Staff Comments: The transaction value is unclear.
Implementing Agencies: Indian Army|People's Liberation Army of China

Title: China signs agreement to Improve Anti-Terrorism Capabilities of Afghanistan (Linked to projects #54038 and #53999)
Description: On November 3, 2015, Chinese Vice President, Li Yuanchao, signed the cooperation agreement with Afghan President, Ashraf Ghani, to improve the anti-terrorism and defense capabilities of Afghanistan, on the reception of the 60th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Afghanistan. China affirmed its position to commit in the reconciliation process between Afghan government and the Taliban. Before the agreement, China has demonstrated its efforts through hosting Taliban representatives in January 2015, and sending an experienced diplomat as a special envoy to Afghanistan in 2014.This project is linked to two other technical agreements that were also signed on November 3, 2015: a 500 million Yuan grant for the construction of 10,000 apartments for civil servants in Kabul (#53999) and a grant of 1500 scholarships for Afghan students (#54038).

Title: Chinese Government donates weapons and ammunition to the Lebanese Army
Description: On July 3, 2015, the Chinese Government donated a batch of weapons and ammunition to the Lebanese Army logistic brigade. The Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF) statement did not specify type or quantity of weapons and ammunition included in the shipment. The donation was received via Beirut seaport before noon and it was meant to help Lebanon contain militants on its eastern border with Syria. Two weeks later, on July 16, 2015, the Lebanese Army received a second batch of weapons and ammunition from China. The shipment was received during a ceremony attended by Brig. Gen. Manuel Kridgian representing Army Commander Gen. Jean Kahwagi, while China was represented by its ambassador to Lebanon Jiang Jiang and his military attaché Yang Jun. According to the pictures attached to the statement, the shipment included at least three sniper rifles and boxes of ammunition.

Title: Chinese Government provides military assistance to Iraq in 2015
Description: In September 2015, the Asia Times reported that the Chinese Government provided Iraq with military assistance, and the Iraq Ministry of Defense released a video (no longer available) showing the launch of a Chinese CH-4B combat drone from al-Kut Air Base. In early August 2015, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi visited China. The Prime Minister said that part of the visit would focus on fortifying Iraq's military with equipment to 'increase the military's combat capabilities' against ISIS. As of the end of June 2019, the U.S. Government reported that, due to maintenance problems, only one of Iraq's Chinese-made CH-4B drones was fully mission capable, contributing to a major shortfall in intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance capacity

Title: PLA provides RMB 30 million grant for provision of naval patrol vessel and other maritime equipment (Linked to Project ID#69507)
Description: In 2015, the People's Liberation Army of China and the Ivorian Armed Forces signed an RMB 30 million (CFA 2.5 billion) grant agreement for the provision of a naval patrol vessel and other maritime equipment (including a crane, forklift, navigation and communication equipment, military vehicles, and other items to furnish a naval workshop). The Chinese patrol boat was launched on May 19, 2017 and a few weeks later it arrived on the coast of Abidjan. Then, on December 8, 2017, the Chinese Ambassador hosted an official equipment delivery ceremony on the Vridi Canal. The naval patrol boat, now named Atchan II, will reportedly be use to improve Cote d'Ivoire's capacity to enforce maritime policies and curb piracy. The construction start date and building firm are unknown. The Chinese Government also employed a team of 13 experts to train Ivorian naval officers on how to operate the boat (as captured via Project ID#69507).

Title: Chinese Government provides military grant worth RMB 5 million in 2015 (Linked to Project ID#66427)
Description: On December 26, 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide an RMB 5 million military grant to the Government of Armenia. In 2015, the Chinese Government gave the Government of Armenia RMB 5 million in concurrence with this agreement.  For other years' transactions and details, see umbrella Project ID#66427.
Source Titles: Armenia adds Beijing to its delicate Balancing Act|China to provide 50 million yuan military aid to Armenia
Source Publishers: Belt & Road News|Armenpress

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 7 million grant for provision of military equipment to Serbia's Ministry of Defense
Description: On December 14, 2015, a donation protocol was signed between the Serbian Ministry of Defense and the Chinese Ministry of Defense in the city of Belgrade. The donation protocol provided for a grant of RMB 7 million in the form of military equipment. The donated items include 16 rubber boats, 16 outboard engines, five snowmobiles and ten portable devices for detecting explosive devices, one part of which would go to the Special Brigade and the rest to the River Flotilla, branches of the Serbian Armed Forces. On June 20, 2017, a handover certificate was signed between Chinese Ambassador Li Manchang and Serbian Defense Minister Zoran Djordjevic in the city of Pancevo, Serbia.
