Title: CATIC provides $211 million supplier credit for L-15 Trainer Jet Acquisition Project
Description: In 2015, China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) — a subsidiary of Aviation Industry Corporation of China (AVIC) — signed a $211 million supplier credit agreement with the Government of Zambia for the L-15 Trainer Jet Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this supplier credit were used by the Zambia Air Force (ZAF) to purchase six L-15 Trainer Jets, which were ordered by the ZAF in April 2014. All six jets were successfully delivered by CATIC to ZAF by January 20, 2017. The L-15 Falcon (??), which is also known as the Hongdu JL-10, is a supersonic advanced training and light combat aircraft being developed by a subsidiary of CATIC called Hongdu Aviation Industry Corporation (HAIC). ZAF was reportedly the first overseas customer to purchase the Chinese-made L-15 Trainer Jets.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ?????6 ?L15. Most sources list the cost of the jets at around $100 million, although the SAIS_CARI database lists the total supplier's credit amount at $211 million.
Funding Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)
Implementing Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 45.6 million grant for Intelligence Technology Equipment Project (Linked to Project ID#72692)
Description: On April 20, 2015, during the period of President Xi Jinping’s visit to Pakistan, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 45.6 million of grant funding for a military project that the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to as ‘Intelligence Technology Equipment’ in its Year Book for Fiscal Year 2015/16. According to the same source, this project was completed and the equipment was successfully delivered. However, the precise delivery date is unknown. An additional Chinese Government grant was provided for this project in 2014 (as captured via Project ID#72692).
Staff Comments: The RMB 45.6 million grant assigned above is the part of a CNY 700 million grant, which was approved on Nov 18, 2014 and was arranged to be utilized for mutually agreed in the future. There is another RMB 25 million grant (captured by project ID#72692) that also belongs to the approved 700 million grant and serves for the Defence related Project.
Source Titles: Pakistan Economic Affairs Division 2014-15 Year Book|Pakistan Ministry of Finance Economic Affairs Division Year Book 2015-16|YEAR BOOK 2014-15
Source Publishers: Government of Pakistan|Pakistan Ministry of Finance|GOVERNMENT OF PAKISTAN ECONOMIC AFFAIRS DIVISION
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Chinese government grants 30 million RMB to Peru's Ministry of Defense through Free Military Assistance Agreement (linked to #69437)
Description: In June 2015, the Chinese Ministry of Defense signed a Free Military Assistance Agreement with the Peruvian Ministry of Defense, granting the latter 30 million RMB. The funds would be used to provide equipment to the Peruvian Armed Force, though the particular projects to be funded with the grant were unspecified at the time the agreement was signed. The funds provided applied to the 2014 budget period.On November 23, 2017, a protocol agreement was signed, outlining the vehicles and other materials to be granted using funds from this Free Military Assistance agreement, along with two other Free Military Assistance agreements (see project #69437).
Staff Comments: Funding to a ministry of defense should be counted as military flows.
Receiving Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Implementing Agencies: China Ministry of Defense|Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)

Source Publishers: Government of Peru|Andina - Agencia Peruana de Noticias|El Tiempo

Title: China sends third batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali (Linked to Project ID# 87024)
Description: In 2015, China sent a third batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali for a one-year service for MINUSMA. On May 19, 2016, they were sent home after a rotation ceremony where they were replaced by the fourth batch of peacekeeping forces that China sent. Ambassador Lu praised the third batch particularly for weathering out great heat.
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant for Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: In March 2016, Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira disclosed that the Government of Bolivia received assistance from the Chinese Government worth RMB 50 million ($7,675,000) in 2015 to support the Bolivian Armed Forces. These funds were committed through a grant agreement that was signed by the Chinese Government and the Government of Bolivia in November 2015. These funds were reportedly used to purchase trucks, vehicles, communication equipment, patrol boats, machine guns, ammunition, outboard motors, mobile phones, parachutes, communication accessories, computers, GPS equipment, cartridges and camouflaged uniforms.
Staff Comments: The Spanish project title is camiones, vehículos, equipo de comunicación, lanchas patrulleras, ametralladoras, municiones, motores fuera de borda, equipos móviles, paracaídas, accesorios para comunicación, computadoras, equipos GPS, cartuchos y uniformes camuflados.
Source Titles: China y Bolivia firman convenio de cooperación militar de $us 7,6 millones|China entrega más equipo militar a Bolivia y apoyo suma $us 45 millones|Revista Informativa Año 7 N° 68 Julio-Agosto 2016
Source Publishers: Pagina Siete|Los Tiempos|Bolivia Ministry of Defense

Title: China to send engineering experts to Liberia (linked to #31326)
Description: In 2014, under the protocol signed between China and Liberia, the Chinese Government is to send a team of engineering experts to Liberia. The team will work with the engineering personnel of the Armed Forces of Liberia, and the team will arrive in March 2014. Along with experts, China also provided the Liberian side with engineering equipment worth US$4 million in linked project ID #31326.
Source Titles: Liberia: China Energizes New AFL -Donate Over Us$4m Engineering Equipment|???????????????????|Defense Receives Equipment Valued At US$4M
Source Publishers: |Chinese Embassy|

Title: Chinese Government provides 10,000 AK47 rifles, three patrol boats worth 30 million RMB through Free Military Assistance Agreement (linked to #59169)
Description: On September 3, 2014, Chinese Ambassador to Ecuador Wang Shi Xiong and Ecuadorian Minister of Defense Maria Fernanda Espinosa signed a 30 million RMB (about 4.8 million USD) Free Military Assistance Agreement. It was originally envisaged that the grant proceeds would be used (at least in part) to facilitate the acquisition of military uniforms. However, on July 27, 2015, a protocol agreement was signed by the two governments, agreeing that the agreement would fund, instead, a grant of 10,000 modern AK47 rifles, and three (type 957) patrol boats with heavy machine guns for patrolling rivers (see page 6 of 'Contraloria General del Estado' for timeline). These materials were delivered to Ecuador on August 15, 2016, alongside a separate grant of disaster relief equipment to Ecuador's Ministry of Defense (see project #59169).Problems with the rifles began to be detected on October 3, 2017, by the government of Lenin Moreno (see 'Pese a informes negativos, FF.AA. utilizarán fusiles...'). On April 7, 2021, Ecuador’s Defense Minister Oswaldo Jarrín announced that all of the donated AK47 rifles would be destroyed because of problems that were found in the triggers of the rifles. Several months later, on June 8, 2021, Ecuadorian Minister Fernando Donoso met with Chen Guoyou, China's ambassador to Ecuador, and announced that the rifles would only be used for military training purposes.

Title: Chinese Navy Fleet visits Kenya and provides technical assistance and training
Description: On January 5, 2014, the 15th Chinese navy escort departed from Mbaraki Berth in Mombasa, Kenya after a 4-day visit. The commander of the fleet Jiang Zhonghua met with the Kenyan navy commander Ngewa Mukala and visited the Kenyan navy base. Officers and sailors from China provided technical assistance for equipment maintenance and training to the Kenyan Navy.
Staff Comments: deactivated - military aid

Title: Chinese People's Liberation Army commits to 30 mil yuan in military aid to Guyana
Description: On August 21, 2014, a bilateral conference between the Guyana Defence Force (GDF) and the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China commenced with the signing of a military aid agreement totalling RMB30 million (approximately US $4.8 million). Chief of Staff, Brigadier Mark Phillips said that, since the 1970s, China and the PLA have been providing military assistance to the GDF.

Title: Chinese Government sponsors training of 400 Cambodian military officials.
Description: During a discussion between Cambodia Minister of Defence Tea Banh and Xu Qiliang, chairman of China’s Central Military Commission, in May 2014, China has offered to provide more than 400 training scholarships to Cambodian officers. Banh commented after the meeting that it is the first time China has offered to train large number of military personnel in China. The offer can be seen in the context of China increasing up its military aid in recent years. For instance in Janurary 2013, an agreement was signed between Moeung Samphan, secretary of state in Cambodia’s Ministry of Defense and Qi Jianguo, deputy chief of general staff of the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA). Under the agreement, China will provide the Royal Cambodia Armed Forces by offering training courses, military equipment and materials.
Source Titles: A Chinese model for patron–client relations? The Sino-Cambodian partnership|Chinese training for Cambodian soldiers|China to Train Cambodia Military|China to train Cambodian army
Source Publishers: Oxford Journals: International Relations of the Asia-Pacific|The Phnom Penh Post|Radio Free Asia|Bangkok Post
Source Type: Academic Journal Article|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report

Title: Chinese Government donates military trucks, military uniforms, iron helmets, and batons to Royal Cambodian Armed Forces
Description: On February 7, 2014, at the Trucking Battalion No. 99 on the outskirts of the capital Phnom Penh (near near Phnom Penh International Airport), the People’s Liberation Army of China officially delivered a batch of donated military equipment — including 26 military trucks, 30,000 sets of military uniforms, and iron helmets and batons — to the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF). The handover ceremony was attended by Chinese Ambassador and General Moeung Samphan, commander of Brigade 70. The donation was reportedly meant to help alleviate the difficulties faced by the Cambodian army.
Source Titles: China provides military trucks and uniforms to Cambodia|China Provides Military Trucks and Uniforms to RCAF|A Chinese model for patron–client relations? The Sino-Cambodian partnership|China Donates Trucks, 30,000 Uniforms to RCAF
Source Publishers: Xinhua News Agency |Agence Kampuchea Presse|Oxford Journals: International Relations of the Asia-Pacific|Cambodia Daily

Title: Chinese Government sends 700 combat troops to serve as military peacekeepers with the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (Linked to Project ID#41987)
Description: In September 2014, the Chinese Government announced plans to 700 combat troops to serve as peacekeepers with the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) (see 'South Sudan: China to Send Troops for U.N. Mission'). The 700 combat troops were organized in an infantry battalion with 121 officers and 579 soldiers. They were equipped with drones, armored carriers, anti-tank missiles, mortars, and other weaponry for self-defense. 180 were set to arrive in Sudan in January 2015, with the rest of the battalion coming in March 2015 (see 'China to send 700 combat troops to South Sudan'). The battalion was tasked in protecting civilians living in UNMISS's properties, carrying out patrols in and around Juba, guarding U.N. assets, and escorting humanitarian supplies (see 'S. Sudan / Chinese Battalion'). There were 1,031 Chinese peacekeepers in South Sudan in December 2015, including the battalion (see 'What China hopes to achieve with first peacekeeping mission'). As China later sent new infantry battalions to serve as peacekeepers in South Sudan, AidData has assumed this battalion's mission term was completed. China also committed to sending non-combat peacekeepers to South Sudan, as captured by linked project ID#41987.
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS)

Title: Chinese Government provides military grant worth N$7,680,000
Description: In the Government of Namibia’s financial year 2014/2015, it signed a military grant agreement worth N$7,680,000 with the Chinese Government.  No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: One source indicates that the Chinese Government provides a military grant worth N$7,680,000 to the Government of Namibia each year. However, AidData has not yet found any corroborating evidence that such grants were provided after financial year 2014/2015. This issue merits further investigation.
Source Titles: National Planning Commission 2014/2015 Annual Report
Source Publishers: Republic of Namibia

Title: Chinese government sends Mauritanian military personnel to study in China
Description: On August 28, 2014, a farewell ceremony was held in Mauritania for Mauritanian military personnel leaving to study in China. The training is supported by the Chinese government.The exact number of trainees and dates of the program are unknown.
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Mauritania|Chinese Embassy in Mauritania

Title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 30 million of equipment to Cameroonian Navy (Linked to Project ID#58080)
Description: On October 23, 2014, a memorandum of understanding regarding an RMB 30 million military grant was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Cameroon Wo Ruidi and Cameroon's Minister of Defense Edgar Alain Mebe Ngo’o. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire Chinese-built military equipment for the Cameroonian Navy. This equipment was be used to help the Cameroonian Navy fight terrorists and pirates in the Gulf of Guinea. This project is separate from but potentially related to the EUR 252,450,000 China Eximbank loan that the Government of Cameroon contracted in 2012 to facilitate the acquisition of two navy patrol vessels (as captured via Project ID#57891).
Source Titles: China steps up its military cooperation with Cameroon|China, Cameroon sign military assistance agreement|CMR Navy gets gift of Chinese military hardware worth 2.5 billion|Boko Haram security threats plague foreign projects in Cameroon
Source Publishers: China Daily|China Military|Cameroun Web|Africa Report

Title: China sends fourth peacekeeping police force to South Sudan
Description: In November 2014, China's fourth peacekeeping police force was sent to South Sudan. The group had 15 members and was organized by the Shanghai Public Safety Bureau. Over the course of their mission they performed joint patrols, refugee protection, and human rights protection across six regions of South Sudan, including Juba, Malakal, Mairut, Bor, and Bentiu. On June 30, 2015, the force was awarded a United Nations Peace Medal. When this team departed from Sudan is unknown. The amount of funding given for the peacekeeping force is also unknown. As of January 2020, China has sent 7 peacekeeping teams to South Sudan.
Source Publishers: China Ministry of Foreign Affairs|Chinese Embassy in South Sudan

Title: China Eximbank provides buyer’s credit loan for Military Camp Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#484)
Description: In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea signed a $2 billion oil-backed buyer’s credit facility agreement for various infrastructure projects (captured in Project ID#484). All subsidiary loans approved under this facility agreement carry the following terms: a 5.5% interest rate, 5 year maturity, and 2 year grace period.In 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Equatorial Guinea subsequently signed a subsidiary buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Military Camp Construction Project (see '??????????????????'). The face value and the borrowing terms of this loan are unknown. This project involved the construction of a military camp at two sites, which house more than 1,300 military officers. The camp includes a dedicated community center with laundry, entertainment, and duty accommodations. The total construction area is 7,037.8 square meters.Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group (JPC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed, but its precise implementation start and end dates are unknown (see 'Military Camp Project of Equatorial Guinea').
Implementing Agencies: Government of Equatorial Guinea|Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group Co., Ltd.(JPC)
Collateral: The buyer's credit loans under the $2 billion USD facility were secured via deposit accounts opened by Government of Equatorial Guinea in China Eximbank. The Government of Equatorial Guinea deposited the proceeds from hydrocarbon exports into these accounts.A repayment guarantee equivalent to 30 percent (minimum) of the outstanding stock of debt was required to be in the accounts at all times.

Title: PLA donates two refurbished PLA naval patrol ships to Namibian Navy (Linked to Project ID#67738)
Description: In 2014, the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) signed an agreement to donate two former PLA naval vessels to Namibia. They are Haiqing (Type 037/1S)-class patrol crafts armed with two single-barrel 37 mm guns in open mounts and anti-submarine mortars. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. The Namibian Navy and Poly Technologies — a Chinese state-owned company — carried out a three-phase process for preparing the ships. First, refurbishment took place between August 2016 and May 26, 2017. Second, Poly Technologies trained 57 Namibians on how to operate the submarine chasers (as captured via Project ID#67738). Third, the ships were transported to Namibian waters in August 2017, with final Harbor Acceptance Tests (HAT) and Sea Acceptance Tests (SAT) concluded on September 26, 2017.  Then, on October 27, 2017, the vessels were officially commissioned by President Hage Geingob and renamed the NS Daures and NS Brukkaros. The ships are operationally utilized for general exclusive economic zone management.
Staff Comments: More research is needed to identify — or estimate — the monetary value of this donation

Description: On December 26, 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to donate RMB 5 million of military grant assistance to the Government Armenia each year. Then, in 2014, the Chinese Government donated RMB 5 million to the Government of Armenia in concurrence with the 2013 agreement. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: For other years' transactions and details, see umbrella project ID#66427.

Title: Bank of China provides $12.6 million loan for unspecified purposes
Description: In the first quarter of 2014, the Government of Indonesia signed a $12,605,457.50 loan agreement with the Cayman Islands Branch of Bank of China for an unspecified purpose. The final maturity date of the loan was 2020. The loan carried a commitment fee of 0.9% and an annual interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus an unknown margin. However, in a December 2017 SEC filing, the Government of Indonesia identified the effective interest rate of the loan as 4.701%. In the same filing, it identified the outstanding balance of the loan as $3,151,364.36.
Staff Comments: This Bank of China loan supported a military- or police-related project. However, more research is necessary to identify the exact purpose of the project.

Title: China Eximbank provides $15.96 million loan for Alutsista and Almatsus
Description: In the second semester of 2014, the Government of Indonesia signed a $15,966,400 loan agreement with China Eximbank to support Alutsista and Almatsus. The final maturity date of the loan was 2020. The loan carried a commitment fee of 0.75% and an annual interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus an unknown margin. However, in a December 2017 SEC filing, the Government of Indonesia identified the effective interest rate of the loan as 5.14%. In the same filing, it identified the outstanding balance of the loan as $13,970,600. Alutsista is the abbreviation of the main tool of the Indonesian National Armed Forces (TNI) weapons system used for state defense, established by the Minister of Defense based on input from the TNI Commander. Almatsus is an abbreviation of special material tools of the national police used for organizing public security and order as determined by the Chief of the Indonesian national police. The Indonesian Ministry of Defense contracted foreign loans that collectively amounted to $299,898,040.98 to finance Alutsista and Almatsus. Agricole Paris Branch contributed EUR 63,170,931.79, Agricole London Branch contributed $119 million, and Korea Exim Bank contributed $90,269,916.7.

Title: China and Belarus sign Military Assistance Agreement
Description: On November 8, 2014, China and Belarus signed an agreement where the former would provide military assistance (see 'Chinese Delegation Visiting...'). The document was signed by Defense Minister Yuri Zhadobin with a Chinese military delegation led by Deputy Chief of the General Staff of the Chinese People's Liberation Army Wang Guanzhong (see 'China to offer...'). Both sides will focus on the cooperation of military training and on the discussion of professionalism.The transaction amount in detail was not mentioned.

Title: 13th batch of Chinese peacekeeping force is sent to Lebanon (Linked to #41114)
Description: On August 27, 2014, the 13th batch of Chinese peacekeepers, composed of 180 officers, was deployed to Lebanon as part of the UN Interim Forces In Lebanon (UNIFIL). The group was deployed for eight months and included three combat engineering platoons, one construction engineering platoon, one combat service support platoon, and one EOD group.  It contributed to de-mining, construction, advisory, humanitarian and medical aid, and other projects. China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. See project ID #41114 for the full project. For individual project descriptions, see these projects: 1st batch: #67581; 2nd batch: #67578; 3rd batch: #67580; 4th batch #71863; 5th batch #71869; 6th batch: #41110; 7th batch: #67582; 8th batch: #67584; 9th batch: #67587; 10th batch: #67588; 11th batch: #67579; 12 batch: #71901; 13th batch: #67589; 14th batch: #72070; 15th batch: #72071; 16th batch: #66366; 17th batch: #67576; 18th batch: #67574; 19th batch: #72082.
Implementing Agencies: China Ministry of Defense|United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon

Title: Poly Technologies trains Namibian naval crew (Linked to #62720)
Description: In 2014, the Chinese People's Liberation Army signed an agreement to donate two former PLA naval vessels to Namibia (captured in project #62720). They are Haiqing (Type 037/1S)-class patrol crafts armed with two single-barrel 37 mm guns in open mounts and anti-submarine mortars. Phase two of the preparation process involved Poly Technologies hosting 57 Namibian trainees in China for a two-month-long workshop beginning on March 12, 2017. Three Namibians spent a month learning how to dive and four Namibians spent 10 days in tracking device training. All soon-to-be crew members graduated from the course on May 19, 2017 (see: 'President commissions navy patrol vessels').
Implementing Agencies: People's Liberation Army of China|Poly Technologies
Source Titles: President commissions navy patrol vessels|SPEECH BY HIS EXCELLENCY DR. HAGE G. GEINGOB, PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF NAMIBIA, AT THE COMMISSIONING CEREMONY FOR NAVAL VESSELS (NS) BRUKKAROS AND (NS) DAURES

Title: SAIC Subsidiary donates 3 vehicles to the Egyptian Ministry of Defense and Military Production (Linked to Project ID#72453)
Description: On June 7, 2014, Egyptian Ministry of Defense and Military Production Resolution No. 98 (2014), accepted a grant of ten MG Model 350 LL Cars (as captured via Project ID#72453), worth EGP 725,000, from Egyptian British Automotive, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Chinese State Owned Enterprise (SOE) SAIC Motor Corporation Limited. The Egyptian Ministry of Defense and Military Production's Vehicle Department was responsible for accepting the grant. On the same day, Egyptian British Automotive donated three MG Model 750 Cars, worth EGP 453,700, to the Egyptian Ministry of Defense and Military Production (as captured via Project ID#72452).

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 80 million grant in 2014 for '9.26’ (UAV Acquisition) Project (Linked to Project ID#72476, #72477)
Description: On October 16, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 80 million of grant funding for a military project that the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to as '9.26' in its Year Book for Fiscal Year 2015/16. 9.26 is a codename for a defense project that involves the acquisition of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). According to the same source, this project was completed and the equipment was successfully delivered. However, the precise delivery date is unknown. Project ID#72477 and ID#72476 capture additional Chinese Government  grants for the same project. In late 2015, Neil Gibson, a weapons analyst with IHS Jane’s, reported that imagery of Pakistan’s first (Burraq) armed drone suggested it was either a Chinese UAV (the CH-3 UAV) or an indigenous drone based on Chinese technology. ISPR Director General Major General Asim Salim Bajwa announced the first-ever use of the Burraq drone to strike a terrorist compound in Shawal Valley (killing three high-profile terrorists) in September 2015.  The attack was a significant milestone for Pakistan in that it joined the small club of countries with armed drones. The Pakistani Government had previously sought to buy armed drones from the US, but Washington refused to authorize the purchase because of concerns about exporting a sensitive technology.
Source Titles: YEAR BOOK 2014-15|Pakistan developing combat drones|China supported, designed or supplied Pakistan's first indigenous drone, claim analysts|China assisted Pakistan on armed drone, say experts|NESCOM Burraq
Source Publishers: GOVERNMENT OF PAKISTAN ECONOMIC AFFAIRS DIVISION|The Guardian|Tribune|Financial Times|Wikipedia
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 25 million grant for Intelligence Technology Equipment Project (Linked to project ID#72690)
Description: On December 7, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 25 million of grant funding for a military project that the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to as ‘Intelligence Technology Equipment’ in its Year Book for Fiscal Year 2015/16. According to the same source, this project was completed and the equipment was successfully delivered. However, the precise delivery date is unknown. An additional Chinese Government grant was provided for this project in 2015 (as captured via Project ID#72690).
Staff Comments: The RMB 25 million grant assigned above is the part of a CNY 700 million grant, which was approved on Nov 18, 2014 and was arranged to be utilized for mutually agreed projects in the future. There is another RMB 45.6 million grant (captured by project ID#72690) that also belongs to the approved 700 million grant and serves for the Defence related Project.
Source Titles: Pakistan Economic Affairs Division 2014-15 Year Book
Source Publishers: Government of Pakistan

Description: On June 10, 2014, the Government of Mozambique ratified a $45,000,000 loan agreement with China Eximbank for the Equipment for the Defense and Security Forces Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The purpose of this loan was to facilitate the acquisition of equipment for Mozambique’s Defense and Security Forces. It is unclear whether this project reached the implementation stage.

Title: China sends second batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali (Linked to Project ID# 87024)
Description: In 2014, Mali sent a second batch of peacekeeping forces to Mali for a one-year term of service to MINUSMA.They left after a rotation ceremony held on May 22, 2015, and were replaced by a third batch of peacekeeping forces. The second batch withstood the Ebola outbreak in Mali.
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA)

Description: In March 2016, Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira disclosed that the Government of Bolivia received assistance from the Chinese Government worth $7,675,000 in 2014 to support the Bolivian Armed Forces. However, it is unclear when and how these funds were used.

Title: Chinese Government provides $50 million military aid package for multiple purposes (Linked to Project ID#72616, ID#72619)
Description: On May 14, 2013, the Ministry of Defense of Cabo Verde and the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China signed a protocol, which committed $50 million of grant funding for the acquisition of two naval patrol ships (captured via Project ID#72619), the provision of IT equipment and office supplies (captured via Project ID#87153), the construction of an Armed Forces uniform production factory (captured via Project ID#87155), and the construction of four gyms at military bases across the archipelago (captured via Project ID#87154). On April 17, 2015, a delivery ceremony took place at Quartel Eugénio Lima for the IT equipment and office supplies, the uniform production factory, and the four gyms. Then, on August 14, 2015, the Coast Guard of Cabo Verde received two naval patrol boats from the Chinese Government for search and rescue purposes and for monitoring the country’s territorial waters. The boats were named N/P Badejo and N/P Djeu. Then, on August 17, 2015, the Chinese Ambassador to Cabo Verde attended a ‘service ceremony’ for the two patrol boats.
Staff Comments: The monetary values of individual donations and subsidiary projects that were supported by the larger $50 million aid package are unknown. Therefore, the full monetary value of the $50 million military aid package is captured via Project ID#30215.
Receiving Agencies: Cabo Verde Armed Forces (FAC)|Government of Cabo Verde

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million military grant for provision of equipment, materials, and vehicles in 2013
Description: In April 2012 or May 2012, China’s Ambassador to Mali, Cao Zhongming, and the Malian Defense Minister signed an RMB 20 million (1.4 billion FCFA or 2.5 million euros) military grant agreement (as captured via Project ID#59115). The grant proceeds were to be used by the Malian Armed Forces to acquire vehicles (4X4 pickups and troop carriers) and other equipment and materials (including radios, spare parts for vehicles, bulletproof vests, and tents). According to an official Government of Mali document, this aid package was received sometime before July 17, 2012. Then, on March 7, 2013, China’s Ambassador to Mali, Cao Zhongming, and the Malian Defense Minister signed another RMB 20 million (1.4 billion FCFA or 2.5 million euros) military grant agreement (as captured via Project ID#30406). The grant proceeds were to be used by the Malian Armed Forces to acquire 65 vehicles (including 4 troop carriers) and other equipment and materials. The delivery of these vehicles, equipment, and materials commenced on June 19, 2013.
Staff Comments: One source indicates that the Chinese Government provided RMB 60 million of military aid to the Malian Government between 2012 and November 2017. However, AidData has not yet identified the timing and nature of the third RMB 20 million grant commitment. This issue merits further investigation.
Source Titles: Malian army gets donation of Chinese equipment|Coopération Sino-malienne : 20 millions de yuans pour renforcer notre armée|Paix et sécurité en Afrique de l’Ouest : la Chine s’implique au Mali
Source Publishers: Agence de Presse Africaine|Bamako.com|UniversitéParis 1-Panthéon Sorbonne
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

Title: China Eximbank loans $285 million USD for Phase 1 of the Tanzania Defense Forces Housing Project
Description: In 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed a $285 million USD concessional loan agreement for Phase 1 of the Tanzania Defence Forces Housing Project (or TPDF Housing Project or ???????? or Tanzania Energy Saving and Eco Housing Project or ????????????????) for the Tanzanian People's Defence Forces (TPDF). The purpose of this loan was to cover 95% of the total project cost, which is equal to $300 million USD. The loan terms are unknown. The purpose of this project was to construct military housing units in Arusha, Dar es Salaam, Dodoma, Kagera, Kigoma, Morogoro, Pemba, Pwani and Tanga. Shanghai Construction Group was contracted by the Tanzanian Ministry of Defence and National Service to construct all 12,000 military housing units. The first phase involved the construction of 6,064 houses. Construction began on June 3, 2013 but the official groundbreaking ceremony did not take place until December 20, 2014.The project encountered problems and delays related to land disputes between the Tanzania People's Defense Forces (TPDF) and the general public. Tanzania's Defense Minister, Shamsi Vuai Nahodha, later announced that official surveys would be conducted and permanent military residential housing be constructed to clearly demarcate the land and settle disputes. It was originally envisioned that the project would take 50 months to finish and the project would reach completion in calendar year 2016. However, as of November 2016, only 70% of the project construction work was complete. The project eventually reached completion but the exact date of completion is unknown.
Implementing Agencies: Shanghai Construction Group General Co.|Tanzania Ministry of Defence and Natinoal Service (MODANS)|Tanzania People's Defence Forces (TPDF)

Title: Deployment of 140 riot police
Description: On July 31, 2013, Chinese Defense Attaché to Liberia, Colonel Zhao Xizhang disclosed that the Chinese government has pledged to send 140 seasoned riot policewomen to Monrovia, Liberia for a United Nations peace-keeping mission. Col. Zhao also disclosed that 30 Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) officers would be sent to China next academic year to undergo studies which AFL soldiers need to build their capacity (ID #31324). On September 29, the Ministry of Public Security officially announced the deployment and mentioned the first batch of 14 members would leave from Beijing on September 30. On October 23, all 140 of the riot police arrived in Liberia, 7 of which were women.
Source Titles: China sends all-female riot police to Liberia |Chinese peacekeeping troops arrive in Liberia|China sends peacekeepers to Liberia|China to send 140 riot policewomen to Liberia
Source Publishers: |Xinhua News Agency||
Geographic Location: Monrovia

Title: Chinese Government provides TND 8 million grant to help the Tunisian military deal with terrorism and other illegal activities
Description: On November 29, 2013, the Chinese Government provided a TND 8 million donation to help the Tunisian Government purchase military equipment for its National Army. The donation was meant to boost Tunisia’s ability to deal with terrorism and other illegal activities. The grant agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Tunisia Bian Yanhua and the Tunisian Defense Minister Rachid Sabbagh.

Title: NORINCO provides $19.5 million supplier credit to revitalize ammunition factory in Serenje district
Description: In April 2013, during Zambian President Michael Sata’s seven-day state visit to China, Zambia’s Deputy Minister of Defense, Davis Mwila, announced that China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) had agreed to provide a $19.5 million supplier credit (loan) to the Government of Zambia before the end of the year to recapitalize and revitalize Mupepetwe Engineering and Contracting Company (MECCO), an ammunition manufacturing facility located in Serenje District. Then, on September 23, 2013, Zambia’s Ministry of Defense signed a $19,524,912.60 contract with NORINCO to supply equipment for restoration and upgrading of the MECCO production line. According to the agreement, a batch of equipment was to be delivered within a period of two months while restoration and upgrading works were expected to be completed within two years. In December 2013, NORINCO was paid a sum of $4,881,228.15 representing 25% of the contract sum leaving a balance of $14,643,684.45. Then, in December 2016, NORINCO delivered the first batch of equipment equivalent to the amount paid. As of August 31, 2020, the upgrading and restoration of the company production line had stalled due to non-payment of the outstanding balance.
Staff Comments: This loan is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020 and updated in March 2021 (which is now maintained by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center).
Funding Agencies: China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group)
Implementing Agencies: China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group)

Title: Chinese Government provides $7.6 million grant for Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: In May 11, 2013, the Chinese government granted 8 million dollars to Bolivia, to be used over the next five years, for the purchase of non-military equipment for the Bolivian Armed Forces. The People's Liberation Army and the Bolivian Minister of Defense signed the agreement. This will be used in logistic and operational areas to improve the capacities of the Armed Forces, specifically through communication and transportation equipment.In March 2016, Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira disclosed that the Government of Bolivia received assistance from the Chinese Government worth $7,675,000 in 2013 to support the Bolivian Armed Forces. However, it is unclear when and how these funds were used.

Title: Chinese Government donates of buses, bus accessories, and military equipment to the Bolivian Armed Forces in 2013
Description: In 2013, the Chinese and Bolivian governments agreed to a shipment of material for military use and JINLONG Brand Buses and their accessories to the State Armed Forces of Bolivia. The donation was made within the framework of a protocol of free military assistance by the Chinese Ministry of National Defense to the Bolivian Ministry of Defense. Import taxes for these shipments were waived via Supreme Decree on October 2, 2013.
Staff Comments: This project may potentially be linked to #36118 China Aids Bolivian Armed Forces with $8 Million USD because #36118 outlines plans for future transactions, including equipment, between the two countries. The buses and accessories may be part of this larger framework.
Source Publishers: Government of Bolivia|Chinabuses.com

Title: Chinese Government provided CFA 8 billion grant for Marien-Ngouabi Military Academy Extension and Rehabilitation Project
Description: In March 2013, during the visit to Republic of Congo, Chinese President Xi Jinping signed a 8 billion FCFA grant for the reconstruction and expansion project of China’s aid to the Marien-Ngouabi Military Academy Extension and Rehabilitation Project (l'académie militaire Marien-Ngouabi). This project involved the expansion and rehabilitation of the Marien-Ngouabi Military Academy (in the northern suburbs of Brazzaville), which was first constructed with financial support from the Chinese Government during the late 1980s. More specifically, it involved the installation of a gate at the entrance, the installation of a fence, painting and waterproofing of the building, and some new construction activities (including dormitories and classrooms). Beijing Uni.-Construction Group Co., Ltd. (BUCC) was he contractor responsible for project implementation. The construction started on July 28, 2015, and was completed on May 31, 2016. On June 20, 2016, the handover ceremony for the reconstruction and expansion project of the Nguwabi military school was held in Brazzaville. The academy was officially completed and handed over to the Congolese authorities on June 20, 2016.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ?????????????. The French project title is les travaux de réaménagement et d'agrandissement de l'Académie militaire Marien-Ngouabi or Agrandissement et Rehabilitation de L'Academie Militaire Marien Ngouabi.

Title: China grants 80 million RMB to Bolivia for citizen security (linked to #36183)
Description: On December 19, 2013, President Xi Jinping and President Evo Morales met and signed 3 economic and technical cooperation agreements worth 204 million yuan (~35 million USD) in Beijing (captured in project #36183). One of the agreements granted Bolivia 80 million RMB of non-reimbursable economic aid for citizen security and support to the Bolivian Armed Forces, according to the Bolivian Defense Minister. It is intended to serve all territorial regions. The other linked projects are captured in the umbrella project (#36183).
Source Titles: Bolivia and China sign financing agreements for 35 million dollars|Bolivia and China agree to economic aid for 35 million dollars|Gasto militar: China concede crédito de $us 12 millones a Bolivia|CHINA FORTALECE FFAA DE BOLIVIA CON $US 12 MILLONES
Source Publishers: Bolivian Ministry of Foreign Affairs|La Razon|EconomíaBolivia|Bolivian Ministry of Defense

Title: Martial Arts Class for the Jordanian Public Security Directorate 2013
Description: On July 4th, 2013,  members of the Jordanian Public Security Directorate (PSD) completed a martial arts training course taught by six martial arts coaches from the Shanghai Corps of Armed Police.  The course was organized by the PSD's Jordanian Police Sports Federation.
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan
Contact Position: Chinese Military Attache |Chinese Ambassador to Jordan

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense donates military property worth RMB 3 million to Azerbaijan’s Ministry of Defense
Description: On January 21, 2013, the Chinese Ministry of Defense and the Government of Azerbaijan signed an RMB 3 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to supply ‘military property’ to Azerbaijan’s Ministry of Defense. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China to provide free aid to Azerbaijan
Source Publishers: APA Blog

Title: [UMBRELLA] China provides annual grant to Armenia for military aid
Description: On December 26, 2013, Armenian Defense Minister Seyran Ohanyan and Chinese Minister of National Defense General Chang Wanquan signed an agreement stating that China will grant Armenia 5 million yuan a year in military aid, particularly military cooperation in training and technical assistance. In 2013-2016 China donated 5 million yuan to in concurrence with this agreement totaling 20 million yuan. On April 9, 2017 Armenian Defense Minister, Vigen Sargsyan and Chinese Minister of Defense and State Councilor, Chang Wanquan, met to review the prior agreement and the current state of the Armenian Armed Forces. At this meeting, the two signed a new agreement to increase the annual amount to 10 million yuan. The current total donated from China, based on the data found thus far, is 30 million yuan - given between 2013 and 2017. See the following projects for yearly specifics:For 2013, see project #41322For 2014, see project #66567For 2015, see project #66570For 2016, see project #66426For 2017, see project #66569
Staff Comments: Coder has not been able to find any details about the duration of this agreement or of the date each year that the money is handed over.

Title: Chinese Government donates 7 Dongfeng Mengshi special light armored vehicles (Linked to Project ID#66834)
Description: On May 17, 2013, the Chinese Ministry of Defense and Belarus’ Ministry of Defense signed a military grant agreement. During the same month, the Chinese Government delivered seven Dongfeng Mengshi special light armored vehicles, spare vehicle parts, and medical equipment. The equipment donation that arrived in May 2013 was supported — at least in part — by a military grant agreement that the parties signed in 2012.
Source Titles: Military Cooperation|??????????????????????????|China, Belarus to strengthen military cooperation
Source Publishers: Belarussian Military|Sina|Xinhua

Title: RMB 5 million Chinese Government grant in 2013 for the provision of military communications and medical equipment to the Ministry of Defense of Montenegro
Description: On June 20, 2013, a handover ceremony of the Chinese Ministry of National Defense ’s free donation of RMB 5 million to the Montenegrin Ministry of Defense was held in the capital of Podgorica, Montenegro. The Chinese ambassador of Montenegro, Zhi Zhaolin, and the assistant minister of the Ministry of Defense of Montenegro, Radusnovich, were present at the ceremony. The goods donated are mainly military communications and medical equipment. It is unclear when the original protocol was signed.
Staff Comments: This may simply be the handover ceremony for the donation identified in Project ID#67199. However, since it appears that China and Montenegro signed these protocols every year, it's likely that this flow is separate from the one in 67199. Thus, we'll keep this project active for now.
Source Publishers: Embassy of People's Republic of China in Montenegro

Title: Chinese Embassy donates infrastructure equipment to Benin Army Corps (Linked to Project ID#69347)
Description: On December 2, 2013, Chinese Ambassador Tao Weiguang signed a military assistance agreement with Benin’s Defense Minister Ye Lima. This agreement aimed to provide equipment to the Benin Army's Infrastructure Engineering Company to promote the Benin military’s mission of safeguarding national sovereignty and security. On January 16th, 2015, the Chinese Ambassador, Diao Mingsheng, held the handover ceremony of the infrastructure equipment for the Engineering Department of the Benin Army Corps (see ????????????????????????). This donation included equipment like forklifts, trucks, and other construction equipment and is meant to greatly enhance the operational capabilities of the Benin Engineering Corps. The donation was made concurrently with a separate commitment to dispatch Chinese experts to provide training on the use of the equipment (as captured via Project ID#69347).

Title: China pledges 20 million RMB in materials to the Peruvian Ministry of Defense (linked to #69437)
Description: On September 3, 2013, Rear Admiral Mario Cesar Sanchez Debernardi was authorized to sign the Agreement on Free Military Assistance between the Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Peru and the Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China (el Acuerdo Sobre la Asistencia Militar Gratuita entre el Ministerio de Defensa de la Republica del Peru y el Ministerio de Defensa Nacional de la Republica Popular China) NO: 2013 A-017-JY430, which pledged to grant 20 million RMB in military assistance materials from China to the Peruvian Ministry of Defense. The exact nature of the materials was to be determined by a military protocol at a later date. On November 23, 2017, a protocol agreement was signed, outlining the vehicles and other materials to be granted using funds from this Free Military Assistance agreement, along with two other Free Military Assistance agreements (see project #69437).
Staff Comments: Project is not to be confused with the 20 million RMB pledged in materials for the military by Agreement NO: 2012 A-075-JY430 (Project #69606)
Receiving Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Implementing Agencies: Chinese Ministry of National Defense |Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Source Titles: Resolucion Ministerial 758-2013-DE/SG|Ministerios de Defensa de Perú y China refuerzan cooperación militar y en atención de desastres
Source Publishers: Peru Ministry of Defense|Government of Peru

Title: Chinese Navy sends 9th technical team to assist Benin Military
Description: In April, 2013, the Chinese Embassy in Benin held a welcome reception of the 9th Chinese Navy Technical Team. On May 7th, 2014, a reception for the departure of the 9th Chinese Navy Technical Team was held (see ????????????????????`). The technical team assisted the Benin Military and played a part in strengthening bilateral military cooperation.
Staff Comments: The exact start date of the Navy Technical Team is unknown, however, the article relating to the welcome ceremony was published on April 3, 2013, so the year has been confirmed as 2013.

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for the provision of two naval patrol boats (Linked to Project ID#30215)
Description: On May 14, 2013, the Ministry of Defense of Cabo Verde and the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China signed a protocol, which committed $50 million of grant funding for the acquisition of two naval patrol ships (captured via Project ID#72619), the provision of IT equipment and office supplies (captured via Project ID#87153), the construction of an Armed Forces uniform production factory (captured via Project ID#87155), and the construction of four gyms at military bases across the archipelago (captured via Project ID#87154). On April 17, 2015, a delivery ceremony took place at Quartel Eugénio Lima for the IT equipment and office supplies, the uniform production factory, and the four gyms. Then, on August 14, 2015, the Coast Guard of Cabo Verde received two naval patrol boats from the Chinese Government for search and rescue purposes and for monitoring the country’s territorial waters. The boats were named N/P Badejo and N/P Djeu. Then, on August 17, 2015, the Chinese Ambassador to Cabo Verde attended a ‘service ceremony’ for the two patrol boats.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ???? or ???????. The Portuguese project title is Dois Navios Patrulha e de Busca e Salvamento.
Source Titles: China donates US$50 million to Cape Verde to purchase military equipment|??????????????????????|Guarda Costeira recebe dois Navios Patrulha da R. P. da China|China oferece a Cabo Verde dois navios para reforçar segurança marítima
Source Publishers: MacauHub|Embassy of China in Cape Verde|Ministry of Defense of Cape Verde|PanaPress
Source Type: Media Report|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report

Title: Training in China provided for Barbados Defense Force officers
Description: In 2013, a group of military officers from the Barbados Defense Force (BDF) attended military-related training in China. On August 19, 2013, a reception was held at the Chinese Embassy in Barbados for officers to ask questions about what studying in China would be like and to recognize students who had received the Chinese Government Scholarship. In total, the event hosted 30 officers and students combined. Given that about 10 students receive the Chinese Government Scholarship every year (see project ID #39906), it is likely that about 20 officers from the BDF attended this training. It is unclear which Chinese government institution was funding the training.
Source Titles: ?????????????????????????|Chinese Embassy in Barbados Held Panel Discussion on Studying in China with Chinese Government's Scholarship|??????????????????????
Source Publishers: Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Barbados|Chinese Embassy in Barbados|Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Chinese Government donates 9 pieces of heavy machinery to Armed Forces of BiH
Description: On December 26, 2013, the Ministry of Defense of the People’s Republic of China, the Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a grant agreement. The proceeds from the grant agreement were used to facilitate the acquisition of 9 pieces of heavy machinery. The Ministry of Defense and the Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina planned to use the equipment to respond to natural disasters and repair local infrastructure. The equipment was officially handed over to the local authorities on July 24, 2015.
Receiving Agencies: Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina

Title: Chinese Government sends security peacekeepers to join the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (Linked to Project ID#31113)
Description: On December 3, 2013, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) sent 135 peacekeepers to Mali to join the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA). The peacekeeping force, drawn from troops based in Harbin, China, consisted of 35 engineers, 65 medical workers, and 35 soldiers. For the engineers and medical workers involved in this peacekeeping detachment, see linked project ID#31113; the soldiers are captured by this project. The Chinese peacekeepers arrived in Bamako, Mali on December 4, 2013 for an eight-month long mission (see '135 peacekeepers depart for Mali'). More peacekeepers arrived later; ultimately, 365 Chinese peacekeepers served between December 2013 and the mission's completion in August 2014 (see '1st Chinese peacekeeping force to Mali commended'). The peacekeepers were set to work on repairing roads and bridges and providing medical assistance, while the security forces were to guard MINUSMA's headquarters and barracks. This was reportedly the first time the PLA sent security forces on a peacekeeping mission (see '135 peacekeepers depart for Mali').
Receiving Agencies: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA)
Source Titles: 135 peacekeepers depart for Mali|135 Chinese peacekeepers arrive in capital of Mali|China Takes a Peacekeeping Risk in Mali|1st Chinese peacekeeping force to Mali commended|China to Deploy “Security Force” to UN Peacekeeping Operation  in Mali
Source Publishers: China Daily USA|Xinhua|Pass Blue|Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China|U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)

Title: Chinese Government donates IT equipment and office supplies to Cape Verde’s Ministry of Defense (Linked to Project ID#30215)
Description: On May 14, 2013, the Ministry of Defense of Cabo Verde and the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China signed a protocol, which committed $50 million of grant funding for the acquisition of two naval patrol ships (captured via Project ID#72619), the provision of IT equipment and office supplies (captured via this project, ID#87153), the construction of an Armed Forces uniform production factory (captured via Project ID#87155), and the construction of four gyms at military bases across the archipelago (captured via Project ID#87154). On April 17, 2015, a delivery ceremony took place at Quartel Eugénio Lima for the IT equipment and office supplies, the uniform production factory, and the four gyms. Then, on August 14, 2015, the  Coast Guard of Cabo Verde received two naval patrol boats from the Chinese Government for search and rescue purposes and for monitoring the country’s territorial waters. The boats were named N/P Badejo and N/P Djeu. Then, on August 17, 2015, the Chinese Ambassador to Cabo Verde attended a ‘service ceremony’ for the two patrol boats.
Staff Comments: The Portuguese project title is Equipamentos informáticos e materiais de escritório.The monetary values of individual donations and subsidiary projects that were supported by the larger $50 million aid package are unknown. Therefore, the full monetary value of the $50 million military aid package is captured via Project ID#30215.

Title: China donates 8 million CNY worth of military equipment to Burundi
Description: On October 3, 2012, Major General Pontian Gaciyubwenge, Burundi's Minister of National Defense and Veteran's Affairs, officially received a military donation from the Chinese Ambassador Xu Zhong Yu. The gift included 800 tents: 600 for 12 men capacity, 100 for 36 men, and 100 for hospital use with 95 men capacity. This was reported to be the second such gift from China to Burundi in that year (#30485), being used for the purposes of peacekeeping in Somalia. The total value was 8 million CNY.
Source Titles: http://www.burundi-gov.bi/Burundi-FDN-remise-officielle-des,2492|CHINA OFFERS LOGISTICS MATERIALS TO BURUNDI'S MILITARY|China offers Burundi logistical materials for military
Source Publishers: |Nam News Network|ECNS.cn
Contact Name: Xu Zhong Yu|Major General Pontian Gaciyubwenge

Title: Chinese Government provides $8 million grant for Ndola and Maina Soko Military Hospital Rehabilitation Project
Description: On May 28, 2012, Chairman Xu Caihou of China's Central Military Commission met with Zambian Defense Minister Geoffrey B. Mwamba signed an $8 million military aid agreement for the rehabilitation of the Ndola military hospital and the Maina Soko military hospital. AidData has not identify any evidence that this project was ever implemented.

Title: Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Company Donated Furniture and Equipment to National Defense College
Description: On November 7, 2012, Zimbabwe's National Defense College received furniture and equipment worth 1.4 million USD from Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Company. The 2,836 pieces of furniture included executive desks and chairs, boardroom tables, beds, computer desks, and dining room tables, among other items.The National Defense College was built by Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Company using loans sourced from China Exim Bank in 2011 (ID #22204).
Source Titles: Govt Gets U.S.$ 1,4 Million Furniture Donation|Mnangagwa backs Look East Policy
Source Publishers: All Africa Global Media|The Zimbabwe Mail
Source Type: Media Report|Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs
Geographic Location: Harare
Contact Position: Zimbabwe Minister of Defense |Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe|Chairman

Title: Chinese Government provides $4.5 million grant for military equipment and training
Description: In 2012, the Chinese Ambassador Zhao Jianhua and Liberia's Defense Chief Brownie Samukai signed a $4.5 million grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to fund the training of the Armed Forces of Liberia personnel in the Engineering Company, and to purchase equipment. The project was scheduled for completion by 2014. However, it is unclear whether or when it was ultimately implemented.

Title: Chinese Government donates logistical materials to Burundi's military worth $1.3 million
Description: On June 26, 2012, the Chinese Government donated $1.3 million worth of logistical materials to Burundi's military. The donation reportedly consisted of 600 squad tents (each with the capacity to hold 12 people), 600 platoon tents (each with the capacity of hold 36 people), and 100 hospital tents. One source also indicates that the Chinese Government donated 10,000 combat uniforms, 10,000 camouflage helmets, 10,000 pairs of boots, 20,000 pairs of socks, 10,000 berets, 200 swords, 64 parachutes, and 20,00 pairs of gloves.
Staff Comments: There are discrepancies among the sources on what was donated to the Burundian military. One source is in French.
Source Titles: Speech by His Excellency the Minister of National Defence and Veterans on the Occassion of the Official Ceremony of Chinese Donations|CHINA OFFERS LOGISTICS MATERIALS TO BURUNDI'S MILITARY
Source Publishers: Republic of Burundi, Department of National Defence and Veterans|Nam News Network

Title: Chinese Government donates buses and ICT equipment to National Defence College (linked to #62952)
Description: On 3 April, 2013, the Government of China donated seven buses and state of the art Information Communication Technology (ICT) equipment to the National Defense College in Zimbabwe (See: Defence College Gets 7 Buses, ICT Equipment).  This donation comes as a result of a MOU agreement for the provision of military aid signed between the two nations in 2012 (See: Defence College Gets 7 Buses, ICT Equipment).  The equipment was successfully installed, and Chinese experts also trained locals to operate and maintain it (See: Defence college gets 7 buses, ICT equipment). The value of this donation is unknown. This project is completed.The linked project #62952 captures the financing and construction of the Chinese-funded National Defence College in Zimbabwe.

Description: On May 28, 2012, Chinese Defense Minister Liang Guanglie and Cambodian Defense Minister Tea Banh signed an RMB 120 million (about $20 million) for the construction of military training schools and military hospitals (captured via Project ID#32193). Title: Chinese Government pledges to provide $100 million to build houses and upgrade infrastructure in Sri Lankan military camps
Description: In 2012, the Chinese Government pledged to provide $100 million for the construction of accommodation and infrastructure facilities in Sri Lankan army camps being built in the North-East.
Staff Comments: The Chinese aid comes in the face of international demand for reducing army presence in the Tamil predominant areas of Sri Lanka. China has been liberal in extending assistance to Sri Lanka to strengthen its armed forces during and after the Eelam war unlike India and the U.S. who are wary of extending such assistance.

Title: China donates $1.5 million USD to the Defense Service College in Sri Lanka
Description: On 30 August 2012 China donated $1.5 million USD to the Defense Service College in Sri Lanka, a national school established for children of defense services and police personnel. The donation included funds and materials for a fully fledged laboratory, furniture to the school, fridges, microwave ovens, etc.

Title: PLA provides RMB 100 million grant for Phase 1 of the Sri Lanka Military Academy (SLMA) Auditorium Complex Project (Linked to Project ID#71490)
Description: In 2012, China’s People's Liberation Army (PLA) provided an RMB 100 million grant to the Government of Sri Lanka for the Phase 1 of the Sri Lanka Military Academy (SLMA) Auditorium Complex Project. Yunnan Construction and Investment Holding Group Co. Ltd. and the Academy of Military Science of the Chinese People's Liberation Army were responsible for the design and implementation of the project. Phase 1 construction of the auditorium started in October 21, 2014 and ended on August 31, 2017. A formal project handover ceremony took place on December 15, 2018.  The state-of-the-art building was constructed in the shape of a lotus, which is the national flower of Sri Lanka and it will serve as an office, teaching and assembly space for the staff and cadets of the Sri Lanka Military Academy. The auditorium has a seating capacity of 785 seats with sound and optoelectronic facilities, central air conditioning and intelligent power supply and distribution control system.  The PLA also provided RMB 18 million for Phase 2 of the SLMA Auditorium Complex Project (as captured via Project ID#71490).

Title: Chinese Ministry of National Defense donates communications equipment worth RMB 20 million to the Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: On May 11, 2012, China's Ministry of National Defense and the Bolivian Ministry of Defense signed an agreement in which the Chinese Government committed to donating equipment worth RMB 20 million ($3 million USD) to the Bolivian Armed Forces (see 'Boletín Informativo Año 3 No. 18 Mayo 2012'). The donated military equipment was to include high-tech communications equipment from China (see 'China dona equipos militares de comunicación a Bolivia'). The equipment was intended to strengthen the operational and logistical capacity of the Bolivian Armed Forces (see 'Boletín Informativo Año 3 No. 18 Mayo 2012'). The current status of the project is unknown.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 18 million grant for military hanging bridges (Linked to Project ID#36853)
Description: In June 2012, representatives of Colombia's Armed Forces and the People's Liberation Army of China signed two military grant agreements (collectively worth RMB 48 million or $7 million): an RMB 18 million grant for military hanging bridges (captured via Project ID#36852) and an RMB 30 million grant for 'defined military elements' (captured via Project ID#36853). The bridges were eventually delivered at the Tolemaida military fort on October 12, 2013; however, their exact locations are unknown. The implementation status of the RMB 30 million grant is unknown.
Staff Comments: This project is linked to project #36853, which is the other half of this donation. This record is also a follow up to the project in #36346 from 2010.

Title: [China Venezuela Joint Fund] $500 million for VN1 Armored Amphibious Vehicle Acquisition Project (Linked to Project ID#58677)
Description: In July 2012, Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez approved a $500 million drawdown from the China Venezuela Joint Fund (captured in Project ID#58677) for the acquisition of Chinese military equipment (including VN1 armored amphibious vehicles and self-propelled rockets). Then, in September 2013, Venezuela’s Ministry of Defense and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) signed a $500 million commercial contract for this purpose. Images released on November 16, 2014 show a delegation from the Venezuelan Navy led by Admiral Jairo Avendaño Quintero “receiving” the VN1 armored amphibious vehicles, while others show the delegation inspecting VN18 and VN16 amphibious vehicles at the NORINCO manufacturing facility in Dalian, China. By the end of December 2014, it was announced that the Norinco VN1 vehicles had been delivered to Venezuela.
Staff Comments: 1. The Spanish project title is Adquisición de armamentos para la actualización, reequipamiento y reorganización de la Infantería de Marina Bolivariana. 2. It is unclear which specific credit line funded this purchase; it was likely either Project ID#37838 or #37821.
Implementing Agencies: China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group)
Collateral: Income from PDVSA oil sales to CNPC.

Title: Chinese Government provides $15 million grant for Military Officer Apartment Building Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#54010 and #53977)
Description: In 2012, Chinese Government provided a $15 million grant to the Government of Tajikistan for the Military Officer Apartment Building Construction Project. The grant proceeds were drawn from a larger $19 million military aid agreement between the two parties.  The purpose of the project was to construct a five-story apartment complex in the capital city of Dushanbe for Tajik military officers. The building has 68 apartments, 20 hotel rooms, an electronic library, small reading rooms, an assembly hall with 200 seats, a press conference hall, a large gymnasium, a swimming pool, a sauna, massage rooms, a large modern dining room, offices, various service centers, a beauty salon, a shop, as well as a fully-equipped medical center. Construction began in 2012 and the project was officially completed on May 5, 2016. The completion ceremony was attended by the Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan Yue Bin, the Chinese Joint Staff Deputy Chief of Central Military Commission Xu Fenlin and Tajikistan President Emomali Rahmon.
Staff Comments: 1. The Chinese project title is ?????????????. The Russian project title is ???? ???????? ???????????? ???????. 2. This grant is part of a larger agreement between China and Tajikistan, in which China launched a set of assistance projects to enhance the military capabilities of Tajikistan. For other projects related to the program (see Project ID#54010).

Title: China grants Cameroon National Gendarmerie 9 heavy-duty trucks in 2012
Description: On February 17th, 2012, China's ambassador to Cameroon, Xue Jinwei, signed a transfer certificate with Cameroon's State Secretary of the National Gendarmerie, Jean Baptiste Bockham, to give nine heavy-duty trucks from China to Cameroon for Cameroon's International Security Forces School (EIFORCES). Cameroon International Security Forces School is committed to cultivating peacekeeping forces. This project is implemented by Guangdong Hengshen Import & Export Co., Ltd. The project was initiated in December 2009 and completed in 2012.
Staff Comments: No other confirming source of this project could be found.
Implementing Agencies: Cameroon National Gendarmerie|Guangdong Heng Shen Import and Export Co., Ltd.

Title: China Eximbank provides EUR 252,450,000 buyer’s credit loan for Patrol Ship Acquisition Project
Description: In 2011, the acquisition of naval patrol ships was proposed after a visit to Cameroon by Hui Liangyu, who was the Chinese vice-premier at the time. Then, during a state by to China by Cameroonian President Paul Biya the same year, some of the specifics of the deal were negotiated. On May 24, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of Cameroon signed an EUR 252,450,000 ($330 million) buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Patrol Ship Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the loan were as follows: 11 year maturity, 2 year grace period, and an annual interest rate of 6-month EURIBOR plus a 3% margin. The interest rate that applies to this loan (3.97%) was calculated by taking the average 6-month EURIBOR rate during the month and year (May 2012) when the loan agreement was finalized (0.970%) and adding a 3% margin. The borrower was to use the proceeds of the loan to finance an EUR 300 million commercial (supply) contract between Poly Technologies Inc. and Cameroon's Ministry of Defense, which was signed in October 2013.The purpose of the project was to facilitate the acquisition of two navy patrol vessels (P108 and P109), which were intended to help Cameroon enhance the security of its territorial waters in the area of the Gulf of Guinea. The patrol ships, which were constructed in Qingdao by Poly Technologies Inc., have several floors and they were both outfitted with latest generation of equipment. Each patrol ship can accommodate a crew of 36. These 64-meter vessels are also armed with 76mm PJ26 cannons, based on the Russian AK-176 gun. During the visit of Cameroon’s Defense Minister Edgard Alain Mebe Ngo'o to China on April 24, 2014, he visited Qingdao, where he officially received two new patrol ships at Qingdao shipyard. Both P109 and P108 patrol craft were inducted into the Cameroonian naval fleet. The two patrol ships subsequently arrived in the Cameroonian port of Douala in May 2014. Then, in 2020, the Special Criminal Court of Cameroon indicted Edgard Alain Mebe Ngo'o, the former Minister of Defense, on charges of embezzling 20.37 billion FCFA (nearly EUR 30.5 million). His wife was also charged with aiding and abetting. The couple has been imprisoned since March 2019. Edgard Alain Mebe Ngo'o allegedly accepted large gifts (including an envelope containing EUR 500,000 in cash and expensive clothing) from Poly Technologies Inc. and in exchange approved several military equipment contracts, including the contract for the Patrol Ship Acquisition Project.
Staff Comments: 1. This project is also known as the Two Navy Patrol Vessels (P108 and P109) Acquisition Project. 2. Some sources suggest that this project was financed with a supplier credit from Poly Technologies Inc. that was, in turn, made possible by China Eximbank’s provision of an export seller’s credit to Poly Technologies. This issue merits further investigation.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million military grant for provision of equipment, materials, and vehicles in 2012
Description: In April or May 2012, China’s Ambassador to Mali, Cao Zhongming, and the Malian Defense Minister signed an RMB 20 million (1.4 billion FCFA or 2.5 million euros) military grant agreement (as captured via Project ID#59115). The grant proceeds were to be used by the Malian Armed Forces to acquire vehicles (4X4 pickups and troop carriers) and other equipment and materials (including radios, spare parts for vehicles, bulletproof vests, and tents). According to an official Government of Mali document, this aid package was received sometime before July 17, 2012. Then, on March 7, 2013, China’s Ambassador to Mali, Cao Zhongming, and the Malian Defense Minister signed another RMB 20 million (1.4 billion FCFA or 2.5 million euros) military grant agreement (as captured via Project ID#30406). The grant proceeds were to be used by the Malian Armed Forces to acquire 65 vehicles (including 4 troop carriers) and other equipment and materials. The delivery of these vehicles, equipment, and materials commenced on June 19, 2013.
Staff Comments: One source indicates that the Chinese Government provided RMB 60 million of military aid to the Malian Government between 2012 and November 2017. However, AidData has not yet identified the timing and nature of the third RMB 20 million grant commitment. This issue merits further investigation.

Title: Chinese Government provides military aid package to Gabon
Description: On June 10, 2012, the Chinese Government and the Government of Gabon signed a military grant agreement. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. Then, on June 10, 2012, the Chinese Government and the Government of Gabon signed a Memorandum of Cooperation on Military Assistance. Sun Jianguo, the deputy Chief of Staff for the People's Liberation Army, visited Gabon as part of China's 'military diplomacy.' Military officers from Gabon have also been invited to the National Defense University in Beijing. The agreement includes grants to fund training of Gabonese officers, sending Chinese Military Health Experts, and 4 proposals in favor of strengthening Sino-Gabonese military cooperation: 1. increasing staff exchanges, especially high-level mutual visits between the armies of the two countries; 2. strengthening pragmatic cooperation and cooperation projects; 3. managing training and internship programs well, 4. giving new impetus to military health collaboration. The implementation status of this project is unknown.
Staff Comments: The French project title is Protocole de coopération relatif à l’assistance militaire accordée par la Chine au Gabon sous forme de don.

Title: China sends second peacekeeping police force to South Sudan
Description: On October 26, 2012, China's second peacekeeping police force in South Sudan departed from China for their mission, as part of the United Nations peacekeeping missions in South Sudan. This force included 13 officers from the anti-terrorism, immigration management, border inspection, and fire investigation departments of the Guangxi Public Security Bureau. The force performed various responsibilities assigned by the United Nations. On November 22, 2013, Chinese Ambassador in South Sudan, Ma Qiang, hosted a party at the Chinese Embassy send off China's second peacekeeping police force and welcome the third (#60619). The amount of funding China provided to send the peacekeepers is unknown.
Staff Comments: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs source states that this team had 14 officers, but embassy source says it has 13.

Title: Chinese Government provides $401,000 grant for Furniture for the FDTL Office Building Project (Linked to Project ID#38001)
Description: On March 8, 2012, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a $395,907.90 grant agreement for the Furniture for the FDTL Office Building Project. The purpose of the project was to furnish a 5751.56 square meter office complex in the town of Fatuhada (on the site of the ex-Indonesian army base) for the Ministry of Defense and Security and Falintil-Forcas de Defesa de Timor-L'este (F-FDTL) Headquarters. The exact locational coordinates of the project site are -8.55476, 125.55332. China IPPR International Engineering Corporation — a subsidiary of Sinomach — was the contractor responsible for implementation. The originally anticipated project implementation start and end dates were January 1, 2012 and March 8, 2013, respectively. The furniture was ultimately delivered and installed over a 3 month period. However, the precise project implementation start and end dates are unknown. According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government disbursed $401,606.43 of grant funding for this project on March 8, 2013. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292534324.
Staff Comments: MOFCOM provided a separate $6.9 million grant for the Ministry of Defense and F-FDTL Headquarters Construction Project (captured in Project ID#38001).

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense grants 8 million RMB in military aid to Moldova Ministry of Defense
Description: On September 13, 2013, the Ministry of National Defense of the People’s Republic of China and the Republic of Moldova Army signed an RMB 8 million grant agreement (No. 2012A-033-JY333). The disbursement of the aid was to be decided at a later date. In 2016. it was decided that this grant would be used to aid the implementation of development projects started by the Moldovan army with previous aid from China. According to the agreement, all parties must fulfill the obligations laid out within the agreement within 5 years of signing. On August 29, 2017, China delivered the equipment worth 8 million RMB to Moldova at Chinisau. The grant proceeds were to be used by the Republic of Moldova Army to purchase 9 buses, 3 ambulances, 10 electricity generators, 4 refrigerated vehicles, and various spare parts. According to the Government of Moldova’s External Assistance Management Platform (PGAE), this grant (PGAE ID#87211525775) had fully disbursed as of November 21, 2013. The PGAE also indicated the project commenced on September 13, 2012 and was expected to reach completion on September 13, 2017. However, the project was officially completed on August 29, 2017.
Staff Comments: The RMB 8 million grant agreement (No. 2012A-033-JY333) can be accessed in its entirety at https://www.dropbox.com/s/i3wepag1toxsp2i/september%2012%202012%20rmb%208%20million%20military%20aid%20agreement.pdf?dl=0  and https://www.dropbox.com/s/pccto57vcm57i3r/protocol_1400.doc?dl=0. A complete list of the goods that were to be purchased with the grant proceeds is provided in the annex to the agreement.
