Title: Chinese Government donates 29 military vehicles for special operations units (Linked to Project ID#66832)
Description: On December 6, 2012, the Chinese Ministry of Defense donated 29 military vehicles with 'cross-country abilities' to the Government of Belarus. The vehicles are Dongfeng Mengshi EQ2050 cross-country vehicles — better known as “Bogatyr” — are specifically designed for Belarus' special operations units. The Bogatyr weighs up to five tonnes and carries four servicemen. Variants are armed with a Kalashnikov PKM 7.62 mm medium machine gun, NSVT HMG, or 9K111-1 Konkurs anti-tank guided missile (ATGM) system.

The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire IT and communications equipment. No further implementation details are available.

Title: Chinese Government provides engineering equipment and training worth $5 million to the Armed Forces of Liberia
Description: In 2012, the Chinese government donated engineering equipment worth about 5 million USD to the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) The Chinese Government also provided hands-on training for AFL’s Engineers on how to operate the different pieces of equipment at the Camp Tubman Military Barracks in Bong County. This project has reached completion.

Title: China granted funds for Y-1211 Aircraft Training and Spare Parts Project (Linked to Project ID#36665)
Description: In 2011, the Aviation Industry Corporation of China (AVIC) signed an agreement with the Guyana Ministry of National Defense and the Government of Guyana to acquire Chinese government assistance for services and parts related to Y-12II aircraft and air-to-ground conversion training. The Chinese Ministry of National Defense supported training for 23 ground crews and five pilots in addition to a handover of spare parts. On May 25, 2012, a completion ceremony for the Y-12II air-to-ground conversion training certificate and spare parts was held at the Timay Air Force Base in Guyana. At the event, the Chief of Staff of the Guyana Defense Force (GDF) and a representative of the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) signed a 'Training Completion Certificate' and a 'Spare Parts Receiving Certificate' to signify Chinese assistance to the GDF in maintaining Y-12II aircraft and related technologies.Previously, in 2001, CATIC provided a 2001 interest-free supplier's credit to Guyana for the acquisition of Y-1211 aircraft and spare parts (see project ID #36665).
Cofinancing Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)
Receiving Agencies: Government of Guyana|Guyana Ministry of National Defense

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 130 million grant in 2012 for '9.26’ (UAV Acquisition) Project (Linked to Project ID#72479, #72477, #53912)
Description: On May 29, 2012, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 130 million grant to the Government of Pakistan for the '9.26' Project. 9.26 is a codename for a defense project that involves the acquisition of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to the grant proceeds for this project as being fully utilized in its Year Book for Fiscal Year 2014/15. However, the precise equipment delivery date is unknown.  Project ID#72477 and ID#72479 capture additional Chinese Government grants for the same project. In late 2015, Neil Gibson, a weapons analyst with IHS Jane’s, reported that imagery of Pakistan’s first (Burraq) armed drone suggested it was either a Chinese UAV (the CH-3 UAV) or an indigenous drone based on Chinese technology. ISPR Director General Major General Asim Salim Bajwa announced the first-ever use of the Burraq drone to strike a terrorist compound in Shawal Valley (killing three high-profile terrorists) in September 2015.  The attack was a significant milestone for Pakistan in that it joined the small club of countries with armed drones. The Pakistani Government had previously sought to buy armed drones from the US, but Washington refused to authorize the purchase because of concerns about exporting a sensitive technology.

Title: CATIC provides $67 million supplier credit for K-8P Fighter Jet Trainer Acquisition Project
Description: In 2012, China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) and the Government of Zambia signed a $67 million supplier credit agreement for the K-8P Fighter Jet Trainer Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this supplier credit were used by the Zambia Air Force (ZAF) to purchase eight K-8P Fighter Jet Trainers from CATIC. On March 21, 2012, CATIC officially handed over eight K-8P trainers to the Zambia Air Force (ZAF) at Mumbwa Air Base in Zambia. The K-8, or Karakorum-8, can perform various daily maneuvers and aerobatic fighter training as well as air-to-air and air-to-ground armament training.
Funding Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 75 million grant for Military Officer Apartment Building Construction Project
Description: In 2012, the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed an RMB 75 million grant agreement for the Military Officer Apartment Building Construction Project. The purpose of this project was to construct an apartment building complex — with two nine-story buildings and 108 housing units — in the Jol microdistrict within the capital city of Bishkek. ZZTY Construction Engineering Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. A foundation stone-laying ceremony took place on April 5, 2012 and the project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on September 3, 2014. The originally anticipated project implementation start date was August 2013.

Title: PLA provides $3 million grant for National Defence College (NDC) Construction Project
Description: In 1998, the Tanzania Peoples Defence Forces (TPDF) formed a committee to examine the possibility of establishing a National Defence College (NDC). The committee team underscored the desirability and importance of establishing an NDC. However, it was not easy to establish such an institution at that time due to financial constraints and heavy costs of running the college. In 2008, the idea of establishing a NDC was again revived. The Chinese Peoples’ Liberation Army (PLA) was approached and they agreed to finance the project with a $3 million grant. The Government of Tanzania contributed 2 billion TZS of local counterpart funding. The project involved the construction of a main academic building, medical center, dining hall, recreational facility, and lodging for the 60 students each year. The NDC is located in the administrative ward of Kunduchi. On January 10, 2011, the newly constructed campus was officially handed over to the TPDF. The handover ceremony was officiated by Tanzania’s Minister of Defence and National Service Dr Hussein Ali Mwinyi. Then, on April 11, 2011 the NDC Faculty — consisting of the Commandant Major General (now Lieutenant General and URT ambassador to Zimbabwe, Charles Lawrance Makakala, three SDS and the College Secretary — were appointed to start preparations for NDC Course 01. On September 10, 2012 Dr. Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete, the Former President of the United Republic of Tanzania and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces officially inaugurated the College and its First Course.
Staff Comments: The National Defence College describes itself as 'a centre of excellence for conducting National Security Studies in a unique and most comprehensive way. It is an inter-services (defence-civil) Government establishment under the Ministry of Defence and National Service. It has been established and mandated to run Security and Strategic Studies Course for senior officers from the Defence, Security Organs and Civil Services. Its aim is to equip Defence and Government policy makers with requisite economic, political, military, scientific, international relations and national organizational knowledge necessary for understanding of national security in its internal and external dynamics. In the forty-seven week training, Course Members are exposed to an integrated multi-dimensional knowledge which enables them to appropriately address challenges impacting on the national security. The NDC also offers an opportunity to those selected senior officers of getting together and exchanging ideas and hence enabling a holistic appreciation of each other’s problems, both in peace and in war. The course therefore builds the capacity of the Course Members for subsequent effective policy making at grand strategic level.'

Title: Chinese Government donates AK47 rifles, rocket launchers, ammunition, anti-aircraft guns and mortars worth RMB 25 million
Description: On April 29, 2011, China's Ambassador to Sierra Leone, Kuang Weilin, donated a batch of AK47 rifles, rocket launchers, ammunition, anti-aircraft guns and mortars to Sierra Leone's army (RSLAF) to improve its defensive capabilities. The handover ceremony took place at the Joint Forces Command Headquarters in Cockrill. The donation included supplies amounting to $4 million (RMB 25 million); six trained Chinese military men also traveled with the supplies to provide training on the new weapons to the local personnel. Foreign Minister Joseph Dauda indicated that eleven military officers were also being trained in China.
Staff Comments: Chinese donations to the Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces (RSLAF) have occurred since 1987.

Title: Chinese Government donates 50,000 military uniforms to Cambodian Army (Linked to Project ID#32233)
Description: On May 26, 2011, the Chinese Government donated 50,000 military uniforms to the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF). The handover ceremony was held at the Military Airport in Phnom Penh and it was attended by Zhang Jianlin, Chinese military attache to Cambodia, Lt. Gen. Sun Samnang, director general of Cambodia' s Defense Ministry's logistics and finance department, and Moeung Samphan, a secretary of state for the Cambodian Defense Ministry. This donation was initially pledged during a May 2010 meeting between Chinese President Hu Jintao and Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen in Shanghai. At that meeting, Hu Jintao pledged a package of 257 military trucks and 50,000 military uniforms. The truck donation is captured in Project ID#32233.

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.25 billion government concessional loan for Z-9 Helicopter Acquisition Project
Description: On August 20, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 1.25 billion ($195 million) government concessional loan (GLC) agreement for the Z-9 Helicopter Acquisition Project. According to the Cambodia ODA Database maintained by the Government of Cambodia, the GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 20-year maturity, 10-year grace period, and 1% interest rate. The proceeds of the GCL were to be used by the borrower to finance a commercial contract between the Civil Aviation Authority of Cambodia and China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC). The purpose of the project was to acquire 12 Chinese-made Z-9 light utility helicopters for disaster management and anti-terrorism purposes. All 12 helicopters were officially delivered to the Royal Cambodian Air Force on November 25, 2013 at a handover ceremony that was attended by Cambodian Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tea Banh and Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Bu Jianguo. On July 14, 2014, one of the Z-9 helicopters crashed into an old sand quarry in Phnom Penh’s Prey Sar commune. Four military officers – including two generals – were killed in the early morning crash. The originally anticipated project completion date, as recorded in the Cambodia ODA Database maintained by the Government of Cambodia, was August 20, 2015.
Staff Comments: In the Cambodia ODA Database maintained by the Government of Cambodia, this project is referred to as the ‘Disaster Management and Anti-Terrorism’ Project. The Chinese project title is 6????.

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 716.4 million government concessional loan for 6 H-425 Helicopters Procurement Project (Linked to Project ID#36006)
Description: On December 22, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Bolivia signed a preferential loan framework agreement, which specified the borrowing terms for the 6 H-425 Helicopters Procurement Project. On the same day, China Eximbank and the Government of Bolivia signed an RMB 716,427,053.03 ($108,729,121.28) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2011) 41 TOTAL NO. (391)] for the 6 H-425 Helicopters Procurement Project. According to the Central Bank of Bolivia, the GCL carried the following borrowing terms: 2% interest rate, 21 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 0.75% commitment fee, and 1% administration (management) fee. The loan agreement was signed into law on March 28, 2012 (Law No. 231). The transaction will mainly be under the executing jurisdiction of the Bolivian Ministry of Defense.The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance a a commercial contract with China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC) for the acquisition of six, Harbin H-425 helicopters. The helicopters were to be used by the Bolivian Armed Forces to support anti-drug trafficking efforts and promote civil defense. The helicopters can used for day and night operations and they are equipped with meteorological radar and terrain proximity warning equipment. They have the capacity to carry up to 12 passengers and a load of 4 tons. The project also involved the provision of a flight simulator, spare parts, tools and equipment to support the missions (stretchers, rescue crane). Training for pilots, technicians, and maintenance personnel was included as well. CATIC successfully delivered the helicopters to the Bolivian Armed Forces on September 12, 2014, and the helicopters are now based in Chimoré with a maintenance detachment in Cochabamba. However, this project has prompted criticism and controversy. Bolivian legislators have levied complaints about undue influence and inappropriate procurement practices. The Bolivian Armed Forces was also reportedly dissatisfied with the project because of maintenance problems, defective parts, and insufficient training for pilots and maintenance teams.This project is linked to the umbrella project #36006, which seems to be the wider agreement connected to this credit.
Staff Comments: 1. The Spanish project title is el Proyecto de Adquisición de seis (6) Helicópteros Harbin H-425 or Compra de 6 Helicópteros. 2. The H-4245 helicopters are also known as the Z-9 helicopters. The Harbin Z-9 is an aircraft built by the Harbin Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation from the AS 365N “Dauphin” kit supplied by Aérospatiale (now Eurocopter). 3. This China Eximbank loan is not included in the China-Latin America Finance Database, co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.4. 'Helicópteros chinos costarán 135.2 millones de dólares' article and INFORME de la DEUDA EXTERNA PÚBLICA AL 31 DE DICIEMBRE DE 2017 disagree on maturity period, with the former noting 20 years and the later noting 21 years. Per coding guidelines, the more official source (Central Bank of Bolivia) is used.5. Gaceta Official Source can be accessed by using the url (http://gacetaoficialdebolivia.gob.bo/app/webroot/index.php/normas/buscar) and searching for 'Ley 231' [Law 231], 'Decreto Supremo 1103' [Supreme Decree 1103] or 'China – EXIMBANK'.

Title: Chinese Government provides $1.5 million grant to fight transnational organized crime and drug trafficking
Description: On October 31, 2011, China’s Central Military Commission and Colombia’s Ministry of National Defense signed a $1.5 million (10 million RMB) grant agreement to support logistical programs in Colombia and help the authorities fight transnational organized crime and drug trafficking. No further implementation details are available.

Title: China pledges speedboat and mobile vehicle to repair Timor Leste Defence Force boats
Description: On October 19, 2011, an agreement was signed in which China offers Timor-Leste a speedboat and a mobile vehicle to repair boats from the Timor Leste Defence Force (F-FDTL) Naval Component.
Source Titles: Timor-Leste and China strengthen cooperation relations in the Defense area
Source Publishers: Government of Timor Leste

Title: Chinese Government donates military equipment worth RMB 6 million to Tonga Defense Services
Description: On May 3, 2011, H.E. Mr. Siamelie Latu paid a visit to China. During the visit, Rear Admiral Guan Youfei of the People's Liberation Army Navy (?PLAN) of China pledged to provide Tonga Defense Service (TDS) with RMB 6 million worth of military equipment. He also indicated that China’s Ministry of National Defense was prepared to assist TDS in training its personnel. Then, on July 22, 2011, the Chinese Government and TDS signed an RMB 10 million military grant agreement. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: Military projects are considered ODA-ineligible unless they meet narrow development requirements (e.g. disaster relief). Therefore the flow class is recorded as military and the intent as mixed.

Title: Chinese Embassy donates computers worth $300,000 to Macedonia’s Ministry of Defense
Description: According to the Macedonian Government's official news source, MIA News, on January 31st, 2011, Chinese Ambassador to Macedonia Dong Chungfeng, handed over 300,000 Euros worth of computers to Macedonian Defense Minister Zoran Konjanovski. The handover took place at an official ceremony in Skopje, and represented official support from China's Ministry of Defense for the Macedonian Ministry of Defense. According to MIA News, this is the third instance of Chinese aid to the Macedonian Ministry of Defense, with two previous instances in 2004 and 2006.
Staff Comments: No other source was found confirming China's donation of computers to the Macedonian Ministry of Defense.
Source Titles: Chinese ambassador donates IT equipment to Macedonian Defence Ministry, army
Source Publishers: BBC

Title: Chinese Government donates military aid to Antigua & Barbuda
Description: On December 7, 2011, Chinese Ambassador Hanming Liu and Antigua and Barbuda Defense Force Chief of Staff Col. Trevor Thomas signed a military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were intended to improve Antigua & Barbuda army's operating capabilities and its hurricane response capabilities in particular. More details on the military aid materials provided for under this grant agreement are unknown.
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People's Republic of China in Antigua & Barbuda

Title: Chinese Government donates patrol vessel to Seychellois Coast Guard (Linked to Project ID#69048)
Description: In 2011, Seychellois President James Michel and then Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping discussed the possibility of the Chinese Government donating a patrol vessel to defend the island nation's exclusive economic zone from piracy.  It was officially donated to the Seychellois Coast Guard on June 17, 2014 and renamed Etoile. The exact monetary value of the 6.5 meter boat is unknown. However, its estimated cost cost if $12.5 million. The Type 62 Class Gunboat (Shanghai class II NATO designation) was built by South China Repairs Shipyard in Guangzhou and is designed for multipurpose missions including patrol, surveillance, anti-piracy, anti-illegal fishing, anti-terrorism, etc. The keel was laid in March 2013 and the vessel was launched on October 14, 2013, while sea trials were conducted in late December 2013. The vessel was transported to Seychelles onboard a Chinese cargo vessel beginning on on April 26, 2014 and arrived at the Seychelles Coast Guard base at Ile du Port on April 29, 2014. Moreover, 18 Chinese crew members trained their Seychellois counterparts on how to operate the boat (as captured via Project ID#69048).
Staff Comments: 1. The Type 62 Class (Shanghai II) is a 38.78 meter long vessel with a displacement of 135 tonnes. It is powered by two diesel engines with a combined output of 1200 hp and two diesel engines which together produce 910 hp. This gives a top speed of 26 knots and a range of 750 nautical miles at 16 knots. 2. AidData has estimated the value of the grant commitment that supported this project by estimating the unit cost ($12.5 million) of a Type 62 Class Gunboat (based on the information provided in this source: https://jamestown.org/program/chinas-inroads-into-east-timor/).

Title: Chinese Government donates $1.6 million to the African Union peacekeeping mission in Somalia
Description: In July 2011, in a speech made at the 9th Plenary Meeting of the Contact Group on Piracy off the Coast of Somalia, the Chinese Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations, Wang Min revealed that China completed a donation of $1.6 million to the Africa Union for its peace keeping mission in Somalia (AMISOM).

Title: Chinese Government donates MDL 7 million worth of military equipment
Description: On May 25, 2011, the Chinese Government donated MDL 7 million worth of military equipment to the Government of Moldova. The equipment donation consisted of vehicles, field bath unit trailers, field water closet trailers, field refrigerated trailers, field power station trailers, fully automatic washing and drying machines, video conference equipment, laptops, and more. According to Moldova’s Ministry of Defense, the Chinese equipment was used to replace obsolete Soviet equipment.

Title: 7th batch of Chinese peacekeeping force is sent to Lebanon in 2011 (Linked to #41114)
Description: On February 22, 2011, the 7th batch of Chinese peacekeepers arrived in Lebanon as part of China's contribution to the UN Interim Forces In Lebanon (UNIFIL). The force consisted of 145 troops, and they served until March 4, 2012, primarily in Southern Lebanon. China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. See project ID #41114 for the full project. Title: China and Seychelles renew Defense Cooperation Agreement (Linked to #68807)
Description: On December 2, 2011, the Chinese Minister of Defense and Seychellois President Michel signed a military cooperation agreement ensuring Chinese assistance in the form of training, equipment, and exchange visits. This is a renewal of a 2004 cooperation agreement (project #68807). Seychelles is strategically located in the Indian Ocean between Asia and Africa attracting piracy activities and therefore threatening China's investments and import-export activities in Africa. On his visit to the island nation, the Chinese Defence Minister General Liang Guanglie was accompanied by a 40-member military delegation. According to an Indian research insitute, a delegation of this size is significant because it suggests China's PLA wants an active presence in Seychelles. At this 2011 meeting, President Michel 'invited' China to establish a military base in Seychelles. However, it is unclear whether this came to fruition since Chinese military analysts later said that their outpost facility did not operate as military base and reaffirmed their policy of not setting up military bases abroad (see: One India, Eurasian Times). Moves like this threaten India's dominance in the Indian Ocean causing India to sign a 20-year pact with Seychelles and build a $550 million USD military base on Assumption Island.
Implementing Agencies: China Ministry of Defense|Seychelles People's Defense Force

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense provides 10 million RMB in heavy construction equipment under military assistance agreement with Peru
Description: On November 2, 2011, an agreement was signed between the Chinese Ministry of Defense and Peruvian Ministry of International Relations for a grant of 10 million RMB. The grant was further directed into military aid in the Protocol for Free Military Assistance (El Protocolo sobre Asistencia Militar Grautuita No 2013 B-003-JY430), which was signed on March 18, 2013. (Resolucion Ministerial No 225-2013 DE/SG) On March 7, 2014, the Government of Peru formally accepted a donation of heavy construction equipment from China, funded by the aforementioned military aid protocol (Resolucion Ministerial No. 122-2014 DE/SG)No customs or duties were paid on the donated materials. The Army of Peru was entrusted with customs clearance, inventory, and discharge of materials. The inventory is to be conducted with participation from the Armed Force of Peru and the military attache of the Embassy of China in Peru.The contents of the donation were two bulldozers, two crawler excavators, two motor graders, two road rollers (roller-compactors), two water tanks for irrigation, and five dump trucks. The equipment is intended to aid the operations of the Armed Forces of Peru.
Receiving Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)

Title: China granted 5 million RMB in military equipment to Guyana in 2011
Description: In 2011, the People's Liberation Army of China (PLA) granted the Guyana Defense Force (GDF) military equipment amounting to 5 million Chinese yuan. The equipment included one ambulance, three front end loaders, one excavator, one generator plant and two inflatable boats with outboard engines. The handover ceremony was held at GDF Base Camp Ayanganna, Thomaslands, Georgetown, Drill Square.
Source Titles: GDF receives $5M RMB in machinery, equipment from PLA|Chinese Military makes another sizable donation to GDF
Source Publishers: Guyana Chronicle |

Title: PLA donates parachutes, buses, and communications equipment to Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: On March 8, 2011, Ma Xiaotian, the Chinese deputy chief of the General Staff of the People's Liberation Army, and Rubén Saavedra, the Bolivian Minister of Defense, signed a military cooperation agreement which promised to grant Bolivia communications equipment. The agreement also discussed the exchange of personnel such as military officers and scholars. The agreement includes the provision of communications equipment and the strengthening of the relations of the Armed Forces of both countries.Through the agreement, China granted 350 parachutes (of models SBS 7 and SBS 9), eight Higer KLQ 810 buses (2013 model) with a 43 passenger capacity, and 30 VHF digital portable radio sets with power amplification and whip antenna (model PRC 2188). The donation had arrived in Bolivia as of September 28, 2013, when President Morales distributed the equipment to the Special Troops Training Center (CITE) 18th Airborne Command Regiment 'Victoria' on the 50th anniversary of its creation.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million grant in 2011 for '9.26’ (UAV Acquisition) Project (Linked to Project ID#72479, #72476)
Description: On September 26, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange, which committed RMB 100 million of grant funding for a military project that the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to as '9.26'. 9.26 is a codename for a defense project that involves the acquisition of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) refers to the grant proceeds for this project as being fully utilized in its Year Book for Fiscal Year 2014/15. However, the precise equipment delivery date is unknown. Project ID#72479 and ID#72476 capture additional Chinese Government grants for the same project. In late 2015, Neil Gibson, a weapons analyst with IHS Jane’s, reported that imagery of Pakistan’s first (Burraq) armed drone suggested it was either a Chinese UAV (the CH-3 UAV) or an indigenous drone based on Chinese technology. ISPR Director General Major General Asim Salim Bajwa announced the first-ever use of the Burraq drone to strike a terrorist compound in Shawal Valley (killing three high-profile terrorists) in September 2015.  The attack was a significant milestone for Pakistan in that it joined the small club of countries with armed drones. The Pakistani Government had previously sought to buy armed drones from the US, but Washington refused to authorize the purchase because of concerns about exporting a sensitive technology.
Source Titles: YEAR BOOK 2014-15|Pakistan developing combat drones|China supported, designed or supplied Pakistan's first indigenous drone, claim analysts|China assisted Pakistan on armed drone, say experts|NESCOM Burraq

Title: Chinese Government provides $2.6 million grant for Military Housing Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#38094)
Description: On April 20, 2010, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a grant agreement worth $2,488,545.37 for the Military Housing Complex Construction Project. The purpose of the project was to construct a housing complex with 100 housing units for F-FDTL — Timor Leste's Defense Force — in the town of Metinaro within Metinaro Subdistrict and Dili District. Each housing unit has three bedrooms, two living rooms, one kitchen, and one bathroom. According to China's Ministry of Commerce, the project was originally intended to benefit veterans but was modified at the request of Prime Minister Jose Ramos-Horta to benefit active military personnel. Chongqing International Construction Corporation (CICO) was the contractor responsible for implementation. A foundation-laying ceremony took place on November 27, 2009 and the housing complex was officially inaugurated on August 26, 2011. According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government disbursed $2,659,990.61 of grant funding for this project. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292191424.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Accommodation for F-FDTL China-Aid Project and the Project Concerning the Construction of 100 Houses for F-FDTL. The Portuguese project title is Construção de 100 quartéis para as FFDTL. The Chinese project title is ?????????.This project is a separate but complementary grant commitment from the one captured in Project ID#38094.
Implementing Agencies: Chongqing Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Group Co., Ltd.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 8 million grant to combat drug trafficking through purchasing logistical equipment
Description: On September 6, 2010, the Chinese Government and Colombia’s Ministry of National Defense signed an RMB 8 million grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to combat narcotics trafficking by purchasing logistical equipment and providing technical assistance for training exercises. The focus of this donation is to combat narcotics trafficking as well as to bolster the working relationship between China and Colombia. No further implementation details of the project are available.
Staff Comments: No further implementation details are available. However, since other military grant agreements were signed by the two parties in the future (see, for example, Project ID#36706), the project was most likely completed. This issue requires further investigation.The project title in Spanish is, 'Acuerdo de Ayuda Militar Gratuita de China a Colombia por valor de Ocho Millones de Yuanes para la Compra de Materiales de Logística.'

Title: Chinese Government grants four trainer aircraft to Pakistan (linked to project #36693)
Description: On May 24, 2010, an agreement was signed by Pakistani Defence Minister Ahmad Mukhtar and his Chinese counterpart Gen. Liang Guangile for the provision of four trainer aircraft to the Pakistan Air Force. The aircraft was said to be ZDK-03 early warning aircraft developed by China and manufactured by Shaanxi Aircraft Manufacturing Company. As of February 26, 2015, the aircraft was said to have been delivered to the Pakistan Air Force. The monetary value of this project is unknown.
Receiving Agencies: Pakistan Air Force (PAF)|Pakistan Ministry of Defence

Title: Chinese Government provides $6.9 million grant for Ministry of Defense and F-FDTL Headquarters Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#63151)
Description: On December 16, 2010, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a $6,727,289.60 grant agreement for the Ministry of Defense and F-FDTL Headquarters Construction Project. The purpose of the project was to construct a 5751.56 square meter office complex in the town of Fatuhada (on the site of the ex-Indonesian army base) for the Ministry of Defense and Security and F-FDTL Headquarters. The exact locational coordinates of the project site are -8.55476, 125.55332. China Shandong International Economic & Technical Cooperation Corporation (SIETC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on August 24, 2010. Construction commenced on December 18, 2010 and the building took 14 months to complete. A project handover certificate was issued in March 2012 and Prime Minister Gusmao officially inaugurated the new office complex on April 3, 2012. According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government disbursed $6,907,941.75 of grant funding for this project on April 3, 2012. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292191429.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Construction of F-FDTL HQ Project. The Portuguese project title is Quartel General F-Fdtl Fatuhada or Construção do edifício do Ministério da Defesa e Quartel General das F-FDTL. The Chinese project title is ???????????????.
Implementing Agencies: China Shandong International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (SIETC)

Title: Chinese Government provides $2.6 million grant for Military Housing Complex Levee Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#35336)
Description: On November 11, 2010, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a $2,661,031.54 grant agreement for the Military Housing Complex Levee Construction Project. The purpose of the project was to construct a 100-meter levee to protect a military housing complex — with 100 quarters — for the F-FDTL, Timor Leste's Defense Force (????????????????). The levee is located in the town of Metinaro within Metinaro Subdistrict and Dili District. Construction commenced on September 28, 2011 and the project was completed in February 2012. According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government disbursed $2,697,256.73 of grant funding for this project on December 31, 2011. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292531895.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Flood Control Project for the F-FDTL Housing Complex Project or the Construction of Flood-Control Project of 100 quarters for the F-FDTL (2). The Chinese project title is ???????????????? or ??????????????. The Portuguese project title is Projecto acrescentado de barragem ao bairro militar. The Chinese Government also provided a separate grant for the construction of the military housing complex — with 100 quarters — for the F-FDTL (captured in Project ID#35336).

Title: Chinese Government donates construction equipment worth RMB 10 million to Mongolian Ministry of Defense
Description: On February 28, 2010, the Chinese Government officially delivered 18 pieces of donated equipment (worth RMB 10 million) — including an auto crane, bitumen transporter vehicle, bulldozer, universal tractor, excavator, loader, trailer, road roller, and truck — to the Defense Ministry of Mongolia. This project was financed with the proceeds from a grant agreement that was previously signed by China’s Ministry of Defense and Mongolia’s Ministry of Defense.
Staff Comments: This project may have been financed with a grant commitment that was made on August 28, 2008 (as captured via Project ID#40391). This issue requires further investigation.
Source Titles: China delivers construction equipment for Mongolian military

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 30 million grant for AU peacekeeping mission in Somalia (Linked to Project ID#52297, ID#60859)
Description: In December 2010, the Chinese Government reportedly provided an RMB 30 million grant to the African Union Mission to Somalia (AMISOM) for peacekeeping purposes. The grant proceeds were to be used to supply equipment and materials for AMISOM. In a speech at the 9th Plenary Meeting of the Contact Group on Piracy off the Coast of Somalia at the UN headquarters, China’s deputy representative to the UN confirmed that the grant was successfully implemented.
Staff Comments: This project is linked to a 2011 donation worth $1.6 million (captured via Project ID #60859) and a 2015 grant worth $1.2 million (as captured via Project ID#52297), both of which went to the same peacekeeping mission.

Title: Chinese Government pledges $30 million of military aid
Description: On November 10, 2010, Jordan’s Prime Minister Samir al-Rifa'i met with the Vice-Chairman of the Chinese Central Military Commission, General Xu Caihou, to discuss ways to boost bilateral cooperation between Jordan and China. Al-Rifa'i hailed the two countries' special relations and valued China's continuous support to Jordan — in particular, a grant agreement that was to be signed the following day for $30 million of Chinese military aid.
Source Titles: Jordan, China to sign 30m-dollar miltary aid agreement in Amman
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Middle East

Title: Chinese Government donates military equipment worth up to $1.2 million
Description: On September 13, 2010, the Moldovan and Chinese defense ministers, Vitalie Marinuta and Liang Guanglie, signed a 15 million lei ($1.2 million) military grant agreement on behalf of their respective governments. The grant proceeds were to be used to facilitate the acquisition of ambulances, computers, communication systems, equipment for video conference halls, water treatment stations and medical equipment for military hospitals. The intended beneficiary of the grant was the Moldovan Army. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: Unable to find information on whether or not the equipment arrived in Moldova.
Source Titles: China offers Moldovan army over 1m dollars in technical assistance|Moldova to use Chinese assistance to build training centre for peacekeepers|Chinese Technical Aid to the National Army
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Ukraine & Baltics|BBC Monitoring Ukraine & Baltics|Ministry of Defense at the Republic of Moldova

Description: On June 14, 2010, the People's Liberation Army of China and the Ministry of Defense of Serbia signed an EUR 500,000 grant agreement for the provision of information technology and office equipment.

Title: China Eximbank provides $105 million loan for Z-9W Helicopter Acquisition Project
Description: In 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Zambia signed a $105 million loan agreement for the Z-9W Helicopter Acquisition Project. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The purpose of the project was to facilitate the acquisition of eight new Z-9W helicopters produced by Harbin Aircraft Industry Group (which also goes by Hafei or ??). The first four helicopters were delivered to Zambia's Air Force in June 2012, and the other four arrived November 2012. According to Zambia's Vice President, just the helicopter's frame was produced by Hafei, and then Hafei used other parts from France and the US to assemble the whole helicopter.   Harbin Z-9W, or Zhi-9W (?9W), is an attack helicopter produced by HAIG. The Z-9W is an indigenous attack variant of the Z-9 utility helicopter, which itself is a license-built version of the Eurocopter AS365 Dauphin. This helicopter can fly at a maximum cruise speed of 238km/h, while carrying external weapons. The ferry range with internal auxiliary tank is 1,000km. The helicopter has an endurance of 3.35 hours.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ?-9???????The SAIS-CARI China Loans to Africa database says that this loan financed six helicopters, not eight.

Title: China Eximbank provides $365.5 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase I of Ministry of Defense Housing Project
Description: On 15 December 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Zambia signed a 365.5 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) for Phase I of the Ministry of Defense Housing Project. The total project cost was $430 million, with 85% financed by China Eximbank and 15% by the Government of Zambia.  The counterpart funding was required to be provided before the end of 2010. The PBC carries the a 20 year maturity and 5 year grace period, but its interest rate is unknown. Phase I of this project involved the the construction of 4,527 housing units for defence forces at four sites in Lusaka, one in the town of Mufulira within Copperbelt province, and one in the city of Kabwe within Central province. China Machinery Industry Group Corporation (Sinomach) signed an EPC contract for the implementation of this project on December 28, 2009. Zambia’s Ministry of Defense acted as the “project owner”. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 1, 2011. Construction then began on June 1, 2011, and Phase I was completed on December 11, 2013.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Zambia Military Residential Housing Project. The Chinese project title is ???????
Implementing Agencies: China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach)|Government of Zambia

Title: CATIC provides $9.2 million supplier credit for acquisition of military equipment
Description: According to the Zambia 2010 Auditor General Report, China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) and the Government of Zambia signed a $9,264,705 supplier credit (loan) for the purchase of military equipment on December 17, 2010. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that a 7.5% down payment was made.
Staff Comments: This loan is not included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020 and updated in March 2021 (which is now maintained by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center).

Title: China sends 9th peacekeeping police force to Southern Sudan
Description: In October 2010, China sent the ninth peacekeeping police force to Southern Sudan. The value of this donation and the return date are unknown.
Staff Comments: Chinese embassy source published on October 30, states that this police force had 'newly arrived' (???), implying the start date was in October 2010. This peacekeeping force was sent to current South Sudan; however, South Sudan reached independence in 2011, meaning that the recipient country remains Sudan.Because the purpose of this peacekeeping mission remains unspecified, the flow class has been coded as Military.
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in South Sudan

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 674,804,000 government concessional loan for National Defence College Project (Linked to Project ID#31170)
Description: On 21 May, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Zimbabwe signed an RMB 674,804,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2011) 7 TOTAL NO. (357) NO. (1420303052011110318)] for the National Defence College Project (See: ?????????9800????????? and PARLIAMENT OF ZIMBABWE: Tuesday, 31st May, 2011).  It was ratified on 31 May, 2011 (See: PARLIAMENT OF ZIMBABWE: Tuesday, 31st May, 2011).  This GCL carries the following terms: 2% annual interest rate, 20-year maturity, 7-year grace period, and a 0.25% commitment fee (See: ?????????9800?????????).  The loan was reportedly repaid with proceeds from diamond mining revenues generated from a joint venture between the government and a Chinese mining company operating in Marange diamond fields called Anjin (????) (See: China and Zimbabwe: After Mugabe and RWI Index Questionnaire: Zimbabwe 2012).The purpose of this project was to construct a National Defence College for Zimbabwe’s Ministry of Defence, and thereby provide better conditions for military training and the study of national security.  It was envisaged that the National Defence College would serve as the premier defense education centre in Zimbabwe imparting specialized training in the field of national security and defense to selected military and civilian officers from various segments of the society.  It was also envisaged that the National Defence College would serve as a think tank for providing research on military, defense and national security for the National Security Council, Ministry of Defense and other government organizations.Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Company (??????????) was the contractor responsible for implementation of the project (See: ??????????????????).  A foundation-laying ceremony was held on 25 August, 2010. Then, on 14 September, 2012, a project completion ceremony was held and the National Defence College officially went into use (See: ?????????????????????). The Chinese project title is ???????? or ???? or ???????????.The linked project #31170 captures a donation of seven buses and ICT equipment to the National Defence College by the Government of China.
Implementing Agencies: Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Co., Ltd. (AFECC)
Collateral: The loan was reportedly repaid with proceeds from diamond mining revenues generated from a joint venture between the government and a Chinese mining company operating in Marange diamond fields called Anjin (????)

Title: China Grants Education Materials to the Jordanian Army's Foreign Language Institute
Description: On October 14th, 2010 the Chinese Embassy in Jordan granted Chinese languages books, textbooks, audiovisual products, and teaching materials to the Jordanian Army's Foreign Language Institute on the behalf of Hanban. China's Ambassador to Jordan, Yu Hongyang and China's Military attache to Jordan, Jiang Jipei, signed over the materials to the Dean of the Jordanian Foreign Language Institute, Colonel Adnan, on the same day.The Jordanian Foreign Language Institute began offering Chinese language as a course in 2010.

Title: Chinese Government donates batch of materials and equipment worth RMB 10 million
Description: On December 13, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cabo Verde signed an RMB 10 million military grant agreement to support Cabo Verde’s Armed Forces. The grant proceeds were to be used by Cabo Verde’s Armed Forces to purchase materials for quarters, uniforms, and communications, as well as parts for the repair of the Mullet (a Chinese vessel in Cabo Verde since the 1990s). This batch of donated materials and equipment was handed over in July 2012.

Title: Poly Technologies provides $100 million supplier credit for the procurement of goods for the Ghana Armed Forces
Description: On March 27, 2010, Poly Technologies — a subsidiary of China Poly Group Corporation — and the Government of Ghana signed a $100 million supplier credit agreement for the procurement of goods for the Ghana Armed Forces (GAF). This supplier credit carried an 8 year maturity. The proceeds from this supplier credit were used for the procurement of strategic equipment to re-equip the Ghana Army and the Ghana Air Force. They were also used to construct barracks (50 units) for Ghanaian soldiers, a stadium, and a large auditorium. The project took place on 18 separately construction sites. A groundbreaking ceremony for this project was held on November 24, 2011.  This project was completed. However, its precise date of completion is unknown.

Title: CATIC provides $1.2 billion supplier credit for acquisition of JF-17 fighter jets
Description: According to the Year Book 2010-2011 published by the Government of Pakistan's Finance Division, the Government of Pakistan finalized a $1.2 billion supplier credit (loan) agreement with China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC) during Fiscal Year 2010-2011 to facilitate the acquisition of JF-17 fighter jets. This loan carried an interest rate of 3.99%. The maturity length and grace period of the loan are unknown. The proceeds of the loan were use to finance a commercial contract between Pakistan Aeronautical Complex (PAC) and CATIC, which was signed in March 2009.  Under the terms of the contract, that parties agreed to co-produce 42 JF-17 Block 1 aircraft. Two serial production aircraft were delivered by CATIC between March and November 2009. Ten JF-17  aircraft were in service as of November 23, 2009. The first JF-17 manufactured JF-17 by PAC handed over to Pakistan’s Air Force on November 23, 2009. The first squadron (No. 26 Black Spiders) was made operational in February 2010 with an initial strength of 14 JF-17 fighters. 18 JF-17 aircraft were in service as of March 2011. The JF-17 made its debut at Farnborough Air Show in 2010, when two JF-17s flew all the way from Pakistan to Farnborough, UK. Four months later in November 2010, three JF-17s flew to China to participate in Zhuhai Air Show, where the aircraft made its first ever aerobatics display. In June 2011, three JF-17s participated in aerobatics and static display in 100-years Celebrations of Turkish Air Force and subsequently three JF-17s also participated in Dubai Air Show in October 2011. At all these Air Shows, the JF-17 attracted intense focus of visitors and international media. The JF-17 Thunder is an all weather, multi-role, light combat aircraft that has the potential to be the main stay & work horse of any Air Force. The design of JF-17 aircraft is based on modern concepts of aerodynamics. The aircraft is equipped with a digital fly-by-wire flight control system that gives it the agility in all regimes of the operational flight envelope. It has a complete glass cockpit, excellent man-machine interface and modern self–protection suite, which enhance combat potential and survivability of the aircraft. It is equipped with fourth generation avionics systems, wide range of conventional & smart weapons, long range glide bombs, Beyond Visual Range & short range Air-to-Air missiles, Anti-Ship missile and Air-to-Surface missiles. The aircraft requires remarkably short lengths of runway for take-off & landing, which offers flexibility of aircraft operations at short air strips. Shortly, the aircraft will also have Air-to-Air refueling capability, which will further enhance its combat potential and employment options.
Funding Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)
Implementing Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)

A U.N. census estimated that there were about 4,500 soldiers in Guinea Bissau's armed forces in 2008.

The agreement was signed at the Seychelles People's Defense Forces (SPDF) headquarters by the Chief of Defense Forces Brigadier Leopold Payet and the Director of National Defense from China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Major General Qian Lihua. Title: Chinese Government donates two boats to Ugandan Navy
Description: In September 2007, the Chinese Defense Minister Cao Gangchuan met with the Commander of the Armed Forces of Uganda Aronda Nyakairima, pledging to promote the military ties between the two armed forces. Then, on March 3, 2009 in Entebbe, Chinese ambassador, Sun Heping, handed over marine boats to Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni to help improve the security of the Great Lakes region. Uganda's Defense Minister, Crispus Kiyonga and the Chief of Defense Forces, Gen. Aronda Nyakairima, attended the handover ceremony. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.

The donation was worth EUR 4 million and it consisted of trucks, tractors, mowers and motorbikes.

Title: Chinese Government provides $57.8 million loan for K-8 Fighter Aircraft Acquisition Project
Description: In 2009, the Government of Bolivia agreed to purchase six K-8 fighter aircraft from China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) for $57.8 million. Then, in January 2010, the Bolivian Minister of Defense, Walker San Miguel, explained that the deal would be financed with a 20-year, concessional loan from the Chinese Government. However, the interest rate and grace period of the loan are unknown. In August 2011, Armando Pacheco, the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, acknowledged that the aircraft were purchased with a loan from the Chinese Government.The 6 K-8s were to be used both for training purposes and counter-narcotic efforts. The project reached completion with the delivery of the aircraft on June 23, 2011. CATIC also provided a K-8 flight simulator, two spare engines, a test vehicle system for maintenance, an interactive multimedia destroyer system, spare parts, and tools. Upon receipt, the aircraft were reportedly deployed in the Cochabamba area for drug interception activities. The K-8s, which have a lifespan of 15-20 years, are equipped with six 23-millimeter guns and 12 rockets. They were assembled in Cochabamba Maintenance Center with high-tech parts and equipment from China, and Bolivian instructors and pilots took training courses in China. On March 24, 2021, a Bolivian Air Force (FAB) K-8 with tail number FAB-663 crashed into a house in Sacaba, Bolivia, killing a woman in her house around 9:30 local time during a training mission. Both crew members survived after ejecting from the aircraft.
Staff Comments: 1. The Chinese project title is ?6?K-8?????????. 2. This transaction should not be confused with the China Eximbank loan that support the acquisition of six H-425 helicopters (captured via Project ID#36007). 3. The K-8 is a low-budget attack aircraft that doubles as a trainer. Also called Hongdu JL-8 or Nanchang JL-8 it is a two-seat intermediate jet initially built jointly by China Nanchang Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation and state-run Pakistan Aeronautical Complex. 4. Some sources suggest that the maturity length of the loan may be as long as 25 years. This issue merits further investigation.
Receiving Agencies: Bolivia Ministry of Defense |Government of Bolivia
Implementing Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)

Title: Chinese Government donates two naval patrol boats and five cars worth $1.22 million to Bolivian Navy (Linked to Project ID#38873 and ID#35989)
Description: On March 2, 2009, the Chinese Government officially delivered two donated naval patrol boats and five cars (worth approximately $1,228,000) to the Bolivian Navy. The boats and cars were to be used to patrol Lake Titicaca in order to combat smuggling and drug trafficking. The patrol boats were equipped with 500 horsepower engines (500 HP) and three machine guns. Each had the capacity to transport 12 military personnel. The delivery ceremony was attended by Chinese Ambassador Qu Shengwu and Bolivian President Evo Morales. Then, in June 2009, a group of Chinese technicians arrived in the country to test the vehicles, install navigation instruments, and provide training to the crew for the handling and operation of the boats. The grant was made within the framework of the Bilateral Cooperation Protocol (Protocolo de Cooperación Bilateral) between the two Ministries of Defense (See: 'BOLIVIA Y CHINA AMPLIAN CONVENIO DE COOPERACION TECNICO MILITAR'). Other projects also executed under this framework are recorded in the linked projects #38873 and #35989.
Staff Comments: 1. The grant was issued under the framework of the Bilateral Cooperation Protocol (Protocolo de Cooperación Bilateral) between the Bolivian and Chinese Ministries of Defense (see BOLIVIA Y CHINA AMPLIAN CONVENIO DE COOPERACION TECNICO MILITAR). Other projects also executed under the same framework include Project ID#38873 and Project ID#35989. 2. The Spanish project title is dos modernas lanchas patrulleras artilladas a la Armada Boliviana. The estimated value of the grant commitment for this project is based on a disclosure by the Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira that Chinese Government committed $1,228,000 of military grant assistance to the Government of Bolivia in 2008, which was likely used to support the early 2009 provision of naval patrol boats and cars.
Implementing Agencies: Bolivia Ministry of Defense |China Ministry of Defense

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 18 million grant to Bolivian military for acquisition of 37 buses, 21 trucks and 40 boat engines
Description: On June 11, 2009, the Bolivian and Chinese Ministries of Defense signed an RMB 18 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire 37 buses (Higer KLQ6702 buses), 21 4x4 trucks (DF-Nissan ZN2031UBS pick-up trucks), and 40 outboard Yamaha engines for boats for the Bolivian Armed Forces. The equipment was officially handed over to the local authorities on or around March 30, 2010 at a ceremony that was attended by Bolivian President Evo Morales, Chinese Ambassador Qu Shengwu and various Bolivian ministers. This donation marked the third Chinese contribution to the Bolivian military, and it fell within a framework of Free Military Assistance between China and Bolivia.
Staff Comments: The Spanish project title is 37 buses marca hinger; 21 camionetas, nissan; 40 motores fuera de borda para la Armada Boliviana, además de stocks de repuestos para los vehículos y motores.This project is linked to other equipment donation projects: #35971: China Donates Water Drillers and Cargo Trucks to Bolivia to Combat Drought; #35988: China Donates 2 Patrol Boats to Bolivian Armed Forces; and #35989: China Donates Trucks, Buses and Vans to Bolivian Armed Forces.

Title: Chinese Government donates logistical materials worth RMB 10 million to Suriname’s Ministry of Defense
Description: On October 6, 2009, the Defense Ministry of the People’s Republic of China officially delivered a batch of logistical materials worth RMB 10 million to Suriname’s Ministry of Defense. Mr. Ivan Fernald, the Minister of Defense of the Republic of Suriname, Mr. Dennis Kamperveen, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Defense, and Colonel Ernst L. Mercuur, Commander of the Surinamese Armed Forces, attended the handover ceremony.  The stated purpose of the donation was to safeguard Suriname's sovereignty and security.
Source Titles: China Grants Suriname Military Materials
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy to Suriname

Title: Chinese Government donates military equipment worth RMB 5 million to Kyrgyz military
Description: The Chinese Ministry of National Defense donated a batch of military supplies — including 1,000 combat fatigues, 1,000 pairs of winter boots, 6 Dongfeng military vehicles, 1 dump truck, 1 car, and office equipment (such as computers, fax machines and printers) — worth RMB 5 million to the Kyrgyz military on October 1, 2009. The handover ceremony took place at the Kyrgyz National Guards Command. Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan Wang Kaiwen and military officer Cui Enxiong attended the ceremony.
Staff Comments: Note that the project is distinct from Project ID#56625. Although the delivery dates are similar, the content of the donated equipment differs.
Receiving Agencies: Armed Forces of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan

Title: Chinese Government donates military equipment to Kyrgyz Border Defense Administration
Description: On October 3, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense officially handed over a batch of military equipment to the Kyrgyz Border Defense Administration at a ceremony that took place in Bishkek. The aid package included 6 buses, 10 diesel engines, 4 cars and 72 sets of housing materials. The director of the Kyrgyz Border Defense Administration said in an interview that the materials would mainly be distributed to the border guards in the remote areas of the Osh and Chu river regions to improve the situation in some of the border defense areas.
Staff Comments: This project is distinct from Project ID#56622. Although the delivery dates are similar, the content of the donated equipment differs.
Source Titles: ?????????????????|China donates military aid materials to Kyrgyzstan
Source Publishers: ????|Sohu News
Geographic Location: The materials would mainly be distributed to the border guards in the remote areas of the Osh and Chu river regions to improve the situation in some of the border defense areas.

Title: Chinese Government provides $300,000 grant to African Union for peacekeeping mission in Somalia
Description: On January 6, 2009, the Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia and Representative to the African Union Gu Xiaojie donated a $300,000 check on behalf of the Chinese Government to Jean Ping, Chairman of the African Union Commission. The grant was to be used for the AU's peacekeeping mission in Somalia, AMISOM.
Staff Comments: 1: Not to be confused with a series of Chinese government donations to AMISOM - projects #61137 (2007), #61149 (2009), #41113 (2010), #60859 (2011), and #52297 (2015).2: AMISOM was funded in 2007 and China was among the first countries to provide financial support (as captured via Project ID#61137).
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia|Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia
Contact Position: Chairman of the African Union Commission|Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia

Title: Chinese Government provides $400,000 grant to African Union for peacekeeping mission in Somalia
Description: On August 19, 2009, the Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia and Representative to the African Union, Gu Xiaojie, handed over a $400,000 check to Jean Ping, the Chairman of the African Union Commission, in Addis Ababa. This grant was to be used for AU's peacekeeping mission in Somalia, AMISOM, which was established in 2007.
Staff Comments: In 2007, the Chinese Government donated to AMISOM (as captured via Project ID#61137) and earlier in January 2009 the Chinese Government also donated $300,000 to AMISOM (as captured via Project ID#61146).
Source Titles: ?????????????????????|Somalia: The Chinese Government donates amount of 400.000 US dollars to AMISOM mission
Source Publishers: Forum on China-Africa Cooperation|ReliefWeb (United Nations))
Source Type: Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)|NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)
Contact Position: Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia |Chairman of the African Union Commission

Title: Chinese Government offers NAD 1.03 billion loan for the acquisition of weapons
Description: According to an Informante article published in September 2009, the Chinese Government agreed to provide an NAD 1.03 billion ($160 million) loan to the Government of Namibia for the acquisition of weapons. No other information is known. defenceWeb claims that much of the Namibian Air Force’s equipment comes from China.
Staff Comments: An unknown senior military official from Namibia visited China in 2009, so it is possible that is when the agreement was signed (see: last page of US Secretary of Defense report to Congress). This issue merits further investigation
Source Titles: China Helps the Powerful in Namibia|SIPRI: 'China’s arms trade with Africa at times questionable'|Namibia Defence Force|ANNUAL REPORT TO CONGRESS Military and Security Developments Involving the People’s Republic of China 2010 |China gives, China takes away
Source Publishers: New York Times|DW|defenceWeb|United States of America Office of the Secretary of Defense |Insight
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report

Title: Chinese Government provides logistical military supplies worth RMB 20 million
Description: As of February 2009, the Chinese government had provided the Government of Papua New Guinea with 6 batches of logistical military supplies worth RMB 20 million.
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People's Republic of China in Papua New Guinea

Title: [Cancelled] CITIC Bank provides $29.7 million loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes (Linked to Project ID#73320)
Description: On March 6, 2009, CITIC Bank and the Government of Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense (Kementerian Pertahanan) signed a $29,748,300 loan agreement [ID#2009-3219] for unspecified purposes. The loan, which went into effect on the same day, carried the following borrowing terms: a 3% interest rate, 4 year and 1 month maturity, 1 year and 7 month grace period, a management fee of $60,548.37, a commitment fee of $70,968.09, and an insurance premium of $1,157,944.41. As of September 30, 2010, the loan had achieved a 69.69% disbursement rate ($16,877,342.50). On November 14, 2013, China Vanguard Industry Corp agreed to assume responsibility for this $29,748,300 loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense. Project ID#66761 captures the cancelled loan commitment from CITIC Bank. Project ID#73320 captures the active loan commitment from China Vanguard Industry Corp.
Staff Comments: The purpose of the loan is assumed to be for military purposes as it is directed to the Indonesian Ministry of Defense. The Government of Indonesia loan identification number is 28704000.
Source Titles: LAPORAN PENGELOLAAN PINJAMAN DAN HIBAH PEMERINTAH|Laporan Perkembangan Pinjaman dan Hibah Triwulan IV Tahun 2011|Laporan Perkembangan Pinjaman Luar Negeri Dan Hibah Triwulan III Tahun 2010
Source Publishers: |KEMENTERIAN KEUANGAN REPUBLIK INDONESIA DIREKTORAT JENDERAL PENGELOLAAN UTANG|
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: China Eximbank provides $7.05 million buyer’s credit loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes
Description: On December 10, 2009, China Exim Bank and the Government of Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense (Kementerian Pertahanan) signed a $7,055,000 buyer’s credit loan agreement for unspecified purposes. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: 7-year maturity, 3-year grace period, an annual interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.453% in December 2009) plus a 1% margin, a 1% management fee, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 5.34% buyer’s credit insurance premium (most likely from Sinosure). On May 3, 2013, the Indonesian Government signed an agreement, which extended the availability period of the loan from June 16, 2012 to September 30, 2014.
Staff Comments: The Government of Indonesia loan identification number is 28706000. The China Exim Bank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant to Moldovan Army for unspecified purposes
Description: In February 2010, during an interview, the Chinese Ambassador to Moldova, Shi Longzhuang, announced that at the end of 2009, the Chinese Government had pledge an RMB 5 million grant to the Moldovan Army. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: INTERVIU CU EXCELEN?A SA, DOMNUL SHI LONGZHUANG
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Republic of Moldova

Title: China Vanguard provides $29.7 million loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes (Linked to Project ID#66761)
Description: On March 6, 2009, CITIC Bank and the Government of Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense (Kementerian Pertahanan) signed a $29,748,300 loan agreement [ID#2009-3219] for unspecified purposes. The loan, which went into effect on the same day, carried the following borrowing terms: a 3% interest rate, 4 year and 1 month maturity, 1 year and 7 month grace period, a management fee of $60,548.37, a commitment fee of $70,968.09, and an insurance premium of $1,157,944.41. As of September 30, 2010, the loan had achieved a 69.69% disbursement rate ($16,877,342.50). On November 14, 2013, China Vanguard Industry Corp agreed to assume responsibility for this $29,748,300 loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense. Project ID#66761 captures the cancelled loan commitment from CITIC Bank. Project ID#73320 captures the active loan commitment from China Vanguard Industry Corp.
Staff Comments: The purpose of the loan is assumed to be for military purposes.
Source Titles: LAPORAN PENGELOLAAN PINJAMAN DAN HIBAH PEMERINTAH

Title: CITIC Bank provides $24.2 million loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes
Description: On January 23, 2009, CITIC Bank and the Government of Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense (Kementerian Pertahanan) signed a $24,219,347.50 loan agreement for unspecified purposes. The loan, which went into effect on the same day, carried a management fee of $60,548 and an insurance premium of $1,157,944. As of mid-2010, the loan had achieved a 69.69% disbursement rate ($11,662,343).  By December 2010, the loan was fully disbursed.
Staff Comments: The Government of Indonesia loan identification number is 28703000.  The purpose of the loan is assumed to be for military purposes as the recipient is the Indonesia Ministry of Defense.
Source Titles: Laporan Perkembangan Pinjaman Luar Negeri Triwulan III Tahun 2009|Laporan Perkembangan Pinjaman Luar Negeri Dan Hibah Triwulan III Tahun 2010|Laporan Perkembangan Pinjamandan Hibah Triwulan IVTahun 2010|Laporan  Perkembangan Pinjaman Luar Negeri Dan Hibah Triwulan I Tahun 2010

Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Bank of Communications provides $42.4 million buyer’s credit loan to Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense for unspecified purposes
Description: On June 25, 2009, Bank of Communications — a Chinese state-owned bank — and the Government of Indonesia’s Ministry of Defense (Kementerian Pertahanan) signed a $42,489,802.55 buyer’s credit loan agreement [ID#2009-11911018] for unspecified purposes. The loan, which went into effect on the same day, carried a 7-year maturity, a 2-year grace period, a 5.5% interest rate, management fee of 0.90% ($382,408.22), a 0.90% commitment fee, and a 5.31% buyer’s credit insurance premium of $2,696,698.64. The first principal repayment date was August 20, 2011 and the last principal repayment date was February 20, 2016. By December 2010, the loan had achieved a 65.1% disbursement rate ($18,671,150.80).
Staff Comments: The Government of Indonesia loan identification number is 28705000. As the recipient is the Indonesia Ministry of Defense, the flow class is coded as Military.
Funding Agencies: China Bank of Communications (BoCom or BoComm)

Title: Chinese Government sends 10th peacekeeping mission to DRC - 2nd batch of 118 soldiers and military officers (Linked to Project ID#34567)
Description: On July 3, 2009, the Chinese Government dispatched the first batch of peacekeepers in the 10th Peacekeeping mission to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. This batch consisted of 218 peacekeepers from the engineering unit and medical unit (see linked project ID#34567). On July 12, 2009, the Chinese Government was scheduled to dispatch a second batch of peacekeepers. This batch consisted 118 soldiers and military officers (captured in this project, #87023). Both missions were to last for 8 months (see '??10????(?)?????????????'). They were completed on time (see 'Chinese soldiers leave for UN peace mission in DR Congo').
Source Titles: ??10????(?)?????????????|Chinese soldiers leave for UN peace mission in DR Congo
Source Publishers: Government of China|People's Daily

Title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 20.8 million military aid package
Description: In 2009, the Ministry of Defense of People’s Republic of China pledged RMB 20.8 million of military assistance to the Government of Nepal. No additional implementation details are available.
Source Titles: A brief history of Nepal-China defense ties|Assessing Nepal’s military diplomacy: Neighborhood and beyond
Source Publishers: The Annapurna Express|Unity Journal

Title: Chinese Government donates vehicles military equipment to National Training School for the Armed Forces and Gendarmerie
Description: On April 16, 2009, the Chinese Government officially delivered a donated batch of military equipment — including four 4X4 vehicles, four motorcycles and two 406s, fatigues, rangers, shoes, metal detectors, under-vehicle detectors, stun sticks, radios, flashing lights, belts, bulletproof vests, bulletproof cases, black berets and flashing lights — to the Comorian Government. Lieutenant Colonel Youssouf Idjihadi, director of the National Training School for the Armed Forces and the Gendarmerie, spoke at the handover ceremony.
Source Titles: Comores les nouvelles de la semaine

Title: Chinese government grants materials worth 8 million RMB to Ministry of Defense through Free Military Assistance Agreement
Description: On July 9, 2009, the Ministries of Defense of China and Ecuador signed a Free Military Assistance Agreement (Asistencia Military Gratuita) that granted 8 million RMB to the latter party for logistics materials.On October 29, 2009, the protocol agreement was signed, which specified the materials to be granted. These included three fuel tanks of 20,000 liters, two water tanks of 14,000 liters, two model NJC2002-100/80 purifier cars, and 1560 pieces of individual water purifier. These materials were worth the full 8 million RMB provided in the agreement. It is unknown when the materials were delivered, though the protocol agreement specifies they were to be delivered within five years of its signing.
Staff Comments: Coded intent as 'Mixed' and flow class as 'Military.' Although the materials granted seem to be more suited to development purposes, because there is no information regarding the delivery of the grant or its ultimate purpose, it cannot be confirmed that the purpose was strictly, 100% humanitarian or development related. Therefore, because the grant is to the Ministry of Defense and is framed in the agreement as 'military materials,' it has been coded with Mixed intent and Military flow class.
Source Titles: 2009A-025-JY418 ACUERDO ENTRE EL MIINISTERIO DE DEFENSA NACIONAL DE LA REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR Y EL MINISTERIO DE DEFENSA NACIONAL DE LA REPUBLICA POPULAR CHINA PARA LA ASISTENCIA MILITAR GRATUITA POR CHINA A ECUADOR
Source Publishers: Ecuador Ministry of Foreign Relations

Title: Chinese Government provides $3 million grant to Malawian Armed Forces
Description: In 2008, the Chinese Government provided a $3 million grant to the Malawian Armed Forces for defense and security purposes. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=08LILONGWE253&version=1314326040|How to Achieve Win-Win Cooperation: Remarks at the Workshop on How to Achieve Win-Win Cooperation between China and Malawi|Domestic news items from Xinhua -- March 26|http://www.malawi.gov.mw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=41:achievements-of-the-ministry-of-foreign-affairs-2004-2009&catid=2:foreign-affairs&Itemid=41
Source Publishers: |Chinese Embassy in Malawi|Xinhua News Agency|
Geographic Location: The Government of Malawi identifies the face value of the grant commitment as $2.8 million. The Chinese Government pledged a second, $3 million grant in 2009 (as captured via Project ID#25620).

Title: China grants US$ 1.5 million USD to Mozambique Armed Defense Forces
Description: On December 9, 2008 the Chinese government pledged to grant $1.5 million US dollars in 2009 to support the Mozambique Armed Defense Forces (FADM). To that end, the Mozambican Defense Minister, Filipe Nyussi, signed a cooperation agreement in Maputo on Monday with Chinese Ambassador Tian Gueng Feng to formalize the grant. China routinely donates to the the FADM which are captured in projects #754, #940, #1189, #1191, #1203, #1214, #1224, and #1245.
Source Titles: China Supports Mozambican Armed Forces|Patterns of Chinese investment, aid and trade in Mozambique
Source Publishers: All Africa| University of Stellenbosch Centre for Chinese Studies

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million interest-free loan for Okahandja Defense Academy Project (Linked to projects #53075 and #68444)
Description: On March 16, 2008, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 60 million interest-free loan to the Government of Namibia for the Okahandja Defense Academy Project. These funds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed by the two governments (see Project ID#68444). The Chinese Government also provided a supplemental RMB 10 million grant to the support this project in 2015. This project captures the interest-free loan and Project ID#53075 captures the grant. The Okahandja Defense Academy Project involved the construction of a National Defense Academy in Okahandja. The new military academy was designed to accommodate between 30 and 50 trainees per course and provide training for officers. Jiangsu Zhengtai Construction Group, a state-run Chinese company, was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in September 2011. During the construction of the company, workers reportedly faced harsh working conditions and ultimately went on strike, which led to major delays. The project was officially completed and handed over to the Namibian authorities on October 17, 2019. The Chinese project title is ?????????? or ???????????? or ???????????.
Staff Comments: Since loan terms for the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
Implementing Agencies: Jiangsu Zhengtai Construction Group Co., Ltd.
