Title: Chinese Government provides grant worth UGX 2.3 billion to Ugandan Defense Ministry for training, equipment, and IT center
Description: In November 2008, the Chinese Government and the Uganda People’s Defence Force (UPDF) signed a military grant agreement worth UGX 2.3 billion. The grant agreement was signed in Bombo, Uganda in the presence of Gen Jing Zhiyuam, the commander of the Chinese Second Artillery Force, Ugandan Permanent Secretary Rosette Byengoma, Ugandan defense state minister Ruth Nankabirwa, the UPDF chief of defense forces, Aronda Nyakairima, and other senior UPDF and Chinese military officers. The grant proceeds were to be used to train the army, buy trucks and military equipment, and build an information technology center. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: UPDF to get sh2b technology grant
Source Publishers: ISI Emerging Markets Africawire
Contact Position: State Minister of Defense|Commander|Permanent Defense Secretary

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant to support Ugandan peacekeeping mission to Somalia
Description: On December 29, 2008, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 5 million grant to the Uganda People's Defense Force to support its peacekeepers in Somalia. The Chinese Ambassador to Uganda, Sun Heping, and Uganda’s Minister for Defense, Dr Crispus Kiyonga, signed the grant agreement. The grant proceeds were earmarked for the acquisition of logistical equipment and other military equipment. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China gives Uganda 400m dollars to aid Somalia peacekeeping mission|Kiyonga, US envoy discuss Somalia
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa|New Vision
Contact Position: State Minister of Defense|Chinese ambassador to Uganda

Title: PLA donates LSL 5 million military aid package to Lesotho Defence Force
Description: On October 22, 2008, the People's Liberation Army of China and the Lesotho Defence Force (LDF) signed a military grant agreement worth LSL 5 million for unspecified purposes. The agreement was signed by the head of the Lesotho Defence Force (LDF) Lieutenant General Thuso Motanyane and Assistant Chief of General staff of the People's Liberation Army, Vice-Admiral Sun Jianguo, in Maseru. The grant proceeds were to be used to help the LDF meet some of its requirements.
Source Titles: China Assists LDF with M5 Million
Source Publishers: Lesotho
Contact Position: Lieutenant General, head of Lesotho Defence Force|Vice Admiral

Title: Chinese Government donates eight buses to the Cambodian Defense Ministry
Description: On February 6, 2008, the Chinese Ministry of Defense donated eight buses to the Cambodian Defense Ministry. The handover ceremony was attended by Gen. Moeng Samphan, state secretary of Cambodian national defence and chairman of the Committee for Aid Reception and Royal Cambodian Armed Forces [RCAF] Development, and Col. Man Zhonghe, military attache of the PRC Embassy in Cambodia.
Source Titles: Cambodia receives eight tourist buses from China
Source Publishers: Television Kampuchea

Title: Chinese Government provides six F7 fighter jets to the Sri Lankan air force
Description: In 2008, the Chinese Government reportedly donated six F7 fighter jets to the Sri Lankan air force. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
Staff Comments: AidData has not identified any official sources that corroborate multiple media reports, which claim that these jets were donated by the Chinese Government. Therefore, to avoid the possibility of over-estimating the amount of Chinese military aid provided to the Government of Sri Lanka, AidData does not record the estimated monetary value of these fighter jets in Project ID#33293.
Source Titles: Port in a storm: how Chinese billions funded Army's battle to break Tigers; Sri Lanka|A Resurgent China: South Asian Perspectives|Sri Lanka's Secrets: How the Rajapaksa Regime Gets Away with Murder|India in the New South Asia: Strategic, Military and Economic Concerns in the Age of Nuclear Diplomacy|Sri Lanka wards off Western bullying|China's aid revealed in Sri Lanka's victory parade|How Beijing won Sri Lanka's civil war

Title: Chinese Government donates eight trucks to Tongan Defense Services with $500,000
Description: On November 22, 2008, the Chinese Government donated eight trucks to Tongan Defense Services (TDS) worth $500,000. During the handover ceremony for these trucks, the Chinese Government pledged to donate an aircraft to the TDS, but it is unclear if the aircraft was ever donated.
Staff Comments: All military equipment donations are ineligible for ODA classification, outside of narrowly defined exceptions. Therefore this is coded as military and not ODA-like
Source Titles: China gifts trucks to Tongan military, promises plane|China to provide military aircraft to the Tongan Defence service.|CHINA GIVES TRUCKS, PROMISES PLANE, TO TONGA|China in the Pacific: The New Banker in Town
Source Publishers: BBCAPP|High Beam|Pacific Islands Report|Lowy Institute
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Academic Journal Article

Title: China conducts military studies for PNG defence force
Description: In 2008, PNG Defence Force and China signed agreements under which PNG would undergo military studies in China over two to three years. The agreement was signed by PNG Defence Minister Bob Dadae and his Chinese counterpart. Mr Dadae said the Taurama military hospital will be refurbished and expanded as part of the Chinese assistance. He said Chinese officials would be in PNG in June to officiate at the start of the Taurama project. Mr Dadae also secured agreement for the Chinese military to provide training for officers in technical fields. The minister, accompanied by his department head and the commander of training at Murray Barracks was taken on field trips to most military establishments in China, including one of the navy bases in Shanghai. The trip was partly sponsored by China.
Source Titles: Papua New Guineans to undertake military studies in China|PNG SIGNS MILITARY TRAINING PACT WITH CHINA
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific|PACIFIC ISLANDS REPORT
Geographic Location: Taurama

Title: Chinese Government provides USD $2 million grant to modernize Tajik armed forces
Description: In 2008, the Chinese Government pledged to provide the Government of Tajikistan with more than USD $2 million of grant funding to modernize Tajikistan's army. The grant proceeds were to be used to procure uniforms, communication equipment, and office equipment. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China gives Tajikistan over 2m dollars to modernize armed forces
Source Publishers: BBC
Geographic Location: Dushanbe

Title: Chinese Government provides military aid to Mongolia’s Ministry of Defense
Description: On August 28, 2008, China’s Ministry of Defense and Mongolia’s Ministry of Defense signed a military grant agreement. The monetary value of the grant commitment is unknown. No implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: This project potentially financed project ID#40421. This issue requires further investigation.
Source Titles: Mongolia-China defence talks to end in aid deal

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 200 million government concessional loan for Jordanian Servicemen Apartment Project (Linked to Project ID#41062)
Description: On July 30, 2004, during a state visit to China by Jordan's King Abdullah II, China's Ministry of Commerce and Jordan's Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation signed an RMB 200 million concessional loan framework agreement (see Project ID#41062). Then, on November 24, 2008, the Export-Import Bank of China (China Eximbank) and the Government of Jordan signed an RMB 200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Jordanian Servicemen Apartment Project. According to April 2018 correspondence between AidData’s Executive Director and the Public Debt Department of Jordan’s Ministry of Finance, this GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 21-year maturity (2008-2029), a 6-year maturity, and an interest rate of 2%. The period of loan repayment is March 21, 2015 and September 21, 2029. RMB 197,966,521.01 was disbursed through this loan, and as of March, 31, 2008, the Government of Jordan had repaid RMB 46,192,188. The proceeds of the loan used by the borrower to finance an EPC contract with China Gansu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (CGICOP) and China National Complete Equipment Import & Export Corporation (CNCEI). The purpose of the project was to construct 26 housing complexes — with 400 apartments — for Jordanian Armed Forces servicemen. The project site occupied a total construction area of 63,739 square meters within Zarqa Governorate. On June 6, 2009, construction began. As of November 13, 2010, 15 buildings were complete and the project had achieved a 40.2% completion rate. Then, on April 9, 2011, CGICOP entered the project’s final phase of construction. On May 3, 2012, CGICOP and CNCEI completed and transferred the project to the Jordanian Military Housing Engineering Department. The construction phase lasted 730 days. On October 27, 2014, King Abdullah II of Jordan officially opened the apartment complexes for military use. Jordanian TV news reported that the purpose of the project was to provide comfortable housing to Jordanian military service members (and reduce their travel times and financial burdens).
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Princess Iman Military Housing Project. The Chinese project title is ????????. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset published by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center in December 2020. It is recorded by Jordan’s Ministry of Finance as loan identification #EC22018.
Implementing Agencies: China Gansu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Co., Ltd. (CGICOP)|China National Complete Equipment Import & Export Corporation (CNCEI)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 18 million grant for modernization of the Nepali Army
Description: On December 7, 2008, Lieutenant General Ma Xiaotian, the deputy commander of the PLA, and Defense Minister of Nepal Ram Bahadur Thapa signed an RMB 18 million ($2.6 million) military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were earmarked for the provision of non-lethal military assistance to modernize the army of Nepal. The assistance package provided $1.45 million for the procurement of military equipment. However, it is unclear how the remaining grant funds were to be used.

Title: Poly Technologies provides $100 million supplier credit for the purchase of military equipment for Ghana Armed Forces” (Linked to Project ID#57551)
Description: On February 1, 2008, Poly Technologies — a subsidiary of China Poly Group Corporation — and the Government of Ghana signed a $100 million supplier credit agreement for the purchase of military equipment for Ghana Armed Forces. The loan agreement was approved by the Ghanaian Parliament on July 27, 2010. This supplier credit carried the following terms: 5 year maturity, 1 year grace period, and 5% interest rate. This project was completed. However, its precise date of completion is unknown. On February 1, 2008, Poly Technologies also provided $60 million supplier credit to the Government of Ghana to support a UN Peacekeeping Operation (captured in Project ID#57551).

Title: Poly Technologies provides $60 million supplier credit to Ghana Armed Forces for Supply of Peacekeeping Operation Equipment Project (Linked to Project ID#57550)
Description: On February 1, 2008, Poly Technologies — a subsidiary of China Poly Group Corporation — and the Government of Ghana signed a $60 million supplier credit agreement for the Supply of Peacekeeping Operation Equipment Project. This supplier credit carried a 5% interest rate. The purpose of the project was to facilitate the acquisition of peacekeeping operation equipment from Poly Technologies for use in Darfur, Sudan. This project was completed. However, its precise date of completion is unknown. On February 1, 2008, Poly Technologies also provided $100 million supplier credit to the Government of Ghana for the purchase of equipment (captured in Project ID#57550).

Title: Poly Technologies provides $39.8 million supplier credit for Acquisition of Two 46.8 Meter Patrol Vessels Project
Description: On September 23, 2008, Poly Technologies — a subsidiary of China Poly Group Corporation — and the Government of Ghana signed a $39,862,066.50 supplier credit agreement for the Acquisition of Two 46.8 Meter Patrol Vessels Project. This supplier credit carried the following terms: 5 year maturity, 1 year grace period, and 5.9% interest rate. The proceeds from this supplier credit were used to purchase two 46.8 meter patrol vessels from Poly Technologies for the monitoring, control and surveillance operation in the fishery waters of Ghana. The ultimate objective of this project was to enable the Ghana Navy combat and deter piracy at sea, illicit drug trafficking, dumping of toxic waste, human trafficking and illegal fishing at sea. These vessels (called “Chemle” and “Ehoo”) were ordered in 2011 and delivered to the Ghana Navy in October 2011. The vessels were then commissioned on February 20, 2012.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ??46????.

Title: PLA donates JAM$300 million worth of military equipment to Jamaica Defence Force
Description: In 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Jamaica signed a military grant agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the People's Liberation Army would provide the Jamaica Defence Force equipment worth JAM$300 million. The donated equipment was delivered on January 13, 2011. It reportedly consisted of uniforms, helmets, boots, jungle hats, backpacks, protective belts, binoculars, socks, raincoats, tents, berets, elbow and leg guards, vests, binoculars, and camouflage fabric.
Source Titles: Facebook post by On the Ground News Reports|JDF gets $300 million in military equipment from China
Source Publishers: On the Ground News Reports|Jamaica Information System
Source Type: Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: China Eximbank provides $100 million preferential buyer's credit for purchase of helicopters
Description: On December 1, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Laos signed a $100 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement (in Chinese: “???????????1???????????????”) (see ???????????????????'). This loan had previously been discussed in March 2008 at the GMS Summit in Laos (see 'China, Laos to enhance ties'). The proceeds of the PBC were reportedly earmarked for the purchase of Z-9 (Z-9A) helicopters. Two Z-9s were delivered to Laos’ Air Force on June 14, 2008. Two additional Z-9s were delivered to Laos’ Air Force in December 2008. Harbin Aircraft Industry (Group) Co., Ltd is the manufacturer of these aircraft. The proceeds from the China Eximbank PBC were likely used to purchase the Z-9 helicopters. However, AidData has not yet independently confirmed that this is indeed the case.
Staff Comments: 1. The Chinese project title is ?-9??????. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 3. Some sources suggest that the PBC proceeds may have also been used to support one or more telecommunication projects (possibly Project ID#64106). This issue requires further investigation. 4. The Harbin Z-9 is a Chinese military utility helicopter and the Z-9s purchased by the Government of Laos were evidently earmarked for use by the country's Air Force. Therefore, AidData has coded this transaction as a military project.
Implementing Agencies: Government of Laos|Harbin Aircraft Industry Group (Avic HAIG)

Title: PLA donates logistical materials, camouflage uniforms, bulletproof clothing, and disaster relief materials to Barbados Defense Force
Description: On February 27, 2008, the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) donated a batch of military supplies to the Barbados Defence Force (BDF). The donated supplies included logistical materials, camouflage uniforms, bulletproof clothing, gas masks, and other supplies. The donation was expected to help modernize the BDF and improve its capability to respond to hurricanes and other emergencies (see '????????????????????'). The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
Staff Comments: This grant is described as the 'second batch' of materials in '??????????????' and '????????????????????', though a first has not been identified.This project may have been funded by an agreement for the provision of a military grant. Both project IDs #71896 and #71894 capture military grant agreements that funded unknown projects signed prior to 2008, though no direct evidence exists to link this project to either.
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Barbados|Chinese Embassy in Barbados

Title: China holds 'Peace Angel 2009' for Gabonese Military (linked to ID#532 and ID#23566)
Description: In 2007, China and Gabon agreed to hold a joint military training on medical rescue. The training was named the 'Peace Angel' operation and the opening ceremony for the initiative was held on June 21, 2009. The training lasted 7 days and was located in Makokou, Ogooue-Ivindo Province. The training included professional development, a rescue exercise, medical aid, and the donation of equipment. The rescue exercise was specifically for Army medics and simulated a mine rescue. This also marked the first time joint military drills with the Chinese PLA, Mongolia, Singapore and Gabon were held in the history of China's international military exchanges with them. A financial amount, as well as contacts for this project are unknown. The medical aid is captured in project ID#532 and the donation of equipment to the Gabonese military is captured in project ID#23566.
Source Titles: TOWARDS A MORE SECURE WORLD|Explaining China’s Participation in Bilateral and Multilateral Military Exercises|'Peace Angel 2009' kicks off|Chinese military team to hold joint medical rescue exercise with Gabon
Source Publishers: China Daily|Institute for Regional Security||Global Times
Source Type: Media Report|Academic Journal Article|Media Report|Media Report

Description: On November 7, 2007, the Chinese Government donated ten military vehicles to the DRC's armed forces. Chinese Ambassador Wu Zexian spoke at the handover ceremony and DRC’s Defense Minister Chikez Diemu officially receiving the donation.

Title: Chinese Government donates KES 150 million to modernize Kenya Armed Forces
Description: On November 21, 2007, the Chinese Government donated KES 150 million to modernize the operations of the Kenya Armed Force. The visiting Vice-Chairman of the China’s central military commission and defense minister, General Cao Gangcuan, officially donated the money to Kenya's chief of general staff, General Jeremiah Kianga. Senior military officers were to decide where the funds would be utilized. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: In 2007, the Kenyan Government received 32 WZ-551 armored personnel carriers from China. However, it is unclear if this acquisition was funded by the Chinese Government. This issue merits further investigation.

Title: China agrees to provides assistance of US$1.5 million to boost logistical capacity of FADM
Description: On April 26, 2007, Mozambican Prime Minister Luisa Diogo received a Chinese delegation, headed by the Political Commissar of the Chinese Armed Forces, Dong Chiangyou. During the visit the Chinese delegation signed a protocol under which China agreed to provide assistance, valued at 1.5 million US dollars, to boost the logistical capacity of the Mozambican armed forces (FADM). On May 19, 2007, the Chinese ambassador to Mozambique Tiang Guafeng presented a donation of equipment worth 1.5 million USD, including seven light vehicles, 31 computers, and assorted uniforms for the Mozambican army, navy, and air force. Mozambican Defense Minister Tobias Dai attested to the donation.
Source Titles: http://www.africanews.com/site/list_message/3062|http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFNWS00020070426e34q000yj&cat=a&ep=ASE

Title: PLA provides $5.5 million grant for Camp Tubman Military Barracks Reconstruction Project
Description: On July 21, 2007, the People’s Liberation Army of China and the Government of Liberia signed a Memorandum of Understanding regarding a $5.5 million grant for the Camp Tubman Military Barracks Reconstruction Project. The purpose of the project was to renovate and expand the Camp Tubman Military Barracks in Gbarnga within Bong County (exact locational coordinates: 7.01786030744, -9.48564429847), which were expected to host the engineering battalion of the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL). The barracks occupy an area of 12 hectares and cover a floor space of 11,763 square meters. It includes a training field, parade ground, a multi-purpose building and basketball court. The project involved the rehabilitation of 12 dilapidated old buildings, the construction of 21 new buildings, and the provision of two generators, a water pump and basic furniture for 500 officers and men. Upon completion, it was envisaged that the military camp would become a comprehensive facility that could accommodate the life, training and education of more than 800 soldiers and their families. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on July 23, 2007. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on April 28, 2009.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is ????????.

Title: China donates military equipment worth 1.5 million Euros to Senegal
Description: In 2007, China donated military equipment to Senegal worth a total of 1.5 million Euros (US$2.2 million). The donation consists of trucks, ambulances, and mine-clearing equipment. Further details on the donation are unclear.
Source Titles: China Donates Military Equipment to Senegal

Title: China donates military equipment worth $1.7 million USD to Ghana
Description: In 2007, Ghana received the sum of $1.7 million USD from China for the upgrading of its defense and military equipment. It is possible that the funds were used to help finance the Defense Ministry's office complex in ID# 1497, but the status of the funding is unclear.
Source Titles: China’s Military Presence in Africa: Implications for Africa’s Wobbling Peace
Source Publishers: Journal of Asia Pacific Studies

Title: Chinese Government donates 51 military trucks to the Uganda People's Defense Force
Description: On June 5, 2007 during a handover ceremony in Bombo, the Chinese government donated 51 military trucks to the Uganda People's Defense Force (UPDF), bringing the total number donated since 2002 to 128. The Chinese ambassador, Fan Guijin, handed the trucks over to the UPDF. The trucks are to be used to improve security and maintain peace and security in the country. The total worth of this donation is unknown.
Source Titles: http://allafrica.com/stories/200706060410.html|China donates 51 military trucks to UPDF
Source Publishers: |New Vision

Title: Chinese Government pledges technical assistance to Mozambique’s military
Description: The Chief of General Staff of Mozambique, General Lagos Lidimo, traveled to China from June 27 to July 2, 2007. During this visit, he met with China's General Liang Guang Lie to talk about strengthening the military cooperation between the two countries. They signed a Memorandum of Technical Assistance that focused on bilateral cooperation between the two military bodies.
Source Titles: Chief of General Staff visited the People's Republic of China

Title: RMB 280,000,000 China Eximbank bank concessional loan in 2007 for the purchase of two MA-60 aircraft
Description: In December 2007, China Eximbank and the Government of Bolivia signed an RMB  279,875,675 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL 2007 (13) 184] for the purchase of two Chinese MA-60 planes. This GCL carried the following terms: 20 year maturity and 2% interest rate. The acquisition of two MA-60 aircraft aims was designed to satisfy the public demand for aerial transport. The commander of the Bolivian Air Force (FAB), Gen. Luis Trigo, said the purchase of the two MA-60 aircraft would also strengthen Bolivia's military aerial transportation. Each MA-60 aircraft has a capacity of about 60 people. China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC) was the contractor. The planes arrived in Bolivia on February 21, 2008.
Staff Comments: The Spanish project title is 'Compra de dos Aeronaves MA-60.'

Title: Chinese Government donates 34 trucks, 5 passenger cars, and 3 off-road vehicles worth $1.07 million to Bolivian Armed Forces
Description: On September 10, 2007, the Chinese Government donated 34 military trucks, 5 passenger cars, and 3 off-road vehicles to the Bolivian Armed Forces. The estimated monetary value of this donation is $1,074,000. This donation was intended to promote greater cooperation among Armed Forces of both countries.
Staff Comments: 1. The grant was issued under the framework of the Bilateral Cooperation Protocol (Protocolo de Cooperación Bilateral) between the Bolivian and Chinese Ministries of Defense (see BOLIVIA Y CHINA AMPLIAN CONVENIO DE COOPERACION TECNICO MILITAR). Other projects also executed under the same framework include Project ID#38873 and ID#35988). 2. The estimated value of the grant commitment for this project is based on a disclosure by the Bolivian Defense Minister Reymi Ferreira that the Government of Bolivia received military assistance from the Chinese Government worth $1,074,000 in 2007.
Implementing Agencies: Bolivia Ministry of Defense |China Ministry of Defense

Title: Chinese Government donates batch of equipment worth $600,000 to Surinamese National Army
Description: In July 2007, the Chinese Government donated three military vehicles, two tractors, one ambulance, electronics and medical supplies and equipment to the Surinamese National Army. The estimated monetary value of the donation was $600,000.
Source Titles: China donates military equipment to Surinam|China donates vehicles to Surinamese army
Source Publishers: BBC|Caribbean Net News
Contact Position: Chinese Ambassador to Suriname|Army Commander|Defense Minister

Title: China gives scholarships to Cambodian soldiers
Description: On August 31, 2011, 60 Cambodian soldiers left for China for military training. They were given scholarships by the Chinese government to study in different schools from different provinces on areas such as anti-terrorism, infantry, computers, Chinese language, navy, airplane repairing, tank and artillery.
Source Titles: 60 Cambodian soldiers with scholarships leave for China for training|Annual Development Review 2010-11
Source Publishers: Xinhua News Agency|Cambodia Development Resource Institute

Title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 4 million grant for acquisition of equipment to strengthen border protection
Description: In November 2007, the Chinese Government announced that it would provide an RMB 4 million military grant to the Kyrgyz Border Service to facilitate the acquisition of communications equipment, computer equipment and other equipment to strengthen the protection of the state border. The donation was expected to be disbursed by the end of November 2007. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Kyrgyzstan to get 0.5m dollars worth of Chinese military aid|Kyrgyzstan to get 0.5m dollars worth of Chinese military aid
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia|BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific

Title: Chinese Government donates 10 cars and 3 ambulances worth RMB 5 million to the Belarusian Ministry of National Defense
Description: On April 23, 2007, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense agreed to donate 10 cars and 3 ambulances worth RMB 5 million to the Belarusian Ministry of National Defense. Then, on August 21, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense officially handed over the vehicles to the Government of Belarus.
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Belarus

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 3 million military grant for unspecified purposes
Description: On December 20, 2007, the Chinese Government provided a military grant worth RMB 3 million to the Government of Papua New Guinea. No further implementation details are available.

Title: Chinese Government provides $3 million loan for acquisition of precision equipment and uniforms for officers and soldiers
Description: According to multiple sources, in 2007, the Chinese Government provided a $3 million loan to the Government of Turkmenistan to facilitate the acquisition of precision equipment for the Turkmen army and uniforms for its officers and soldiers. No additional implementation details are available.

Title: Chinese Government donates 500 military tents to Burundian army
Description: On December 6, 2006, Burundi's first vice-president of the republic, Dr Martin Nduwimana, met with the Chinese National Defense Ministry, Major-General Ding Jingong. During the meeting, the Chinese ambassador to Burundi announced that an earlier request by the Burundian President for a Chinese donation of 500 military tents for the Burundian army had been approved. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
Source Titles: Burundi: China donates military tents to army
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa

Title: Chinese Government pledges patrol boats
Description: In 2006, Nigerian security sources said Nigeria would receive new defense supplies from China would include dozens of patrol boats to secure the swamps and creeks that form the launching pad for rebel attacks. Analysts say Nigeria wants 200 boats to guard the Delta. The status of the supplies is uncertain.
Source Titles: FT.com site : Nigeria turns to China for defence aid.
Source Publishers: Financial Times (FT.Com)

Title: Chinese Government donates patrol vessel to Sierra Leone Armed Forces
Description: On March 10, 2006, the Chinese Government donated a Type 62-1 Class Military Patrol Boat (Shanghai class III NATO designation) to the maritime wing of the Sierra Leone Armed Forces. Sierra Leonean President, Alhaji Dr. Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, and Chinese Ambassador to Sierra Leone, Cheng Wenju, attended the handover ceremony. The exact monetary value of the boat (known as the Sir Milton PB 105 ) is unknown. However, its estimated cost cost is $12.5 million. The stated purpose of the donation was to increase defensive capacity of the Sierra Leone Armed Forces within their capacity, and help them safeguard the coastline, maritime resources, and fishery production. Some sources indicate that, as part of a larger aid package, the Chinese Government also provided two water bowers and spare parts, UHF and VHF communication equipment, a training package for the maritime wing personnel, and residential apartments at the Kingtom naval wing facility.
Staff Comments: AidData has estimated the value of the grant commitment that supported this project by estimating the unit cost ($12.5 million) of a Type 62 Class Military Patrol Boat (based on the information provided in this source: https://jamestown.org/program/chinas-inroads-into-east-timor/)
Receiving Agencies: Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces (RSLAF)
Source Titles: China, Sierra Leone sign military training agreement|China donates military equipment to Sierra Leone|The Rise and Fall of the Sierra Leone Navy  and the UK’s role in its downfall|First report of the Secretary-General on the United Nations Integrated Office in Sierra Leone

Title: People's Liberation Army of China lead Military training at Zimbabwe Staff College
Description: The People's Liberation Army in China has sent a team of PLA military instructors to teach at the Zimbabwe Staff College. At the college they train civilians and officers from Zimbabwe, Botswana, Tanzania, Malawi, Zambia, Namibia, Lesotho, and Mozambique. The exact implementation dates of this project are unknown.Information regarding amounts, dates of implementation are yet to be found. Continued assistance shown in Project #19939.
Staff Comments: The commitment year has been recorded at 2006 as that is the earliest known date, however more research is required to confirm this.

Title: China donates construction equipment to Zimbabwe Defense Force
Description: On May 4, 2006, the Chinese handed over construction equipment to the Zimbabwe Defense Forces (ZDF). The equipment included brick making machines, bricklayers, plaster, carpenter and electrician tool kits, and surveying gear. The equipment totaled a $1.5 million US dollar gift from the Chinese government. The tools would be used to help build housing for the Pomona Barracks in Harare. The gift also cut down on the costs of renting equipment and transporting the rentals.

Title: China to provide military materials, training to Zimbabwe
Description: On July 31, 2006, the military forces of Zimbabwe signed a cooperation agreement with the Chinese People's Liberation Army for assistance in military materials and personnel training. Specifically, the Zimbabwean Defense Forces will send 55 officers to China to receive military and technical training during 2006 and 2007. The Zimbabwe Defense Forces were represented by General Constantine Chiwenga and the Chinese government was represented by the military attache of the Chinese Embassy in Zimbabwe, Tian Jianjun.
Implementing Agencies: People's Liberation Army of China|Zimbabwe Defence Forces (ZDF)
Source Titles: China to provide military materials, training to Zimbabwe|http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020060801e2810008e&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific|

Title: Chinese Government donates generators, vehicles, computers, and communication equipment worth RMB 5 million to Ministry of Defense of Liberia
Description: In April 2006, Chinese Major General Zhang Bangdong disclosed that his government was making an RMB 5 million grant available to the Liberian Defense Ministry. The proceeds of the grant were to be used to acquire three Toyota pick-up trucks, 36 laptops, 42 radio hand sets, 2 base radios, and other equipment. The equipment package was expected to take roughly 55 days to arrive in the country.  On September 19, 2006, the Chinese Government officially delivered the donated equipment — including two generators, three vehicles, 48 sets of computers, and several communication gadgets — to the Ministry of Defense of Liberia. Chinese Ambassador, Lin Songtian, and Liberia’s Defense Minister, Brownie Samukai attended the handover ceremony.

Title: Chinese Government pledges loan for purchase of Chinese J-10 fighters
Description: In April 2006 the Pakistani government decided to purchase a number of Chinese J-10 fighters. The acquisition was part of a bigger purchase totalling 98 fighter aircraft, including F-16s from US and 800 Beyond Visual Range (BVR) missiles. The acquisitions had been approved in April 2006 in a cabinet meeting headed by Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz. The expenditure on the entire package would be met from PAF share in Armed Forces Development Programme, and the Cabinet has allowed PAF to set up Joint Working Group to purchase J-10s with a long-term credit financing from the Chinese government. It was reported that the J-10 has been offered to Pakistan only for export. Pakistan will receive the first export versions of the J-10, up to 36 aircraft, by 2015.

Title: Chinese Embassy donates sports equipment to the Pakistan Navy
Description: On January 20, 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan donated treadmills, exercise equipment and others to the Pakistan Navy during a ceremony held at the sports stadium in the Pakistan Navy Headquarters. Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang and Pakistan Navy Headquarters Major General Khalid signed the donation handover letter. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
Source Publishers: Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Islamic Republic of Pakistan

Title: PLA units complete anti-terrorist training with Tajik forces
Description: On September 22, 2006, the first joint anti-terrorism exercise between the Chinese and Tajik military forces began. The training will last for 2 days and include two stages. The first stage is 'command-post exercise,' which includes the 'establishment of a joint structure command, analysis and judgment of the situation, determination of joint counter-terrorism operations, and organization of operational coordination.' The second stage is the actual military exercise, which includes the capture and elimination of the terrorist group. On the Chinese side, over 150 people attended the training, and 300 people from the Tajik military forces attended. The exercise was conducted in accordance with the Memorandum on joint anti-terrorism exercises, signed by the defense ministers of China and Tajikistan in Beijing in April 2006.This marks the first time that regular units of the People's Liberation Army of China (PLA) traveled and participated in joint training exercises with foreign troops.
Source Titles: China and Tajikistan conducted a joint anti-terrorist exercises 'Interaction-2006'|?????????? ???????????
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan|????

Title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 15 million grant to Tajik Army for training of army officers and material and technical support
Description: During the Tajik Defense Minister's visit to China in 2006, the Chinese government pledged a grant of RMB 15 million to Tajikistan's Ministry of Defense to benefit the Tajik Army. The grant was to be used for training courses for army officers as well as material and technical support. It is not clear whether or when this pledge was fulfilled.
Source Titles: China allocates about 2m dollars to Tajik army
Source Publishers: BBC
Geographic Location: Dushanbe

Title: Chinese Government provides $3.27 million grant for training of Afghan Army
Description: According to the Development Assistance Database (DAD) maintained by the Government of Afghanistan’s Ministry of Finance, the Chinese Government disbursed $3.27 million for the training of the Afghan Army between March 21, 2006 and December 20, 2010.
Staff Comments: 1. DAD Platform referral code: DAD/002439. 2. Nearly all of the international assistance provided to the Government of Afghanistan is donated rather than lent, so AidData has flow-coded this transaction as a Grant.

Title: China Eximbank provides $55.5 million loan for MA-60 and Y-12 Cargo Aircraft Acquisition Project
Description: In 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Zambia signed a $55,500,000 loan agreement for the MA-60 and Y-12 Cargo Aircraft Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this loan were used to acquire two MA-60 airliners and twelve Y-12 cargo planes.  China Aviation Industry Corporation II (AVIC II) was the contractor responsible for the acquisition and delivery of the planes. These aircraft were successfully delivered in an official handover ceremony on August 19, 2006. Secretary to Zambian Cabinet Joshua Kanganja attended the handover ceremony.
Implementing Agencies: China Aviation Industry Corporation II (AVIC II)

Title: China donates bulldozers and road graders valued at 10 million yuan to the Philippines' military in 2006
Description: On January 23, 2006, a handover ceremony was held for the donation of the first batch of military engineering equipment to the Philippines. The donation included 6 bulldozers and 6 graders, worth 10 million yuan, and will be used for 'used for infrastructure construction and military development,' according to the Chinese Embassy. The handover ceremony was attended by the Chinese Ambassador, Li Jinjun, the Minister of Defense for the Philippines, Cruz, as well as several Filipino military officers. This project is completed.

Title: Chinese Government donates military assistance to Antigua and Barbuda Defense Force
Description: On November 15, 2006, the Chinese Embassy and the Antigua and Barbuda Defense Force held a military assistance handover ceremony. Chinese Ambassador Ren Xioaping and Colonel Thomas signed the handover certificate. The equipment included printers, among other things (See: '??????????????????????????'). The monetary value of this aid is unknown.
Source Publishers: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China

Title: PLA provides military grant to strengthen the logistical capabilities of Barbados Defence Force
Description: During a visit from August 3-6, 2006, representatives from the Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) and the Barbados Defense Force (BDF) signed a military grant agreement to strengthen the BDF's logistical capabilities. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Summary of China-Barbados Bilateral Relations|??????????????

Title: “Chinese Government donates equipment to create 5,000 military uniforms to Madagascar's Ministry of Defense
Description: On August 22, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Madagascar signed a military aid agreement. Then, on September 13, 2006, the Chinese Government officially delivered a batch of military equipment to Madagascar's Ministry of Defense headquarters in Ampahibe. The donation was mainly fabric, enough to make 5,000 military uniforms, and equipment for use by the Malagasy army, including 23 km of jungle green military fabric, 300 army rangers boots, and a 20-watt radio. The donation was officially handed over to Madagascar's Minister of National Defense.
Staff Comments: The French project title is Don de matériel militaire.

Title: CATIC provides $150 million supplier credit for 12 K-8 Jet Trainer Aircraft Acquisition Project
Description: In 2006, China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) — a Chinese state-owned company reportedly provided a $150 million supplier credit to the Government of Zimbabwe for the 12 K-8 Jet Trainer Aircraft Acquisition Project. This project supported the acquisition of twelve K-8 jet aircraft by Zimbabwe’s Ministry of Defense from Nanchang Aircraft Manufacturing Company (NAMC). Permanent Secretary of the Zimbabwean Ministry of Defence, Trust Maphosa, accompanied by army commander, General Constantine Chiwenga, and Airforce of Zimbabwe Chief Air Marshall, Perence Shiri, stated during a hearing of the joint Senate and House of Assembly Parliamentary portfolio committee on defence and home affairs that six K-8 training jets had already arrived in the country by March 2006 and that the remainder were to be delivered by the end of 2006. The price of each jet was estimated to range between $10 and $20 million depending on the precise specifications. The K-8 is primarily a training aircraft but has reconnaissance capabilities and can be fitted out as a light attack platform.

Title: Chinese government grants 6 million RMB to Ministry of Defense through Free Military Assistance Agreement (March 2006)
Description: On March 21, 2006, the Ministries of Defense of China and Ecuador signed a Free Military Assistance Agreement (Asistencia Military Gratuita) that granted 6 million RMB to the latter party for logistics materials. It is unknown what projects or pieces of equipment were eventually purchased with this grant, which were to be confirmed via the signing of protocol agreement at a later date.
Staff Comments: The project is not marked as umbrella as there are no sub-projects captured and there are no risk of duplication.

Title: Chinese Government donates tractors, army fatigues, and communications equipment to CAR Army
Description: In 2005, the President of the  Central African Republic (CAR), the CAR Defense Minister, Francois Bozize, and He Siji, China's Ambassador to the CAR signed a military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire tractors, army fatigues, logistical resources, and communications equipment on behalf of the CAR Army. No further implementation details are available.
Receiving Agencies: Government of the Central African Republic

Title: Chinese Government funds construction of military installation
Description: According to the Wall Street Journal, China funded the construction of a military installation in Ethiopia in early 2005. Nor further details are available.
Staff Comments: In a potentially related incident on April 24, 2007, over 200 gunmen of the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) attacked a Chinese-run oil field in Abole, Ethiopia. Seventy-four people were killed including nine Chinese and 65 Ethiopians, in a raid claimed by the ONLF separatist rebel group on their website. The exploration facility of the Zhongyuan Petroleum Exploration Bureau of the China Petroleum & Chemical Corporation was completely destroyed. Seven Chinese workers were also kidnapped and then released unharmed five days later on April 29, 2007.

Title: China grants US$7 million and builds officer housing for Mozambique Armed Defense Forces
Description: In 2005, the Chinese worked to build houses for the officers of Forças Armadas de Defesa de Moçambique (FADM), the military organization in Mozambique. The housing projects were built in Magoanine, a suburb of Maputo, Mozambique. An additional source reported the value of military housing provided to Mozambique at about US$7 million. The amount of housing and exact dates including completion have yet to be determined.
Source Titles: http://www.cifor.org/publications/pdf_files/WPapers/WP93German.pdf|Heading for China
Source Publishers: |The Indian Ocean Newsletter
Geographic Location: Magoanine

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million for capacity building of Liberian Army
Description: On April 14, 2005 the Chinese Government agreed to provided RMB 5 million of grant funding to assist with capacity-building of the Liberian Army. He Meng, the second secretary at the Chinese embassy in Monrovia, said that the grant proceeds would be earmarked for the acquisition of materials and logistics. However, the diplomat also said that the details of the agreement would be worked out at a later date. Then, in 2006, a report stated 22 Liberian VIP protection personnel and 8 medics and logisticians of the Liberian Army were undergoing training in China.
Source Titles: China pledges aid for Liberian army 'capacity-building'|Africa Focus: Liberia-China ties grow steadily and stronger: Liberian President
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific|Xinhua News Agency

Title: Chinese Government provides 2 fighter jets in compensation for fishing rights
Description: According to the Wall Street Journal, in 2005, the Chinese Government gave 2 fighter jets to the Government of Mauritania as partial compensation for fishing rights. AidData has not corroborated this transaction with any independent sources. The monetary value of each jet is unknown.
Source Titles: Offshore Disturbance: Global Fishing Trade Depletes African Waters --- Poor Nations Get Cash, The Rich Send Trawlers; A Dearth of Octopus| Global Fishing Trade Depletes African Waters
Source Publishers: The Wall Street Journal'License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service [http://www.djreprints.com/link/DJRFactiva.html?FACTIVA=wjco20070718000097]|Washington Street Journal

Title: Chinese Government donates 40 troop-carrying vehicles and 15 pick-up trucks worth $2 million to Ghana’s Defense Ministry
Description: On February 7, 2005, the Chinese Ambassador to Ghana, Zhang Keyuan, donated 55 vehicles to the Ghanaian Ministry of Defense in Accra. The donation consisted of 40 troop-carrying vehicles and 15 pick-up trucks.
Staff Comments: This project is linked to project ID#1449, although it is uncertain how the two are connected.
Source Titles: Ghana: China donates 55 vehicles to Defence Ministry|Defence Ministry to get Vehicles from China
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa|ModernGhana
Geographic Location: Ghana Armed Forces/Ministry of Defence, Accra, Ghana

Title: Chinese Government provides technical assistance for radio jamming and  equipment ahead of 2005 elections (linked to #18302)
Description: In January 2005, the Chinese Government has reportedly provided technical assistance to the Government of Zimbabwe on the use of radio jamming equipment by sending intelligence officers to Harare to provide training in telecommunications and radio communications (See: 'State Sabotage' of Radio Station's Broadcasts).  This agreement was devised under technical cooperation accords signed between the two countries (See: 'State Sabotage' of Radio Station's Broadcasts).  Several media reports also indicate that the Chinese Government has also helped the Zimbabwean authorities censor certain websites by monitoring internet traffic. This technical assistance was reported by media articles, and could not be verified by official sources. This project is linked to project #18302, which records the Chinese Government's reported donation of military-strength radio jamming equipment to be used ahead of the Zimbabwean election later in 2005.
Source Titles: http://www.journalism.co.za/index.php/news-and-insight/insight/166-media-freedom3/768-china-grows-its-role-in-africas-media.html|'State Sabotage' of Radio Station's Broadcasts
Geographic Location: Harare

Title: Chinese Government provides radio jamming and internet surveillance equipment ahead of 2005 elections (linked to project #18290)
Description: In 2005, the Chinese Government reportedly donated military-strength radio jamming equipment, which helped the Government of Zimbabwe block opposition broadcasts ahead of the country’s 2005 elections (See: Can China Save Zimbabwe’s Economy?). The equipment was installed at Thornhill Airbase (See: State Jamming Radio Signals From UK).  The Chinese Government also reportedly donated internet surveillance equipment. The value of this donation is unknown. This donation was reported by media articles, and could not be confirmed by official sources.This project is linked to project #18290, which captures the Chinese Government's reported provision of technical assistance to the Government of Zimbabwe on the use of radio jamming equipment by sending intelligence officers to Harare to provide training in telecommunications and radio communications.
Receiving Agencies: Government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe Internet Service Providers Association

Description: In 2005, the Chinese Government donated 39 military trucks, educational and medical equipment worth $3 million to the Armed Forces of Zimbabwe. No further implementation details are available.

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 333.33 million grant for acquisition of 6 naval patrol boats (Linked to Project ID#67969)
Description: On January 19, 2005, an Inter-Ministerial Working Group composed of four members — HE Uk Rabun, Secretary of State of the Ministry of Economy and Finance, as chairman; Lt. General Ung Samkhan, Commander-in-Chief of the Navy, as vice-chairman; HE Chea Vandeth, Cabinet Chief and Advisor to Deputy Prime Minister Sok An; and, Por Yutha, Chief of Bilateral Cooperation Office at the Ministry of Economy and Finance — convened to discuss the possibility of acquiring naval patrol ships from China. The Chinese Government subsequently provided a grant worth approximately RMB 333.33 million to the Royal Armed Forces of Cambodia (RAFC) for the acquisition of 6 naval patrol boats. The boats were expected to be used by the RAFC to help its navy branch counter crimes like smuggling, drug trafficking, illegal immigration, piracy and terrorism. Another purpose of the project was to safeguard oil and gas installations in the Gulf of Thailand. At the time that the grant was issued, Sihanoukville — Cambodia's only deep-sea port — was expected to become a processing center for oil and natural gas from its 'Block A' chunk in the Gulf of Thailand.  CSSC was the contractor responsible for implementation. The vessels were officially delivered at a handover ceremony that took place on September 1, 2005. In 2005, China Eximbank also provided a loan to the Government of Cambodia for the acquisition of nine additional naval patrol vessels (as captured via Project ID#67969).
Staff Comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 6????. 2. In 2005, the Cambodian Government used the proceeds of a China Eximbank loan worth RMB 500 million to purchase 9 naval patrol boats from CSSC (as captured via Project ID#67969), which implies that the unit cost of a CSSC naval patrol boat is RMB 55.55 million. Therefore, AidData estimates the value of the grant commitment that supported this project as RMB 333.33 million (RMB 55.55 million x 6).

Title: Chinese Government donates 18 truckloads of weapons and explosives to Royal Nepalese Army (Linked to Project ID#34362 and 34366)
Description: Soon after a coup d'état occurred on February 1, 2005, the Chinese Government pledged military assistance worth $989,000 to help the government fight a Maoist insurgency. Then, in November 2005, the Chinese Government sent eighteen truckloads of military aid to the Royal Nepalese Army, consisting of weapons and explosives. The aid was meant to assist the government in fighting a Maoist revolt.
Staff Comments: A coup d'état occurred on February 1, 2005 when King Gyanendra declared a state of emergency and dissolved the parliament of Nepal. Members of parliament were put under house arrest, and “key constitutional rights were suspended, soldiers enforced complete censorship, and communications were cut”. The coup was condemned by India, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The king's rule lasted for over a year, until April 24, 2006, when the king agreed to give up absolute power and to reinstate the dissolved House of Representatives, following the Loktantra Andolan movement.

Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report

Title: Chinese Government donates 5 armored combat vehicles to Nepal (Linked to Project ID#34359 and #34362)
Description: Soon after a coup d'état occurred on February 1, 2005, the Chinese Government pledged military assistance worth $989,000 to help the government fight a Maoist insurgency. Then, in June 2005, the Chinese Government donated five armored combat vehicles — each able to carry 10 individuals — to the Government of Nepal to support its fight against Maoist rebels.
Staff Comments: “A coup d'état occurred on February 1, 2005 when King Gyanendra declared a state of emergency and dissolved the parliament of Nepal. Members of parliament were put under house arrest, and “key constitutional rights were suspended, soldiers enforced complete censorship, and communications were cut”. The coup was condemned by India, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The king's rule lasted for over a year, until April 24, 2006, when the king agreed to give up absolute power and to reinstate the dissolved House of Representatives, following the Loktantra Andolan movement.

Title: Chinese Government pledges $2 million grant for military equipment and training
Description: On October 23, 2005, it was reported that the Chinese Government would provide the Afghan Defense Ministry with a batch of military equipment worth $2 million and training for Afghan military personnel. This would probably be the first time that China provide military assistance to the Afghanistan; before March 2005, there was no records of China providing military assistance to the country. As of June 2006, the Chinese Government had not yet fulfilled the pledge that it made in 2005. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China to provide Afghanistan with defence equipment worth 2m dollars|China to train Afghan soldiers on logistics|AFGHANISTAN SECURITY Efforts to Establish Army and Police Have Made Progress, but Future Plans Need to Be Better Defined
Source Publishers: |Pajhwok Afghan News|United States Government Accountability Office

Title: Chinese Government provides $750 million loan for acquisition of four F-22P frigates (warships) and and six Z-9c helicopters
Description: In 2003, Pakistan initiated negotiations with China for four frigates (warships). Then, at the 2004 International Defence Exhibition and Seminar (IDEAS), the Chinese side revealed a design for the F-22P frigate that it had proposed to Pakistan’s Navy. The proposed F-22P was a variant of the Type 053H3, but with a heavily reworked superstructure with reduced radar cross-section (RCS) design elements. The Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan reportedly negotiated a $750 million loan non-commercial (i.e. low-cost) terms for the joint manufacture of the warships in September 2004. Pakistan’s Chief of Naval Staff (CNS), Admiral Shahid Karimullah, said negotiations were in the “final stages” in December 2004. Then, in October 2005, Pakistan’s Ministry of Defence Production and China Shipbuilding and Trading Company signed a framework agreement for the supply of four F22P frigates (warships) and six Z-9c helicopters with Transfer of Technology (TOT) for use by Pakistan’s Navy. The manufacturing cost of each F22P Frigate — an improved version of China’s original Type 053H3 Frigate — was $175 million. The parties signed a commercial contract in May 2006. A project commencement (‘launching’) ceremony took place on July 4, 2005 and it was attended by the chief of Pakistan Navy, Admiral Shahid Karimullah and senior officials from China's People Liberation Army.  The first Chinese-built F-22 frigate, named PNS Zulfiqar (Arabic for sword), was delivered to Pakistan on July 30, 2009. The second, PNS Shamsheer was handed over on January 23, 2010. The third frigate, PNS Saif, was commissioned on September 15, 2011. The fourth frigate, PNS Aslat, was commissioned on April 17, 2013. The original deal was later expanded to support the construction and acquisition of eight F22P frigates from the Hudong Zhonghua shipyard in Shanghai, China, and Karachi shipyard and Engineering Works (KSEW), Pakistan. In addition to building eight frigates, the Sino-Pakistan defense deal included the upgrading of the Karachi dockyard for indigenous production of a modern surface fleet. The Pakistan Navy describes the F-22P frigate as a Sword Class ship that is equipped with long-range surface-to-surface missiles (SSM) and surface-to-air missiles (SAM), depth charges, torpedoes, the latest 76mm guns, a close-in-weapons system (CIWS), sensors, electronic warfare and an advanced command and control system. The ship has a displacement of 3,000 tons and carries anti-submarine Z9EC helicopters. Although the Pakistan Navy already possessed Sea-King helicopters for anti-submarine operations, it acquired Chinese Z9ECs to enhance its operational capabilities.
Receiving Agencies: Karachi Shipyard and Engineering Works Ltd.
Implementing Agencies: China Shipbuilding Trading Company (CSTC)|Karachi Shipyard and Engineering Works Ltd.

Title: Chinese Government donates various types of equipment to Ecuador’s Ministry of Defense
Description: In 2005, the Chinese Government reportedly donated 12,000 military uniforms, 2 planes, 9 dump trucks, 1 loader, and several stashes of weapons and ammunition to the Ministry of Defense of Ecuador. However, after a complaint was filed by the Commission for the Civic Control of Corruption about alleged customs declaration irregularities, the donation was blocked and the shipments were impounded in Guayaquil port. The donation was subsequently accepted by the Government of Ecuador and the country’s Minister of Defense, Solón Espinosa, insisted that no weapons or ammunition were included in the donation.
Staff Comments: 1. The Spanish project title is Dos aviones, nueve volquetas, un cargador y 12.000 uniformes militares. 2. The anti-corruption effort surrounding this donation followed the dismissal of the President’s brother (Gilmar Gutiérrez) from his position in the Congress (as a Deputy), where he allegedly embezzled Chinese Government grant funding for the acquisition of sports equipment (as captured via Project ID#37812).

Title: Chinese Government commits to provide RMB 16 million grant to Kazakh armed forces
Description: On September 16, 2005, the Chinese Government and Kazakhstan's Armed Forces signed a military grant agreement. The sides signed 'an agreement on the provision by the Chinese side of no-strings military aid to Kazakhstan's armed forces and an executive protocol to an agreement concluded earlier in 2004 worth 16m yuan [about 1.98m dollars]', says a press release circulated by the Kazakh Defence Ministry's press service.
Staff Comments: It is unclear how exactly this is related to the 2004 commitment of 1 million USD to Kazakhstan's armed forces (Project ID #40098).
Source Titles: Kazakh, Chinese defence ministers sign aid agreement
Source Publishers: BBC

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense donates border patrol equipment worth RMB 2 million
Description: Following the signing of a technical assistance agreement with the Tajik military, the Chinese National Defense Ministry donated a batch of border patrol equipment worth RMB 2 million to the Tajik State Border Protection Committee.

Title: China signs agreement for military assistance for Albania Military
Description: On 28 March 2005, The People's Republic of China has agreed to give support to Albania in the military and defense fields. The meeting was followed by the ceremony for the signing of an agreement, which provides for [Chinese] assistance in military training, military technology and logistics, and medicines. It is the first time that such an agreement on support for the Albanian Army is signed with the People's Republic of China. The agreement was signed by the head of the Chinese delegation and Nikolla Nosi, director of the defense and integration policy department in the Defence Ministry.
Source Titles: China, Albania sign agreement on military assistance
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring European
Contact Position: Chinese Foreign Relations Chief in Defense Ministry of the People's Republic of China

Title: China commits to 3 million RMB of military equipment to the Moldovan National Army
Description: On November 17, 2005, during the visit of the Moldovan Minister of Defense, Valeriu Plesca, to China, China committed to donating military equipment worth over 3 million RMB (roughly 370,000 USD) to the National Army of Moldova. The equipment will be donated under the Technical Assistance Agreement, signed earlier during the same visit.

Title: Chinese Government provides $2.7 million grant for Military Officers’ Residence and Club Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#57876)
Description: On November 18, 2005, the Chinese Government provided a $2.7 million grant to the Government of Guinea-Bissau for the Military Officers’ Club Renovation Project. The grant agreement was signed by Guinea-Bissau’s Foreign Affairs Minister, Isaac Monteiro, and by China’s Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister. The estimated monetary value of the grant commitment is $1.5 million. The project involved the refurbishment of a Military Officer’s Residence and Club in the city of Bissau. Hainan Provincial Construction Engineering Group (??????????) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Project implementation commenced in September 2006 and the project was originally expected to reach completion by the end of 2007. However, the project was ultimately completed and handed over to the local authorities on June 4, 2008.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Armed Forces Residence and Club Refurbishment Project and the Refurbishing of Barracks and Officer’s Mess at Bissau General Headquarters Project. The Chinese project title is ??????? or ???????????? or ??????????????????????. The Portuguese project title is Residências para os oficiais das Forcas Armadas.

Title: PLA donates defense equipment worth VT 32.8 million to Vanuatu Mobile Force
Description: On August 2, 2005, the People’s Liberation Army of China agreed to provide more than VT 32.8 million (about $292,000) for defense equipment to the Vanuatu Mobile Force (VMF).  Two agreements were signed by the head of the People's Liberation Army, General Cao Gang Chuan, and Vanuatu Minister of Police George Wells. The donated equipment included uniforms and equipment for the VMF and the provision of a 28-seat Toyota bus to transport VMF members to their external activities, and three double cabin Hilux for police patrols and a sedan for the police traffic control section. Also, two boats were to be provided as requested for coastal surveillance operations against activities of illegal immigrants on foreign sailing boats, illegal fishing in the 12-nautical-mile exclusive zone, and other surveillance activities (that the only national patrol boat RVS Tukoro wouldn't be able to undertake because of the high cost of its operations).
Source Titles: VANUATU RECEIVES DEFENSE SUPPORT FROM CHINA|The Dragon Looks South
Source Publishers: Pacific Islands Report|Lowy Institute

Title: China Eximbank provides RMB 500 million government concessional loan for Naval Patrol Craft Acquisition Project (linked to project ID#32092)
Description: On January 19, 2005, an Inter-Ministerial Working Group composed of four members — HE Uk Rabun, Secretary of State of the Ministry of Economy and Finance, as chairman; Lt. General Ung Samkhan, Commander-in-Chief of the Navy, as vice-chairman; HE Chea Vandeth, Cabinet Chief and Advisor to Deputy Prime Minister Sok An; and, Por Yutha, Chief of Bilateral Cooperation Office at the Ministry of Economy and Finance — convened to discuss the possibility of acquiring naval patrol ships from China. Then, on July 4, 2005, China Eximbank and the Royal Armed Forces of Cambodia signed an RMB 500 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Naval Patrol Craft Acquisition Project. The loan carried the following terms:  a 20-year maturity, a 1.75% interest rate, and a 10-year grace period. The proceeds of the loan were used by the borrower to finance a commercial contract with China State Shipbuilding Corporation (CSSC), which was signed in December 2005.  The purpose of the project was to facilitate  the acquisition of 9 naval patrol boats. The boats were expected to be used by the Royal Armed Forces of Cambodia (RAFC) to help its navy branch counter crimes like smuggling, drug trafficking, illegal immigration, piracy and terrorism. Another purpose of the project was to safeguard oil and gas installations in the Gulf of Thailand. At the time that the loan was issued, Sihanoukville — Cambodia's only deep-sea port — was expected to become a processing center for oil and natural gas from its 'Block A' chunk in the Gulf of Thailand.  CSSC was the contractor responsible for implementation. On July 12, 2005, work on approximately seven naval vessels had already commenced in a Chinese warship factory. On November 7, 2007, CSSC delivered four 46 meter patrol boats, three 20 meter patrol boats, and one landing ship, and one 60 meter floating dock. The equipment handover ceremony was held at the the Ream Navy Headquarters in Sihanoukville, the port city in southwest Cambodia near the Gulf of Thailand. In 2005, the Chinese Government also provided a grant to the Government of Cambodia for the acquisition of six additional naval patrol vessels (as captured via Project ID#32092).
Staff Comments: 1. In the Cambodia ODA Database maintained by the Government of Cambodia, this project is referred to as the Purchasing Suppressing Smuggling and Drug Trafficking Equipment Project. The Chinese project title is 9????. 2. According to CSSC, a China Eximbank Cambodia Project Evaluation Team visited the naval patrol vessel production factory. Therefore, AidData assumes that China Eximbank is the lender even though the name of the lender is not disclosed in the Cambodia ODA Database.

Title: NORINCO provides $262.5 million supplier's credit for acquisition of ammunition
Description: On December 8, 2005, China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO) — a Chinese state-owned company — and the Government of Pakistan signed a $262.5 million supplier credit agreement for the acquisition of ammunition. The loan’s ‘closing date’ was recorded by the Government of Pakistan as August 15, 2007. The outstanding principal balance of the loan in June 2012 was $31,875,000 and the outstanding interest balance of the loan in June 2012 was $360,9375.
Staff Comments: The Government of Pakistan loan ID number, as disclosed by the Economic Affairs Division (EAD) of the Government Pakistan, is DL820050001. The EAD project title is 'CHINA NORINCO (AMMO)'.
Funding Agencies: China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO Group)

Title: Chinese Government provides $5.6 million grant for Ministry of Defense Office Building Construction Project (linked to #1913)
Description: In March 2004, the Chinese Government provided a $5.6 million grant to the Government of Ghana for the Ministry of Defense Office Building Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a new, 5-story, 7,610 square meter office building for Ghana’s Ministry of Defense in Burma Camp within the city of Accra. The total cost of the project was $6.8 million. The Chinese Government provided $5.6 million and the Government Ghana covered the remainder. Qingdao Construction Group Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. It signed a construction contract on October 20, 2006 with Ghana’s Ministry of Defense. Then, on April 19, 2007, a formal groundbreaking ceremony took place. Construction began on April 20, 2007 and ended April 12, 2008. A formal project completion ceremony was then held on December 4, 2008. The originally expected duration of project implementation was 14 months.

Title: China donated $1.4 million USD in equipment and vehicles to Afghanistan (linked to #34500)
Description: In June, 2004 China donated police communications equipment as well as off-road vehicles to Afghanistan's transitional government. This included an alarm system, computer LAN, wireless systems and a digital programmable dispatching system as well as 22 Cherokees made by Beijing Jeep Corporation. The value of this donation is US$1.4 million. This is the second donation of goods made by China to the Afghan government to promote bilateral ties. The first was in 2002 when China donated military uniforms, boots and coats to the Afghan police and army (See Project ID#34500)
Source Titles: China donates another batch of equipment and vehicles to Afghan police|China donates office, sports equipment to Afghanistan
Source Publishers: |Embassy of People's Republic of China in India
Contact Position: Afghan Deputy Interior Minister|Chinese ambassador to Afghanistan

Title: Chinese Government donates military construction equipment worth 80 million pesos
Description: In November 2004, the Chinese Government announced that it would donate heavy engineering equipment to the Philippine military worth 80 million pesos ($2.5 million). The donation was received on December 29, 2005 and it included six bulldozers and six road graders. The equipment was intended for use in projects like road-building in rural areas.
Source Titles: China pledges $1.2 mln military aid to Philippines|China gives heavy machinery to Philippines military|The Limits of Twenty-First Century Chinese Soft-Power Statecraft in Southeast Asia: The Case of the Philippines
Source Publishers: Reuters News|Agence France Presse|Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University, Taipei

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense pledges RMB 100 million interest-free loan for military purposes
Description: In March 2004, the Chinese Government pledged an interest-free loan of RMB 100 million ($12 million) to the Government of Pakistan for military purposes. The loan was announced by the Chinese Minister of Defense Cao Gangchuan in a meeting with his Pakistani counterpart, Rao Sikandar Iqbal, during a a five-day visit to Islamabad. In January 2005, the two officials reaffirmed their intention to deepening military collaboration during Rao Sikandar Iqbal’s visit China.

Title: Chinese Government pledges $1 million grant to Kazakh armed forces
Description: On April 27, 2004, Kazakh Defense Minister Mukhtar Atlynbayev announced that the Chinese Government would provide $1 million to the Kazakh armed forces. This announcement came after the Kazakh defense minister met his Chinese counterpart Cao Gangchuan to discuss problems of security in Central Asia, and the role played by the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) in the struggle against international terrorism and separatism. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: The project may be connected to Project ID #40102, but this is unclear.
Source Titles: .China offers million dollars in aid to Kazakh armed forces. 27/4 Tass 172 By Alexander Zyuzin BEIJING, ...|China to give 1m dollars worth of military aid to Kazakh army|Military Cooperation between China and Central Asia: Breakthrough, Limits, and Prospects
Source Publishers: OANA|BBC|Jamestown Foundation
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

Title: Chinese Ministry of National Defense provides $966,400 grant to Tajik Army
Description: On August 31, 2004, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense provided a grant to the Government of Tajikistan to equip the Tajik Armed Forces. According to a May 2018 export from the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the monetary value of the grant was USD $966,400. The AIMS project identification number is TJK/042057. The funds were used to acquire military uniforms, computers, advanced communication equipment, and meet other needs of the Tajik Armed Forces.
Source Titles: China gives 1 mln dlr in disinterested aid to arm Tajik army.|May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects
Source Publishers: ITAR PASS|Tajikistan AIMS

Title: Chinese Defense Ministry provides RMB 10 million grant to Kyrgyz Defense Ministry
Description: On December 23, 2004, the Chinese Defense Ministry signed an RMB 10 million military grant agreement with the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry. The grant proceeds were to be disbursed in 2005. Chinese deputy head of the chancellery for foreign relations, Tsyan Likhua [phonetic], and the Kyrgyz deputy defense minister, Zamir Suyerkulov, signed the agreement. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China will hand over military-technical aid to the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry
Source Publishers: Organisation of Asia-Pacific News Agencies

Title: Chinese Government donates computer equipment worth $500,000 to Macedonian Army
Description: On or around February 16, 2004, the Macedonian Ministry of Defense and the Chinese Ministry of Defense signed a $500,000 (393,000 euro) military grant agreement. The agreement was signed by Macedonian Defense Minister Vlado Buckovski and Chinese Defencs Minister Cao Gangchuan. The proceeds of the grant were to be used to acquire computer equipment worth $500,000 (393,000 euro) for the Macedonian Army. The equipment donation was completed in 2004, but its precise completion date is unknown.
Source Titles: China To Donate Computer Equipment for 393,000 Euro to Macedonia|Macedonian military delegation visits China
Source Publishers: Macedonian Press Digest|Invest in Macedonia

Title: China donates light trucks and other equipment to the Lesotho Defense Force
Description: In 2004, the Chinese government donated light trucks and other equipment to the Lesotho Defense Force. The value of this donation is unknown.
Source Titles: LESOTHO: CHINA'S INFLUENCE IN AFRICA
Source Publishers: Wikileaks

Title: Chinese Government funds construction of Tubman Cantonment in Bong County (Linked to Project ID#1617)
Description: In 2004, during the end of the Liberian Civil war, a number of ‘cantonment sites' were built to facilitate the disarmament of the different rebel groups. The Chinese Government reportedly funded the construction of one of these military installations called the 'Tubman Cantonment’ in Bong County.
Staff Comments: In 2007, the PLA provided a $5.5 million grant to the Government of Liberia to renovate and expand the Camp Tubman Military Barracks in Gbarnga within Bong County (as captured via Project ID#1617). However, it is unclear if the Tubman Cantonment and the Camp Tubman Military Barracks are one and the same. This issue merits further investigation.
Source Titles: Liberia: UNMIL Braces for Disarmament, Tubmanburg's Cantonment Site Nearing Completion|China and Liberia:  Engagement in a Post-Conflict  Country 2003 – 2013
Source Publishers: All Africa|South African Institute of International Affairs

Title: Chinese Government donates 10,000 corrugated iron sheets, 110 computers, 3,000 bicycles and office furniture worth RMB 10 million
Description: On July 5, 2004, the Chinese government donated 10 million RMB worth of equipment to the government of the Central African Republic (see ''????????'' and ''Don chinois de matériels au gouvernement centrafricain''). Media articles reported that in 2004, the Chinese government donated equipment worth $4 million USD to the Central African Republic, which included 20,000 corrugated iron sheets, 110 computers, 3,000 bicycles and 60 mt of office furniture. The donation was made by Chinese Ambassador El Si Ji. The iron sheets will be used to rebuild military barracks while the CAR transitional government will use the computers, bicycles and office furniture during general elections planned for early 2005. This is likely referring to the same project.
Staff Comments: The Chinese project title is 1000??????????.
Receiving Agencies: Government of the Central African Republic

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense donates tents, uniforms, and teaching aids worth $362,000 to Jamaica Defense Force
Description: On November 29, 2004, the Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China and the Ministry of Defence of Jamaica signed a military grant agreement worth $362,000. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire uniforms, teaching aids, and tents for the Jamaica Defense Force (JDF). No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Public Library of US Diplomacy|Exchanges on military affairs and others
Source Publishers: WikiLeaks|Embassy of the People's Republic of China in Jamaica

Title: China signs Defense Cooperation Agreement to train Seychellois soldiers (Linked to #68808)
Description: In October 2004, the Chinese Minister of National Defense and the Seychellois President signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) on military defense cooperation sending 50 Seychelles soldiers for unspecified training in China. The program value and duration are unknown. They renewed this agreement in 2011 (project #68808). Seychelles is strategically located in the Indian Ocean between Asia and Africa; attracting piracy activities and therefore threatening China's investments and import-export activities in Africa.
Source Titles: CHINA PLEDGES TO INCREASE MILITARY ASSISTANCE TO SEYCHELLES|The Proposed PLA Naval Base in Seychelles and India’s Options|China invited to set up anti-piracy base in Seychelles
Source Publishers: Seychelles Department of Foreign Affairs|Manohar Parrikar Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses|Defence Web
