Title: Chinese Ministry of National Defense agrees to grant 6 million RMB in military aid to Peruvian Ministry of Defense
Description: On Dec 10, 2004 in Lima, Peru, representatives of the Ministry of Defense of Peru and the Ministry of National Defense of China respectively signed the Agreement between the Ministry of Defense of Peru and the Ministry of Defense of China for Free Military Assistance from China to Peru. The agreement pledged a grant of 6 million RMB worth of materials for military use, the nature and quantity of these materials to be decided at a later time and added in an addendum to the Agreement. The agreement sought to further develop cooperative relationships between the peoples of Peru and China and the military forces of both countries. In the terms of the agreement, the Chinese Ministry of Defense would be responsible for all costs involved in transporting the materials from a Chinese port to the Port of Callao (Puerto del Callao) in Peru while the Peruvian Ministry of Defense would be responsible for all costs incurred after the arrival of the materials at the Port of Callao. The agreement entered into force on the date of signing (Dec 10 2004) and it is valid until the obligation in the Agreement is completed, within 5 years of signing.In 2006, a batch of 20 Dong Feng EQ-2100 (4x4) 3.5-ton trucks and 13 FAW YQ-6100YH buses were delivered to support the logistical capacities of the Army of Peru, funded through this agreement (see 'Donación de material chino a las Fuerzas Armadas de Perú').
Staff Comments: While no source explicitly links the Free Assistance Agreement to the supplies delivered in 2006, the supplies were valued at about 750,000 USD (equivalent to about 6 million RMB at the time), have no clear funding mechanism, and there is no evidence of another grant that this agreement could have funded. Therefore, it is very likely that the 2004 agreement is the funding mechanism.
Receiving Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Implementing Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)|Peruvian Army (Ejército del Perú)
Source Titles: El Acuerdo sobre la Asistencia Militar Gratuita entre el Ministerio de Defensa de la Republica del Peru y el Ministerio de Defensa Nacional de la Republica Popular China|Donación de material chino a las Fuerzas Armadas de Perú|1999-2004 [Peru Tratados y Documentos Internacionales]
Source Publishers: Peru Ministry of Defense|America Militar|Derecho Internacional
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report|NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)

Title: Chinese Government provides military aid package
Description: From December 3 to 5, 2004, Chinese military officials including Deputy Director-General Colonel Li Ji of the Bureau of American and Oceanian Affairs of the Foreign Affairs Office of the Ministry of Defense of PRC visited Barbados. During the visit, the Chinese Government and the Government of Barbados signed a military grant agreement. The stipulations of the agreement and the amount of aid provided are unknown.
Source Titles: Summary of China-Barbados Bilateral Relations
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Barbados

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for provision of vehicles to Ghana Armed Forces
Description: In March 2004, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 10 grant to the Ghana Armed Forces for the acquisition of vehicles. These vehicles would reportedly be used in peacekeeping operations and to support the broader transportation needs of the Ghana Armed Forces. The grant agreement was signed by Ghana's Defence Minister Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor and Maj. Gen. Zhang Bangdon, Director of Foreign Affairs of the Office of National Defence of the People's Republic of China.
Source Titles: 1 GHANA – CHINA BI - LATERAL RELATIONS: A TREASURED FIFTY YEARS OF DIPLOMATIC, CULTURAL, ECONOMIC AND TRADE RELATIONS
Source Publishers: NYARKU
Contact Name: Maj. Gen. Zhang Bangdon|Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor
Contact Position: Director of Foreign Affairs, Office of National Defense|Defense Minister

Title: China sends military instructors to support equipment maintenance
Description: In 2003, China and Zimbabwe signed a military cooperation agreement that included the provision of a team of 3-10 instructors. The instructors were sent to help aid in equipment maintenance through the National Defense University. The financial amount for this project cannot be found.
Source Titles: http://mil.news.sohu.com/20070323/n248915877.shtml|China's New Security Strategy for Africa
Source Publishers: |Parameters

Title: China donates twenty-three vehicles worth $482,000 USD to Ghana
Description: In 2003, the Ghanaian Minister of Defense and Acting Interior Minister Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor received a donation of 23 vehicles from the Chinese Government. The donation of vehicles includes four tipper trucks, eight troops carrying vehicles, six double cabin pick-ups, and five single cabin pick-ups made possible with a grant of $482,000 USD. This donation was funded by an interest-free loan of $4.5 billion from the Chinese government to the Ghana Armed Forces and the Police Sevice. This project is related to ID#13883
Source Titles: $4.5m From China for Barracks
Source Publishers: Ghana Web

Title: China contributes peacekeepers to UN mission in Liberia (linked to project ID#88200)
Description: In December 2003 China joined the UN peacekeeping operations in Liberia by deploying 500 soldiers to the country. A total of 600 Chinese peacekeepers rotated deployment at an 8 month interval between January 2004 and June 2010. The peacekeepers consisted of supplies transport, engineering and medical units, including civilian police, military observers and staff officers. The Engineering and Medical units are based in Zwedru in UNMIL Sector 4, which covers the southeast region of Liberia (captured in project ID#88200). The other units are captured in this project, ID#1552.China concluded its peacekeeping activities for Liberia in 2018, withdrawing the fifth Chinese peacekeeping police team on February 28.
Implementing Agencies: Department of Peacekeeping Operations of the United Nations (DPKO)
Source Titles: http://www.china.org.cn/china/military/2008-12/18/content_16974293.htm|http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2005-07/12/content_794006.htm|China peacekeepers in Liberia|http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200412/23/eng20041223_168392.html|China decides to send peacekeepers to new ally Liberia.|China Solidifies Ties With Liberia, Govt Contemplates Reciprocation|Chinese peacekeeping squad leaves for Liberia|Senator says peacekeepers left 'indelible' impression|China concludes 14-year peacekeeping operations in Liberia

Title: Chinese Government provides military equipment and training worth RMB 25 million
Description: On November 21, 2003, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 25 million grant for the provision of military equipment to the Sierra Leonean military during an official visit to the People's Republic of China, where discussions were held to further the relationship between the two countries and their armed forces. Sierra Leone’s Deputy Defense Minister, Joe Blell, who was accompanied by Alhaji Ibrahim Morekeh Fofanah, Special Assistant to the President, Al-Hassan Kharamoh Kondeh, Director Defence Policy, Mr. Alusine Deen, Sierra Leone's Ambassador to China and his Deputy, Mr. Sahr E. Johnny, at the invitation of the Chinese Government, discussed issues that would further strengthen the friendly relations and fruitful cooperation between the two Armed Forces. The head of the Chinese Government Team, which received the Sierra Leone delegation, was pleased to inform the delegation that the Ministry of National Defense of China had decided to grant RMB 25 million to the Ministry of Defense in Sierra Leone for military equipment and training.
Source Titles: Deputy Defence Minister And Delegation Returns From China|http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=AFNWS00020031128dzbl004cc&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=
Source Publishers: All Africa|

Title: China provides $963,000 USD military grant to Ghana
Description: In 2003, China provided a military grant worth $963,000 USD to Ghana. No further information is available.
Source Titles: Assessing the Chinese Influence in Ghana Angola, and Zimbabwe:  The Impact of Politics, Partners, and Petro|How China delivers development assistance  to Africa

Title: China helps Pakistan to develop Shaheen-1 ballistic missile
Description: China helped Pakistan develop the 750-km-range, solid-fueled Shaheen-1 ballistic missile. In March 2003, the Shaheen I, or Hatf-4, solid-fueled missile was turned over to the Pakistani Army's Strategic Force Command. The Shaheen I is reportedly based on the Chinese M-9 missile, which according to one report, has a range of 200-600 km and a payload capacity of 950 kg.
Source Titles: China’s Military and Security Relationship with Pakistan|The Pakistan Thorn in China–India–U.S. Relations|Pakistan Profile|Pakistan Missile Update - 2003|The China factor in the India-Pakistan conflict
Source Publishers: Heritage Foundation|The Washington Quarterly|Nuclear Threat Initiative (NTI)|Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control|Parameters

Title: Chinese Government donates 40 jeeps to Kazakh Defense Ministry
Description: On September 26, 2003, the Chinese Government officially delivered a set of 40 donated (Cherokee and Super-Cherokee) jeeps to the Kazakh Defense Ministry. The estimated cost of each jeep was between $13,000 and $18,000. The Kazakh Defense Minister, Mukhtar Altynbayev, and the Chinese Ambassador to Kazakhstan, Chzhou Syao Pei took part in the handover ceremony.
Source Titles: Chinese jeeps for the Kazakhstani military men.|Military Cooperation between China and Central Asia: Breakthrough, Limits, and Prospects|Kazakhstan-China Military Exchanges Continue

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million of military grant assistance to Kyrgyz Defense Ministry
Description: On March 31, 2003, the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry by the Chinese Defense Ministry signed an RMB 100 million military grant assistance agreement (‘protocol’). The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire communications equipment, home and office equipment like computers, motor transport, and 12,000 uniforms. On November 14, 2003, a Chinese military delegation, led by the deputy chief of staff of the Xinjiang Military Area Command, arrived in Kyrgyzstan for the military assistance handover ceremony.
Source Titles: China renders aid to Kyrgyzstan|China gives 10m dollars in no-strings aid to Kyrgyz Defence Ministry|China gives military rear belongings to Kyrgyzstan|Western China military official visits Kyrgyzstan, donates equipment

Title: Chinese Government donates 2,200 military uniforms worth RMB 2 million to Kyrgyz Border Service
Description: On August 6, 2003, the Chinese Ministry of Defense and the Kyrgyz Border Service signed an RMB 2 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were used to purchase 2,200 military uniforms. The uniforms were officially handed over to the Kyrgyz Border Service on November 17, 2003. This project is completed.
Source Titles: China agrees 244,000-dollar no-strings aid to Kyrgyz border service|Another boost for Chinese-Kyrgyz defence ties
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific|BBC Monitoring Central Asia

Title: Chinese Government donates RMB 7 million to the Moldovan National Army for unspecified purposes
Description: On August 11, 2003, China’s Ministry of Defense and Moldova’s Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 7 million ($850,000) military grant agreement for unspecified purposes. The agreement was signed in the presence of Maj-Gen Zhang Shiming, Deputy Head of the General Armament Department of China’s Ministry of Defense and Moldova’s Defense Minister, Brig-Gen Victor Gaiciuc. The funds were transferred directly to the Government of Moldova as soon as the agreement was signed on August 11, 2003.

Title: China and Lesotho sign military cooperation agreement (Linked to #56636)
Description: In 2003, the Chinese People's Liberation Army and Lesotho Defense Force signed a bilateral military cooperation agreement in which China would regularly host Lesotho officers for training. Since its signing, a total of 152 Basotho officers and soldiers have successfully completed training as of August 2017. AidData has only recorded one of these sub-projects: #56636 from 2017.

Description: In 2003, the Chinese Government provided a $106 million loan to the Government of Sudan for the acquisition of military equipment. No additional information about this transaction is available.
Staff Comments: Poly Technologies could be the implementing contractor (see source ID 64700, p. 74).

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for Phase 2 of Military Housing and Facilities Project (Linked to Project ID#58102)
Description: In 2003, the Chinese Government provided a grant to the Government of Mozambique for Phase 2 of the Military Housing and Facilities Project. The monetary value of this grant is unknown. This project involved the construction of the supporting facilities — including military officers' clubs, small supermarkets, nurseries, primary schools, health centers, and two kilometers of roads — for a military camp (‘district”) in Maputo. China Youfa International Engineering Design Consulting Co. was responsible for the design of the project and Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Corporation was responsible for the implementation of the project. Construction began on December 27, 2003 and ended on July 2, 2004. The project was officially completed an handed over to the authorities on August 17, 2004. The Chinese Government also provided grant funding for Phase 1 of the Military Housing and Facilities Project, which involved constructed 12 general villas and 7 school buildings. Phase 1 was completed in February 2002 (See Project ID#58102).
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Phase 2 of the Maputo New Military District Residential Project. The Chinese project title is ???????????? or ?????????????? or ?????????????? or ????????????.

Title: Chinese Government dispatches 2nd peacekeeping team to DRC
Description: In December 2003, the Chinese government dispatched their second peacekeeping team to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The team fulfilled its mission from December 2003 to July 2004. The peacekeeping team's mission is unknown. This project is completed.
Receiving Agencies: Government of Democratic Republic of Congo
Source Publishers: Chinese Embassy in Democratic Republic of Congo

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense donates logistical materials worth RMB 3 million to Uruguayan Ministry of Defense in 2003
Description: On July 19, 2003, representatives from China's Ministry of Defense and Uruguay's Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 3 million grant agreement (‘protocol’) for the acquisition of military logistical materials. The agreement was ‘accepted’ by the Government of Uruguay on August 19, 2003 via Executive Resolution No. 81.044. No further implementation details are available.

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense donates logistical materials worth RMB 1 million to Uruguayan Ministry of Defense in 2003
Description: On August 27, 2003, representatives from China's Ministry of Defense and Uruguay's Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 1 million grant agreement (‘protocol’) for the acquisition of military logistical materials. The agreement was ‘accepted’ by the Government of Uruguay on September 30, 2003. No further implementation details are available.

Source Publishers: Presidency of Uruguay|Uruguay Ministry of Defense

Title: Chinese Government donates 32 vehicles worth 10 million RMB to Kenya military
Description: On February 20, 2003, Chinese and Kenyan officials held a handover ceremony for the donation of 32 Chinese military vehicles to the Kenyan military. Major General Njoroge, commander of Eastern Command of Kenya, represented the Kenyan military to receive the vehicles. The 32 vehicles, including 12 buses, 12 minibusses, and eight ambulances, are valued at 10 million RMB (about 1.2 million US dollars).
Source Titles: Relations Between China, Kenya Strengthened: Official|Kenya gets 2.3m-dollar Chinese military aid
Source Publishers: People's Daily|BBC Monitoring Africa
Geographic Location: A media article claims that between 2002 and 2007, 66 military vehicles have been donated from China to Kenya.

Title: Chinese Government provides $3.9 million interest-free loan for the Police and Military Barracks Construction Project
Description: In 2003, the Chinese Government provided a $3.9 million interest-free loan to the Government of Ghana for the Police and Military Barracks Construction Project.  This project involved the construction of 40 housing units for the Ghanaian military and police at Burma Camp in Accra. These barracks are locally known as the “Beijing Barracks”. The project commenced in March 2003. It was completed in March 11, 2004.  The building area is more than 2000 sq meters with 6 stories.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Beijing Barracks Construction Project or the Ghana Armed Forces (GAF) Barracks Construction Project. The Chinese project title is ???? or ?????-????????????. Since loan terms for the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
Source Titles: Ghana Ministry of Defence - Myanmar Barracks Hall and Library Project| Fiifi Kwetey lied about NPP's housing record|Ghana engages China in joint military exercise|Ministry of Defence|New building for defence ministry underway|Ghana-China Bilateral Relations|????????????2007???|Introduction of China-Ghana Relations
Source Publishers: GEMC|Pulse.com.gh|China military.com|Peace FM Online|Joy Online|NYARKU|Economic and Commercial Counsellor's Office of the Embassy of the People's Republic of China|Embassy of the People's Republic of China in Ghana
Source Type: Implementing/Intermediary Organization Source|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source
Geographic Location: These police and military barracks are located in Burma Camp within the city of Accra. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.openstreetmap.org/node/382529700 and https://www.google.com/maps/place/Burma+Camp,+Accra,+Ghana/@5.5939589,-0.1633143,15z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0xfdf9ad1f0efd137:0xbba2bc1bac87124e!8m2!3d5.5958462!4d-0.1518394.

Title: China donates military equipment worth US$1.8 million to Mozambique Armed Defense Forces
Description: On November 12, 2002, the Chinese government donated military equipment worth US$1.8 million to the Mozambique Defence Armed Forces (FADM). The donation consists of eight trucks, health and diving equipment, boots, and about 200,000 meters of cloth for manufacturing uniforms.
Source Titles: China donates military equipment to Mozambican armed forces.|China doa material militar a Moçambique no valor de 1,8 milhão de euros
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa|Agência de Notícias de Portugal

Title: China loans $2.7 million USD interest-free loan for construction of new military and police housing in Ghana
Description: In 2002, China agreed to assist Ghana with constructing new housing units at all military barracks in the country at a cost of $2.7 million USD. According to Dr. Kwame Addo-Kufuor, Minister of Defense for Ghana, this project was part of measures used to motivate soldiers. Construction commenced in January of 2003 with a sod-cutting ceremony. The barracks will comprise of three blocks of 28 units and two blocks of 12 units, accommodating 105 families. There is some confusion as to the amount of Chinese financing. It is unclear when the project was completed. This project is related to ID#1449 and possibly ID# 34571.
Staff Comments: Since loan terms for the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
Source Titles: http://www.modernghana.com/news/19479/1/chinese-assists-to-improve-facilities-at-army-barr.html|Chinese Attacks ... 2 Ghanaians Injured.|Addo-Kufour Commissions New Barracks|http://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afnws00020020620dy6k000xd&cat=a&ep=ASE|Assessing the Chinese Influence in Ghana Angola, and Zimbabwe:  The Impact of Politics, Partners, and Petro|How China delivers development assistance  to Africa|$4.5m From China for Barracks|??????30?????
Source Publishers: |All Africa|All Africa|||Centre for Chinese Studies|Ghana Web|Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)|Media Report|Donor/Recipient Official Source
Geographic Location: Accra

Title: Chinese military donates 5 million RMB to the Guinean military
Description: On 28 June 2002, President Lansana Conte received a Chinese military delegation led by the commander of the Beijing Military Region. During the visit, the Chinese military announced that they would grant 5 million RMB (2 billion Guinean francs) to the Guinean army. It is unclear how the funds were used.
Source Titles: Chinese military delegation announces donation to president.
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa - Political

Title: Chinese Government donates 50 military trucks to the Uganda People's Defense Force
Description: In 2002, during a visit by Chinese Maj. Zhang Bangbong to Ugandan army headquarters in Bombo, Uganda, the Chinese Government donated 50 heavy duty Jiefang trucks to the Uganda People's Defense Force (UPDF). Ugandan military officials valued the trucks at 1.3 million USD. During the visit, Maj. Zhang also pledged spaces in Chinese military colleges for Ugandan army officers (See ID#15026).
Source Titles: http://ug.chineseembassy.org/eng/zwgx/t168251.htm|China donates trucks to Ugandan army.|Sino-Ugandan Relations|UPDF Gets 50 Trucks|China Powers Anti-Kony Drive
Source Publishers: |Kyodo News||New Vision|New Vision
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Media Report|Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)|Media Report|Media Report
Contact Name: Brig. Gen. Nakabus Lakara|Maj. Zhang Bangbong

Title: Chinese Government provides assistance for Cockeril Military Headquarters Renovation Project
Description: In 2005, the Financial Times and several other sources reported that the Chinese Government provided grant assistance to the Government of Sierra Leone to renovate the headquarters building of the the Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces (RSLAF) in Cockeril. The monetary value of the grant commitment is unknown. Multiple sources indicate that the project was completed at some point in 2005. However, precise implementation start and end dates are unavailable.
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Cockerel Military Headquarters Renovation Project.
Source Titles: http://www.sierra-leone.org/Speeches/kabbah-062003.html|China leads the way, building on ties that go back 30 years CHINESE INTEREST: Relationship can be seen in some of Freetown's architecture. Andrew Child reports.|http://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=FTFT000020050214e12e0005j&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=|China – Sierra Leone relationship has yielded dividend – says John Baimba |China’s Big Investment|“Sierra Leoneans are desperate for development for which they can’t wait any longer”.-Chinese Ambassador | Sierra Leone News, This is Sierra Leone,All about Sierra Leone and Sierra Leone News.pdf|Re-enter the Dragon|China’s hold on Sierra Leone | Politico SL.pdf
Source Publishers: |Financial Times||Sierra Leone Telegraph|PBS|||Politico SL
Source Type: Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Academic Journal Article|Media Report
Geographic Location: This project involved the renovation of the the headquarters building of the Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces (RSLAF) in Cockeril. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/261177867 and https://mapcarta.com/31988406.

Title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 20 million military grant
Description: In 2002, the Chinese Government pledged an RMB 20 million military grant to Cambodia during a visit by Chinese Army Chief of Staff Fu Quanyou.
Source Titles: China increases military aid to Cambodia.|Human Rights Watch World Report 2003 - Cambodia|China to give more aid to Cambodia during premier's visit|Cambodia: Human Rights Development
Source Publishers: |United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|Yahoo Groups (Associated Press)|Human Rights Watch
Source Type: Media Report|NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)|Media Report|NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy (non-Donor, non-Recipient, non-Implementing)

Title: Chinese Government provides military aid to Sri Lankan Army
Description: On June 14, 2002, the Ministry of Defense of China and the Ministry of Defense of Sri Lanka signed a military grant agreement. The agreement was signed after Sri Lanka’s Defense Minister Tilak Marapone met with his Chinese counterpart Chi Haotian in Beijing.  At the time that the agreement was signed, the Sri Lankan military reportedly wanted China to help upgrade the island's navy and prevent weapons smuggling by Tamil Tiger guerrillas. However, the specific purpose and monetary value of the grant are unknown.
Staff Comments: No details of the agreement were disclosed or even vaguely hinted at. Although military sources it has to do with Sri Lanka seeking Chinese help in upgrading the island's navy and preventing weapons smuggling by Tamil Tiger rebels.
Source Titles: China agrees to lend Sri Lanka military assistance|Sri Lanka signs military assistance pact with China |China pledges Sri Lanka military assistance|Sri Lanka signs military assistance pact with China
Source Publishers: |ZeeNews|BBC|Zee Media Corporation Ltd
Contact Position: Minister of National Defense|Defence Minister, Sri Lanka

Title: Chinese Government donates $50,000 worth of military equipment (Linked to Project ID#40459)
Description: On March 28, 2002, Fijian Army Commander, Voreqe Bainimarama, and the Deputy Chief of Staff of the People’s Liberation Army of China, General Qian Shugen, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) at Queen Elizabeth Barracks in Nabua, Suva regarding the provision of military assistance. Then, on March 30, 2002, the Chinese Government donated $50,000 worth of equipment — consisting of tents and footwear — to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#37682). The Chinese Government also funding the construction of a computer laboratory and the provision of 41 computers to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#85625) and the construction and furnishing of a gymnasium for the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#40459).
Staff Comments: This project is linked to Project ID#40459.
Receiving Agencies: The Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF)
Source Titles: China donates 50,000 dollars-worth of military equipment, stores to Fiji|Defense and Security: A compendium of National Armed Forces and Security Policies
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political|ABC-CLIO

Title: Chinese Government provides $1 million grant to PNG military for physical training facilities
Description: On September 24, 2002, the Chinese Government and the PNG Defence Force signed a $1 million (about 4 million kina) military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used to improve physical training facilities, including gymnasiums and swimming pools at PNG army barracks. The agreement was signed between Papua New Guinean Defence Minister Yarka Kappa and the People's Republic of China Minister for National Defence Gen Chi Haotian. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China makes grant to PNG military during minister's stopover.
Source Publishers: British Broadcasting Corporation
Contact Position: China Minister for National Defence|Papua New Guinean Defence Minister

Title: Chinese Government pledges $3 million grant to Kazakh armed forces
Description: On March 18, 2002, the Chinese Government pledged a $3 million grant to the armed forces of Kazakhstan, according to Kazakh Defence Minister Mukhtar Altynbayev, supreme commander-in-chief and president of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev, and Xiong Guangkai, deputy chief of the General Staff of the Chinese People's Liberation Army. Mukhtar Altynbayev said that the aid would be received by the armed forces of Kazakhstan in the form of office equipment, communications equipment, and hardware for specialized subdivisions.
Source Titles: China to give no-strings military aid worth 3m dollars to Kazakhstan.
Source Publishers: BBC

Title: PLA provides first consignment of materials worth $1 million to Tajik Ministry of Defense (Linked to Project ID#40217)
Description: On December 24, 2002, the People's Liberation Army of China delivered an initial consignment of aid — consisting of four ambulances and other medical equipment for military hospitals — worth $1 million to the Ministry of Defense of Tajikistan (captured via Project ID#40216). Then, on December 26, 2002, the People's Liberation Army of China delivered a second consignment of aid — including rear equipment, field uniforms, clothes and footwear as well as two additional ambulances — worth $1 million to the Ministry of Defense of Tajikistan (captured via Project ID#40217).
Source Titles: CHINA GIVES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO TAJIK DEFENSE MINISTRY.|China gives one million dollars in technical aid to Tajik Defence Ministry.
Source Publishers: Interfax News Service|BBC
Geographic Location: Dushanbe

Title: PLA provides second consignment of materials worth $1 million to Tajik Ministry of Defense (Linked to Project ID#40216)
Description: On December 24, 2002, the People's Liberation Army of China delivered an initial consignment of aid — consisting of four ambulances and other medical equipment for military hospitals — worth $1 million to the Ministry of Defense of Tajikistan (captured via Project ID#40216). Then, on December 26, 2002, the People's Liberation Army of China delivered a second consignment of aid — including rear equipment, field uniforms, clothes and footwear as well as two additional ambulances — worth $1 million to the Ministry of Defense of Tajikistan (captured in this project)
Source Titles: China gives second 1m-dollar aid consignment to Tajik army.|China gives second 1m-dollar aid consignment to Tajik army.
Source Publishers: BBC|BBC
Geographic Location: Dushanbe

Title: Chinese Defense Ministry donates equipment worth RMB 10 million to Kyrgyz Defense Ministry
Description: On March 15, 2002, China’s Defense Ministry and the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry signed an RMB 10 million military grant agreement for the acquisition of uniforms, communications equipment, radio stations, and night vision devices. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: According to Agence France-Presse (AFP), China, which shares a border with Kyrgyzstan, provided more than four million dollars' worth of military aid to Kyrgyzstan between 1999 and 2002.
Source Titles: China to give 1.3 million dollars in military aid to Kyrgyzstan|Chinese military chief, Kyrgyz defence minister sign 1m-dollar aid accord|Kyrgyz-Chinese military cooperation deepening, says Chinese attache
Source Publishers: Agence France-Presse|BBC Monitoring Central Asia|BBC Monitoring Central Asia

Title: Chinese Government donates equipment to Kyrgyz National Guard worth $500,000
Description: On July 23, 2002, the Chinese Government officially delivered 900 camouflaged military uniforms worth RMB 500,000 to the National Guards of Kyrgyzstan (Kyrgyz National Guard).
Source Titles: Kabar News Agency of Kyrgyzstan
Source Publishers: KABNEW

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for construction and furnishing of gymnasium (Linked to Project ID#37682 and ID#85625)
Description: On March 28, 2002, Fijian Army Commander, Voreqe Bainimarama, and the Deputy Chief of Staff of the People’s Liberation Army of China, General Qian Shugen, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) at Queen Elizabeth Barracks in Nabua, Suva regarding the provision of military assistance. Then, on March 30, 2002, the Chinese Government donated $50,000 worth of equipment — consisting of tents and footwear — to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#37682). The Chinese Government also funding the construction of a computer laboratory and the provision of 41 computers to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#85625) and the construction and furnishing of a gymnasium for the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#40459).
Staff Comments: It's possible that this project is a duplicate of project #64735, the construction of Suva Multipurpose Sports Complex (now known as Vodafone Arena and previously known as the FMF Dome), which began in 2002.
Receiving Agencies: The Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF)
Source Titles: China donates 50,000 dollars-worth of military equipment, stores to Fiji.
Source Publishers: BBC

Title: Chinese Government pledges anti-terrorism military training for Romanian gendarmes
Description: On October 9, 2002, the Chinese Government pledged to provide Romanian gendarmes specialized anti-terror assistance. Chinese experts would provide martial arts courses and Chinese police officers would attend ‘refresh’ courses at a school of the Romanian Gendarmerie. The Chinese Government also reportedly sent more than one hundred bullet-proof vests for a Romanian contingent in Kosovo.
Source Titles: Chinese assistance is offered for anti-terror training of Romanian gendarmes.
Source Publishers: ROMPES

Title: Chinese Government donates uniforms, computers, radios and other equipment worth $234,000 to Jamaica Defense Force
Description: On December 5, 2002, the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of Jamaica signed a Memorandum of Understanding wherein the Government of the People's Republic of China agreed to provide $234,000 for the provision of uniforms, computers, radios and other non-operational, non-combat equipment to the Jamaica Defense Force (JDF). No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Public Library of US Diplomacy
Source Publishers: WikiLeaks

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for Phase 1 of Military Housing and Facilities Project (Linked to Project ID#58100)
Description: In 2001, the Chinese Government provided a grant to the Government of Mozambique for Phase 1 of the Military Housing and Facilities Project. The monetary value of this grant is unknown. This project covered an area of 9,800 square metes, and involved the construction of 12 general villas and 7 school buildings for a military camp (‘district”) in Maputo. Construction started on September 28, 2000. Phase 1 was completed in February 2002. The Chinese Government also provided grant funding for Phase 2 of the Military Housing and Facilities Project, which involved the construction of military officers' clubs, small supermarkets, nurseries, primary schools, health centers, and two kilometers of roads. Phase 2 was officially completed an handed over to the authorities on August 17, 2004 (See Project ID#58100).
Staff Comments: This project is also known as the Phase 1 of the Maputo New Military District Residential Project. The Chinese project title is ????????????.
Implementing Agencies: Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Group Co., Ltd. (AFECC)|China Youfa International Engineering Design Consulting Co., Ltd.
Source Publishers: Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China|Department of Economic and Commerce of PRC Embassy to Mozambique|Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China
Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source
Geographic Location: This project was located in Maputo.

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense donates logistical materials worth RMB 3 million to Uruguayan Ministry of Defense in 2002
Description: On November 15, 2002, representatives from China's Ministry of Defense and Uruguay's Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 3 million grant agreement (‘protocol’) for the acquisition of military logistical materials. The agreement was ‘accepted’ by the Government of Uruguay on January 28, 2003 via Executive Resolution No. 80.565. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: SE ACEPTA DONACIÓN OFRECIDA POR LA REPÚBLICA POPULAR CHINA
Source Publishers: Presidency of Uruguay

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 2 million military grant for unspecified purposes
Description: On June 24, 2002, the Chinese Ministry of Defense and the Government of Moldova’s Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 2 million military grant agreement. The grant was to be disbursed for the acquisition of an unspecified set of tangible assets at a later date. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Lista tratatelor bilaterale încheiate de Republica Moldova|ÎNTRE MINISTERUL AP?R?RII NA?IONALE AL REPUBLICII POPULARE CHINEZE ?I MINISTERUL AP?R?RII AL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA PRIVIND ACORDAREA DE C?TRE CHINA A UNUI AJUTOR NERAMBURSABIL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA|ÎNTRE MINISTERUL APARARII NATIONALE  AL REPUBLICII  PULARE CHINEZE SI  MINISTERUL APARARII AL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA  PRIVIND ACORDAREA , DE C?TRE CHINA A UNUI AJUTOR NERAMBURSABIL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA|Lot de tehnic? donat Armatei Na?ionale de c?tre China|ACORD ÎNTRE MINISTERUL AP?R?RII NA?IONALE AL REPUBLICII POPULARE CHINEZE ?I MINISTERUL AP?R?RII AL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA PRIVIND ACORDAREA DE C?TRE CHINA A UNUI AJUTOR NERAMBURSABIL REPUBLICII MOLDOVA|List of Bilateral agreements

Source Type: Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Chinese Ministry of National Defense donates buses and ambulances worth 6 million RMB to Peru Ministry of Defense
Description: On Dec 6, 2002, an agreement between Peru's Ministry of Defense and the Chinese Ministry of National Defense was signed to grant the Peruvian Ministry of Defense aid in the form of military logistics materials, including buses and ambulances, worth 6 million RMB. The purpose of the agreement is to further develop cooperative relations between the governments and armed forces of both countries through consultations and free military aid provision. According to the terms of the agreement, the Chinese Ministry of National Defense was responsible for transporting the materials from a Chinese port to the Port of Callao and the costs incurred by this transport. The Ministry of Defense of Peru was responsible for all costs incurred after the materials arrive to the Port of Callao. The agreement entered into force on the day of signing and remained valid until the completion of the agreement.The materials were as follows:-12 buses (Type CA6990). Buses with diesel motors, type CA6110, made in China. Each bus has 45 seats, plus one for the driver. The buses do not contain air conditioning based on the climate of Chile.-3 ambulances (Iveco brand, Type NJ5036XJH2). -Wearable parts for a year for all vehicles
Receiving Agencies: Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Implementing Agencies: Government of Peru|Peru Ministry of Defense (Ministerio de Defensa) (MINDEF)
Source Titles: ACUERDO ENTRE EL MINISTERIO DE DEFENSA DE LA REPÚBLICA DEL PERÚ Y EL MINISTERIO DE DEFENSA NACIONAL DE LA REPUBLICA POPULAR CHINA SOBRE LA ASISTENCIA MILITAR GRATUITA POR CHINA AL PERU
Source Publishers: Peru Ministry of Defense

Title: Chinese Government provides grant for computer laboratory (Linked to Project ID#40459 and ID#37682)
Description: On March 28, 2002, Fijian Army Commander, Voreqe Bainimarama, and the Deputy Chief of Staff of the People’s Liberation Army of China, General Qian Shugen, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) at Queen Elizabeth Barracks in Nabua, Suva regarding the provision of military assistance. Then, on March 30, 2002, the Chinese Government donated $50,000 worth of equipment — consisting of tents and footwear — to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#37682). The Chinese Government also funding the construction of a computer laboratory and the provision of 41 computers to the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#85625) and the construction and furnishing of a gymnasium for the Fiji Military Forces (captured via Project ID#40459).
Receiving Agencies: The Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF)
Source Titles: China donates 50,000 dollars-worth of military equipment, stores to Fiji
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

Title: Chinese government grants 4 million RMB through Free Military Assistance Agreement (April 2002)
Description: On April 16, 2002, the Ministries of Defense of China and Ecuador signed a Free Military Assistance Agreement (Asistencia Military Gratuita) that granted 4 million RMB to the latter party for logistics materials. It is unknown what projects or pieces of equipment were eventually purchased with this grant. There is a possibility that it funded the grant whose handover is captured in project #35783, though there is no evidence to suggest this beyond the grant arriving relatively soon after the signing of this agreement, and prior to any other known Free Military Assistance Agreement.
Staff Comments: The project is not marked as umbrella as there are no sub-projects captured and there is no risk of duplication.
Source Titles: No. 2002-19-JY139A ACUERDO ENTRE EL MIINISTERIO DE DEFENSA NACIONAL DE LA REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR Y EL MINISTERIO DE DEFENSA NACIONAL DE LA REPUBLICA POPULAR CHINA PARA LA ASISTENCIA MILITAR GRATUITA POR CHINA A ECUADOR
Source Publishers: Ecuador Ministry of Foreign Relations

Title: Chinese Government pledges assistance for rehabilitating uniform manufacturing plant
Description: As reported in January 2001, the government of Tanzania was implementing plans to improve a uniform manufacturing plant run by the National Service Camp in Ruvu under a framework of cooperation with China. Defense Minister Professor Philemon Sarungi said that a market for the uniforms would be assured, given the fact that Nigeria and Namibia used to purchase uniforms from them. The current status of this project is yet unknown.
Source Titles: Government to improve army uniform factory with Chinese assistance.
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Africa - Political

Title: China donates US$1.2 million to Zambian armed forces
Description: In November of 2001, the Chinese government donated $1.2 million USD to the Zambian armed forces. Among those present at the ceremony were Chinese People's Army General Fu Quanyou, Zambian Defense Minister Joshua Simuyandi, and Zambian Minister of Foreign Affairs, and the Commander of the Zambian Army. It is unclear how the funds were used, and the project appears to be untied.
Source Titles: 'Zambia And China Relationship is Historical'.
Source Publishers: All Africa

Title: Chinese Government provides $2 million grant for Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution (Linked to Project ID#87160 and #87633)
Description: On February 13, 2001, China’s Ministry of Defense and the Cambodian Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 30 million ($3.7 million) grant agreement for the renovation of the Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital and the construction of the Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution (military training institute). Then, on May 8, 2001, the Government of Cambodia announced that the Chinese Government had agreed to earmark $1.7 million of the grant proceeds for the renovation of the Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital (as captured via Project ID#87633). Therefore, AidData assumes that the remaining balance of the grant commitment ($2 million) was earmarked for the construction of the Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution (military training institute).The Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution, a new training facility at the Combined Arms Officer School Thlok Tasek, was officially inaugurated on January 25, 2013. Located near Pich Nil town in Phnom Sruoch district within Kampong Speu province, the facility is overseen by Chinese advisers, and the courses are devised by China’s Ministry of Defense. The training facility seeks to provide high-quality training to young soldiers to replace old officers. About half of all of Cambodia's military officer trainees now reportedly come through the Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution.In 2017, the Chinese Government announced that it would provide a $65 million grant for the expansion of the Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital, which is recorded in the linked project #87160.
Staff Comments: The Chinese-Cambodian Friendship Infantry Institution appears to have been operational prior to its official inauguration on January 25, 2013. Since 2009, Cambodian military cadets have reportedly been admitted annually to four-year courses devised by China's Defense Ministry and on-site Chinese advisers. This includes compulsory six month stints at military academies in China. The 190 students who graduated in March 2015 were the third such cohort from the school.
Implementing Agencies: Cambodia Ministry of Defense|China Ministry of Defense|Government of Cambodia|Preah Ket Melea Military Hospital
Source Titles: Army best friends with China and Vietnam|A Chinese model for patron–client relations? The Sino-Cambodian partnership|Chinese influence in Cambodia grows with army school, aid|PM Hun Sen chastises RCFA for unprofessionalism|China’s Military Aid More Than Expected|Army best friends with China and Vietnam|Chinese defense minister doles out aid at start of Cambodia tour|China’s Military Aid More Than Expected| China steps up military aid
Source Publishers: |Oxford Journals: International Relations of the Asia-Pacific|Reuters|The Phnom Penh Post|Cambodia Daily|Phnom Penh Post|Agence France-Presse|The Cambodia Daily|Phnom Penh Post
Source Type: Media Report|Academic Journal Article|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report|Media Report
Geographic Location: This project involve the construction of a military training institute near Pich Nil town in Phnom Sruoch district within Kampong Speu province. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/491544444.
Contact Position: Chinese Defense Minister|Chief of Foreign Affairs of the Defence Ministry|Co-minister of Defence

Title: Chinese Government pledges $400 million loan to Royal Thai Navy and Royal Thai Army for acquisition of weapons (Linked to Project ID#34257)
Description: On July 3, 2001, the Chinese Government agreed — at least in principle — to lend $200 million to the Royal Thai Army and $200 million to the Royal Thai Navy for purchase of Chinese weapons. This decision was made after a series of meetings with China defense minister General Chi Haotian, Thai defense minister Gen Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, and other officials. The Chinese Government reportedly agreed to waive interest payments for two years. The Royal Thai Navy and the Royal Thai Army subsequently purchased 2 Pattani-class offshore patrol vessels, a QW-18 man portable air defense system, a WS-1B self-propelled multiple rocket launch system, and 60 C-802 anti-ship missies from Chinese suppliers between 2001 and 2014. However, it is unclear if a loan agreement with the Chinese Government was ever finalized to facilitate any of these purchases. This issue requires further investigation.
Staff Comments: This project is currently coded as an umbrella project and covers sub-project #34257. However, it is not certain whether #34245 and #34257 are unrelated projects, or if #34245 is an umbrella project with sub-project #34257.Exact dates of project agreement unknown.
Source Titles: China assures Chavalit of its friendship.|Thailand’s Military Relations with China: Moving from  Strength to Strength|‘The Chinese and the Thais are Brothers': the evolution of the Sino–Thai friendship
Source Publishers: Bangkok Post|YUSOF ISHAK INSTITUTE|Journal of Contemporary China
Source Type: Media Report|Academic Journal Article|Academic Journal Article
Contact Position: Chinee Defense Minister|Chief of the Defence Minister's Staff officers

Title: Chinese Government pledges $120 million loan for acquisition of military equipment (Linked to Project ID#34245)
Description: According to press release from Thai News Service on August 31, 2001, Thailand's armed forces and China's armed forces agreed on a number of measures to facilitate Thailand's purchase of military hardware from China. At the time, the Government Thailand was negotiating the purchase of patrol vehicles and a frigate from the Chinese Government for $120 million (5.29 billion baht). The Chinese Government reportedly agreed to cut the interest rate on a five-year loan from 4.5 to 2% to enable the purchase.The Royal Thai Navy subsequently 2 Pattani-class offshore patrol vessels from a Chinese supplied in 2002. These vessels were delivered in 2005 and 2006. However, it is unclear if a loan agreement with the Chinese Government was ever finalized to facilitate these purchases. This issue requires further investigation. There is no evidence that the Royal Thai Navy subsequently purchased a frigate from a Chinese supplier.
Staff Comments: The specific loan amount is unclear, as $120 million is the monetary value of the equipment purchased. This project is currently coded as a sub-project of #34245. However, it is not certain whether #34245 and #34257 are unrelated projects, or if #34245 is an umbrella project with sub-project #34257.
Source Titles: China, Thailand reach agreement on arms procurement.|[SEA] THAI - Thai-Sino Arms Deals Facilitated|Arms Transfers, Military Coups, and Military Rule in Developing State|THAILAND’S POST-COUP RELATIONSWITH CHINA AND AMERICA:MORE BEIJING, LESS WASHINGTON|Thailand’s Military Relations with China: Moving from  Strength to Strength|‘The Chinese and the Thais are Brothers': the evolution of the Sino–Thai friendship
Source Publishers: Thai News Service||University of Dhaka|ISEAS–Yusof Ishak Institut|YUSOF ISHAK INSTITUTE|Journal of Contemporary China
Source Type: Media Report|Other|Academic Journal Article|Academic Journal Article|Academic Journal Article|Academic Journal Article

Title: Chinese Defense Ministry donates non-lethal military equipment worth $1 million to Venezuelan Defense Ministry
Description: On August 31, 2001, the Chinese Defense Ministry donated non-lethal military equipment worth $1 million to the Venezuelan Defense Ministry. The donation consisted of Chinese-made uniforms, boots, tents and other supply items. The Chinese donation was a 'gesture of friendship' and reflected a desire by the Chinese armed forces to develop stronger contacts and cooperation with their Venezuelan counterparts, Venezuelan Defense Minister Jose Vicente Rangel told reporters after talks with China's Defense Minister Chi Hoatian.
Receiving Agencies: Venezuela Ministry of People's Power for Defense
Source Titles: China makes $1 mln military donation to Venezuela.|Venezuela: Favoring China Over U.S.
Source Publishers: Reuters|

Title: CATIC provides a $2 million USD interest-free supplier's credit for the Acquisition of Second Hand Y-1211 Aircraft and Spare Parts for the Guyana Defence Force
Description: On August 10, 2001, China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corporation (CATIC) and the Government of Guyana signed an interest-free supplier’s credit loan agreement (Agreement No. ATE/GUY/01M0001) worth $2,122,084 USD for the purchase of a Second Hand Y-1211 Aircraft and Spare Parts for the Guyana Defence Force. This supplier’s credit carried the following terms: an interest rate of 0%, a grace period of 1 year, and a maturity period of 5 year.  Debt service payments were scheduled between August 9, 2002 and August 9, 2007. According to a 2007 Report of the Auditor General of Guyana, the outstanding balance of this supplier’s credit was $322,000 USD in 2007.
Funding Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)
Implementing Agencies: China National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corporation (CATIC)
Source Titles: CARIBBEAN/CHINA: WINNING FRIENDS AND INFLUENCING PEOPLE|2003 Guyana NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SUPPLEMENTARY ORDER PAPER |Guyana 2007 Report of the Auditor General |Report of the Auditor General on the Public Accounts of Guyana and on the Accounts of the Ministries/Departments/Regions for the Fiscal Year Ended 31 December 2006|NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MINUTES OF PROCEEDINGS OF THE 19ThSITTING OF THE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY OF THE SECOND SESSION (2002-2003) OF THE EIGHTH PARLIAMENT OF GUYANA HELD AT 2.00 P.M.

Source Type: Media Report|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source|Donor/Recipient Official Source

Title: Chinese Government donates tents, overhead projectors, digital cameras, laptop computers, gas masks and uniforms worth $360,000
Description: On December 8, 2003, the Chinese Government donated $360,000 worth of military equipment to the Government of Trinidad and Tobago. The donation consisted of tents, overhead projectors, digital cameras, laptop computers, gas masks and uniforms. It was funded with the proceeds from a grant agreement that the parties signed in 2001. Military officers from Trinidad and Tobago also received training in China as part of the deal.
Receiving Agencies: Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago
Source Titles: China donates military equipment to Trinidad|HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES Friday, January 28, 2005
Source Publishers: Associated Press Newswires|Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago

Title: China supplies Pakistan missile Haider-1
Description: In January 2003 it was reported that China in the second half of 2001 had provided significant assistance to Pakistan for the development of the Haider-1 missile.
Source Titles: Chinese?Pakistani nuclear/missile ties and balance of power politics|Handbook of Technology Management in Public Administration
Source Publishers: The Nonproliferation Review|CRC Press
Source Type: Academic Journal Article|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 8 million grant to Tajik Army
Description: On September 17, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed an RMB 8 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were earmarked for military exercises, education and rearmament and designed to support the armed forces of Tajikistan.
Source Titles: China gives one million dollars to Tajik army
Source Publishers: AFPR

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense provides RMB 8 million military grant to protect the Zamyn-Uud border, coordinate visa issues, provide military training, and acquire civil defense rescue equipment
Description: In June 2001, China’s Defense Ministry and Mongolia’s Defense Ministry signed an RMB 8 million military grant agreement. The grant proceeds were to be used for the protection of the Zamyn-Uud border, the coordination of visa issues, the training of 16 Mongolian officials in China, and the acquisition of civil defense rescue equipment. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China grants Mongolia 8m yuan in defence aid.

Title: Chinese Defense Ministry donates military equipment worth USD $1 million to to Kyrgyz Defense Ministry
Description: On July 16, 2001, China’s Defense Ministry and the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry signed an RMB 8 million (USD 1 million) military grant agreement for the acquisition of technical equipment and hardware. The agreement was signed during Kyrgyz Deputy Defence Minister Malik Borubayev's meeting with the head of the one of the departments in the Chinese Defense Ministry Qin Lihua.  In the course of the meeting, the Chinese side inquired about the measures Kyrgyzstan is taking to ensure its security.  Qin noted that China objectively assessed the military-political situation in Central Asia and was ready to continue to assist Kyrgyzstan in fighting international terrorism and religious extremism.
Source Titles: China to give Kyrgyzstan 1m dollars in military aid - Kyrgyz minister|Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, China to build a railway|China to render military assistance to Kyrgyzstan
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia|ITAR Tass: Comtex|BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense Commits 500,000 RMB in Military Equipment and technical assistance to Kyrgyzstan
Description: In 2001, the Chinese Defence Ministry and the National Guard of Kyrgyzstan signed an agreement on cooperation under which China would provide material aid to the servicemen of the Kyrgyz National Guard. The agreement was signed by the Chinese military attache in Kyrgyzstan, U Chun Zhun [transliterated], and the commander of the Kyrgyz National Guard, Abdykul Chotbayev, in Bishkek. Military aid worth 500,000 Chinese yuan (about 60,000 US dollars) will be provided under the agreement. Cooperation in the field of training specialists is also included under the agreement. For example, seven officers of the Kyrgyz National Guard will be sent to China for training at military schools at the end of August 2001.
Source Titles: Kyrgyz National Guard to get military aid from China|Defence Ministry to give financial, technical aid to Kyrgyz army
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia|BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

Title: Chinese Government $1 million grant for military reconstruction activities (Linked to Project ID#42242)
Description: On April 27, 2001, the Chinese Government provided a $1 million (EUR 1.1 million) cash grant to the Government of Macedonia  to support post-conflict and military reconstruction activities in the northern part of the countries.  $400,000 (443,000 euro) was earmarked for the modernization of the military’s computer network and the provision of equipment in the Macedonian Ministry of Defense. However, the Chinese government specified that the grant was not to be used for the purchase of weapons. This $1 million grant is part of a larger $20 million financial package that the Chinese Government provided for post-conflict reconstruction activities (see Project ID#42442).
Source Titles: Chinese Govt Donates $1.0 Mln to Macedonia|Macedonia Receives $1.0 Mln Chinese Grant
Source Publishers: Macedonian Press Digest|Macedonian Press Digest

Title: Chinese Government provides military aid to Congo-Brazzaville to reorganize its army
Description: On June 24, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of the Congo signed a military cooperation accord to reorganize the Congolese army. The accord followed an official visit by Congolese President Denis Sassou Nguesso to China in April 2000. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Congo, China sign military cooperation accord
Source Publishers: Agence France-Presse

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 22 million for military training purposes
Description: On August 30, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Ministry of Defense of Cambodia signed two agreements that involved the provision of RMB 22 million ($2.7 million) of military grant assistance. Eang Sophalleth, the Cambodian government spokesman, said the money would be used to train people, but not to buy new weapons. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: China pledges military aid to cambodia|China pledges military aid to Cambodia
Source Publishers: Agence France-Presse|BBC
Contact Position: personal assistant to the Cambodian premier|Visiting Chinese defense military director-general

Title: 1st Chinese Deployment of Peacekeeping Police in Timor-Leste
Description: The Chinese government deployed its first batch peacekeeping forces to Timor-Leste on January 18, 2000. The team comprised of 15 officers working conjunction with the UN mission in Timor-Leste (UNTAET), which was tasked with assisting Timor-Leste during its transition into a fully fledged state. Working with other civilian police officers, the team were dispersed across the country.The deployment of peacekeeping personnel was accompanied by a 50 million RMB donation from the Chinese government to assist the reconstruction effort in Timor-Leste (see Project #34443).

Title: Chinese Government grants gymnastics training to Tongan Army
Description: In March of 2000, the Chinese Government pledged to provide a Chinese gymnastics instructor to train a Tongan 200-man army unit for a year. The value and status of this project are unknown.
Source Titles: Chinese Army Offers Small-Scale Aid To Pacific Armies
Source Publishers: DJI

Title: Chinese Government donates camouflage uniforms, t-shirts, boots, tents, lawn-mowers, cooking utensils and other non-lethal equipment worth AUD 680,000 to PNG Military
Description: In March 2000, the Chinese Ministry of Defense shipped a batch of donated equipment — consisting of camouflage uniforms, t-shirts, boots, tents, lawn-mowers, cooking utensils and other non-lethal equipment — to the PNG Military via Port Moresby. The estimated monetary value of this donation was 680,000 Australian dollars (1 million kina). Then, on March 3, 2000, an assurance was given by the highest Chinese defense official to visit PNG, Maj-Gen Li Donghui, that China would provide additional military assistance to PNG.
Receiving Agencies: Papua New Guinea Ministry of Defense
Source Titles: China to donate military gear, no arms|PAC - China rewards PNG for Taiwan snub|China to donate military gear, no arms.
Source Publishers: British Broadcasting Corporation|Australian Associated Press|

Title: Chinese Government provides military logistic assistance worth TOP 300,000 to Tonga Defence Services
Description: In 2000, the Chinese Government provided military logistic assistance worth TOP 300,000 to Tonga Defense Services. The aid package arrived in May 2000, and China's Ambassador to Tonga officially handed over the donation to the local authorities.
Source Titles: Chinese military equipment handed over.
Source Publishers: BBC/APP

Title: China provides a non-weapon aid package worth FJD 1.8 million to RFMF
Description: On December 5, 2000, an agreement about a military aid package program worth 1.8 million FJD was signed between the governments of Fiji and China. The agreement was signed at the military headquarters by army commander Cdre Frank Bainimarama and Chinese Ambassador Junsai Zhang. According to the agreement, the Chinese Government is going to provide military logistics goods to the RFMF (Republic of Fiji Military Forces).
Implementing Agencies: The Republic of Fiji Military Forces (RFMF)
Source Titles: China agrees non-weapons aid for military|Defense and Security: A compendium of National Armed Forces and Security Policies
Source Publishers: BBC  Monitoring Service: Asia-Pacific|ABC-CLIO

Title: China assists Pakistan in creating Shaheen-2 ballistic missile
Description: China assisted Pakistan in creating nuclear-capable Shaheen-2 ballistic missile, also known as 'Ghaznavi'. It is a land-based supersonic surface-to-surface medium-rage guided ballistic missile. Since 1998, Pakistan reportedly received China's support in the serial production of Shaheen-1 SRMB and the Shaheen-2 MRMB, including 12 shipments of missile components and the building of a second missile plant. The production of Shaeen-1 is recorded in project #39041.
Source Titles: Chinese?Pakistani nuclear/missile ties and balance of power politics|China and Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction and Missiles: Policy Issues|https://www.nonproliferation.org/wp-content/uploads/npr/102paul.pdf
Source Publishers: The Nonproliferation Review|Diane Publishing|The Nonproliferation Review
Source Type: Academic Journal Article|Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)|Academic Journal Article

Title: Chinese Government provides $300,000 military grant to fight ethnic separatism
Description: On August 23, 2000, China’s Ministry of Defense and the Ministry of Defense of Uzbekistan signed a military grant agreement worth $300,000. The agreement was signed during a meeting by Uzbekistan's Defense Minister Yuriy Agzamov and Chinese Defense Minister Chi Haotian. No further implementation details are available.
Staff Comments: This grant commitment appears to be distinct from the one that is captured via Project ID#40041. However, this issue warrants further investigation.
Source Titles: China gives Uzbeks military aid, ready to help fight 'ethnic separatism'|China bids to fight the flames of conflict burning in Central Asia.
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia |The Scotsman

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant to acquire military equipment for conducting antiterrorist operations in mountainous areas
Description: On September 4th, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed an RMB 5 million (about 600,000 US dollars) military grant agreement. The Chinese and Uzbek Defense Ministers signed the agreement on behalf of their respective governments. The grant proceeds were to be used to acquire military equipment for conducting antiterrorist operations in mountainous areas. At the time, Beijing announced that it was ready to cooperate with Tashkent in training military personnel and improving structures of military departments. The Chinese Government’s financial contribution was reportedly a response to an incursion of IMU-led militants into Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan in August 2000.
Source Titles: China to give Uzbekistan military aid worth 600,000 dollars.|Islamic Extremism in Former Soviet Republics
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political|Military Review

Title: Chinese Government provides RMB 11 million grant to Kazakh armed forces
Description: On May 2, 2000 the Chinese Government announced that it would provide an RMB 11 million grant to the Kazakh armed forces. A grant agreement was signed by the parties during Kazakh Defence Minister Sat Tokpakbayev's visit to China from April 24-28, 2000. The purpose of the grant was to acquire goods and services, which were scheduled for delivery before the end of 2000.
Source Titles: China to provide aid for Kazakh armed forces.|Sino-Russian Strategic Partnership in Central Asia: Implications for India
Source Publishers: BBC|Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses, New Delhi, India

Title: China’s Ministry of Defense provides RMB 5 million military grant for unspecified purposes
Description: On July 12,  2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed an RMB 5 million military grant agreement for unspecified purposes. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Tajik defence minister meets new Chinese military attache.|CHINA TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO TAJIK MILITARY.|Military delegation, Tajik leaders discuss cooperation.
Source Publishers: BBC|IPRSID|BBC
Geographic Location: Dushanbe

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense provides RMB 8 million military grant for unspecified purposes
Description: In January 2000, China’s Defense Ministry and the Government of Mongolia signed an RMB 8 million military grant agreement for unspecified purposes. The agreement was signed during Chinese Defense Minister Chi Haotian's visit to the Mongolian capital, where he stayed from January 23-25, 2000. No further implementation details are available.
Source Titles: Beijing renders military aid to Mongolia.

Title: Chinese Ministry of Defense donates equipment to Defense Ministry of Kyrgyzstan worth RMB 10 million
Description: On March 31, 2000, China’s Ministry of Defense officially delivered a donation (worth RMB 10 million) to the Defense Ministry of Kyrgyzstan consisting of 42 prefabricated buildings, several diesel power stations, and a heating system. The buildings were to be installed at border outposts in remote areas.
Source Titles: China donates equipment to Kyrgyz border troops.
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia
Geographic Location: The buildings were to be installed at border outposts in remote areas.

Title: PLA donates 40 tonnes of military supplies worth RMB 5 million
Description: On January 5, 2001, the People’s Liberation Army of China (PLA) officially handed over 40 tonnes of military supplies (including uniforms and boots) to the Kyrgyz Armed Forces. Kyrgyz Deputy Foreign Minister Asanbek Osmonaliyev and Deputy Defense Minister Boris Poludo presided over the handover ceremony. The Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan and representatives of the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry, Foreign Ministry and the prime minister's office also attended the handover ceremony. This donation was financed with the proceeds from an RMB 5 million military grant agreement that the PLA and the Kyrgyz Armed Forces signed in May 2000.
Receiving Agencies: Armed Forces of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan
Source Titles: Kyrgyz army to get free aid from China.|Kyrgyz army receives humanitarian aid from Chinese Liberation Army.|China gives military equipment to Kyrgyzstan.
Source Publishers: BBC Monitoring Central Asia|BBC Monitoring Central Asia|Reuters News

Title: Chinese Government donates 103 vehicles to Kenyan military
Description: According to the People's Daily newspaper, the Chinese Government provided 103 military vehicles to the Kenyan military towards the end of 2000.
Source Titles: Relations Between China, Kenya Strengthened: Official|POLITICAL WARFARE IN SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA: U.S. CAPABILITIES AND CHINESE   OPERATIONS IN ETHIOPIA, KENYA,   NIGERIA, AND SOUTH AFRICA
Source Publishers: People's Daily|Strategic Studies Institute

Title: Chinese Government donates sniper rifles, body armor, and other military equipment
Description: In 2000, the Chinese Government donated several hundred sniper rifles, body armor and other military equipment to the Government of Uzbekistan. No additional implementation details are available.
Source Titles: CENTRAL ASIAN STATES AND CHINA: PROBLEMS AND PROSPECTS FOR COOPERATION|Chinese Defense Minister to pay an official visit to Uzbekistan   ???????????: https://regnum.ru/news/polit/1384517.html ????? ????????????? ?????????? ??????????? ?????? ??? ??????? ??????????? ?? ??
